Author: y_u_no_python
Content:
These are really useful python decorators that I created in my script library to help when writing new functions (error prone). ü§ì 

```py
import time
import traceback
# ************************************ DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE *****************************************
def error_log(func):     # Wrapper function log error writing (add above function call)
    def errorCheck(*args, **kwargs): 
        try:
            retval = func(*args,**kwargs)
            return retval
        except Exception as Argument:
            logger = system.util.getLogger(str(Argument))
            logger.error(traceback.format_exc())
            print(traceback.format_exc())
    return errorCheck
def timeit(func):
    def timed(*args,**kwargs):
        beg_ts = time.time()
        retval = func(*args,**kwargs)
        end_ts = time.time()
        print("elapsed time: %f" % (end_ts - beg_ts))
        return retval
    return timed
# ************************************ DO NOT EDIT ABOVE THIS LINE *****************************************
```

We apply these decorators to our functions easily with:
```py
@timeit # Apply timer wrapper to our function
@error_log # Apply log error capture
def someFunction(arg1,arg2,arg3):
    # do stuff
    pass
```
If the function is successful, it will return the value and print time taken to output console, if its not it will print and log the error to the Ignition Log wrapper.

An example error would be 
```py
someFunction()

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<module:scripting>", line 17, in wrapper
TypeError: someFunction() takes exactly 3 arguments (0 given)

elapsed time: 0.002000
```

Ignition edge also now has addition ‚Äúfor edge‚Äù prices for mqtt distributor/engine/azure connector etc. 200$ a pop. So ignition edge IoT (transmission) plus engine for edge at a total of 1000$, with 40% discount for 500+ licenses..

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Thoughts on using Ignition Historian vs any other historian?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I don't have first had experience so FWIW, from what I understand it uses a pretty standard SQL database, nothing time series specific so works fine but could have problems scaling at the enterprise level or fast changing data.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content:
Low on the performance scale, low on the cost scale.

Only a collection of specific short, medium, & long-term requirements will determine if its performant enough for a specific use case.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content: Also don't confuse Ignition "historian" with Ignition as a platform.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I am a fan of using the right technology, meaning the technology that can be supported. If a client is using Ignition for other applications and needs a basic historian, the Ignition historian is a good choice. That said, it will not be as performant as other enterprise historians like Canary labs. I will also use the Ignition historian for items like sparkline charts if that is what the application calls for.

Author: tomt4914
Content: Wondering if anyone has used Azure App Proxy for remote access to Ignition Perspective.  I found a couple of posts at IA that mention it, but nothing that had a working solution.  I can get a connection like perspective is loading, but it can‚Äôt get past loading to the root perspective screen.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: From the Ignition docs the historian can with a decent sized server run up to 10k values per second for a standard SQL, and up to 30k for high performance SQL. In comparison Canary can do 300k with similar hardware, and up to 2 million plus with even more hardware, with zero performance hit as db size increases.

Author: y_u_no_python
Content:
1. As everyone has stated, there is nothing wrong with using ignition historian to support an application and show useful data over time. There is however a trade off of the abstraction layer created by the Ignition system to store the data and read it back out (by ignition). Making it "as simple as clicking the history checkbox" means that the application does the brunt of the work for keying, assigning and CRUD operations on the historian DB

2. Having a more traditional standalone historian with additional built in capabilities for analyzing data that is being collected, provides even more benefit. 
     Think of it like the difference between SQLite and a traditional database MSSQL, MySQL, PostGreSQL, etc.

3. The other problem presented with using an embedded solution is that it may not (doesn't in this case) make it easy for other applications to access and use the data. Look for a  historian that can handle multiple input streams and have its own output stream.

Content: Agreed with single-quotes for a string value, but consider using system.db.runPrepUpdate (https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC81/system.db.runPrepUpdate) and placeholders to protect against SQL injection..  Also, the error you got there is also complaining about the `database` argument--that needs to be a named database connection (that you've configured in your Gateway Config -> Database -> Connections area of GW web UI).

Author: andyott33
Content:
For publishing general messaging outside SpB you can use:
```
system.cirruslink.transmission.publish()
```
https://docs.chariot.io/plugins/servlet/mobile?contentId=99057679#content/view/99057679

Or 
```
system.cirruslink.engine.publish()
```
https://docs.chariot.io/plugins/servlet/mobile?contentId=99057679#content/view/33490934

Author: jon.forbord
Content: So, A couple of general bad experiences with Ignition‚Äôs OPC UA client. Mass-adding tags from other OPC UA servers, will in some cases either lead to a struct being interpreted as a document data type, and sometimes it just stops short of 3 levels into the hierarchy. To fix this I figured I‚Äôd build my own tag-adding function with system.opc.browseServer. It kind of worked, but I used a different Opc UA client on the side, and noticed some of the native OPC complex types of the server, would show in the properties that it was data type = ExampleComplexType.. My hopes got up that I could use this to add UDTs as well, by getting the dataType of the complex object.. alas, Ignition .getElementType() or .getDatatype() would return [igniton‚Ä¶.document; Bah.. generally Ignitions OPC UA client just fails to impress me..

Author: mparris
Content:
Yes, as far as I know, their client is still on version 1.03, not supporting the more recent way to represent complex data types.

Ignition was at the forefront of OPC UA, even having a free Modbis-OPCUA offering in the early days.

I get the sense that it is not a priority. I connected them with Matrikon to see if there would be a way for them to outsource their OPC-UA client and server so someone else with the bandwidth and expertise could continue development. Don't know if it will go anywhere.

Author: mparris
Content:
I also struggled with bulk import across about 100 servers and the behavior was finikey like you described. Definitely was a pain anytime the address space of the servers change by adding a variable and had to pull that in across all 100 servers.

SpB was amazing to see the data types all come in correctly and dynamically

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôve read somewhere that 1.04 support will come with Ignition 8.2, but yeah, doesn‚Äôt seem to be a high priority with them.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I don't have enough hands on experience with Ignition to answer fully, but my understanding is that to some extent you can "convert" a vision app to perspective which is why you should develop there first. Perspective is coming along but it's not nearly as mature as vision yet.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: You will want to use Vision for wire-framing the application and eventually convert it to Perspective. While it builds in technical debt is requires less effort to provide the value. Ignition will let you upgrade the Vision license to Perspective.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Thoughts on the best way to design an Ignition system with the intent of MES to consume the plant floor data? The protocol options for MES are MQTT, OPC-UA or SQL. There are silos of PLCs on an isolated networks and no localized on-premise server. (only a regional data center)

I have 2 main ideas:
1) Ignition Edge reads PLC data and sends MQTT messages up to a MQTT broker at regional data center. MES consumes via MQTT
2) Ignition Edge reads PLC data and sends data up to a gateway node at the regional data center via the gateway network. MES consumes via OPC-UA

I think #2 I like best because the gateway network goes thru the store and forward engine so won't lose data when connection is lost between plant and regional data center. Also I'm assuming the gateway network would scale better than MQTT messages as the internal guts of Ignition handles the data exchange between edge and data center. via that network. It seems MQTT we need a bunch of individual Cirrus Logic calls via event scripting and will end up crashing and burning at some point.

I'm up for other ideas entirely, the company loves Telit DeviceWise/IoT platform, but I don't know anything about that system yet.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If your primary focus is MES, I‚Äôm not sure an HMI like Ignition or their peers is the right starting place.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Not sure if I agree with that.  We have found the flexibility of treating ignition like an application platform has hugely helped our MES efforts.  The flexibility of ignition lets you fill in and blend all of the special use cases of MES that MES vendors tend to miss

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Well, given that 80% of MES spend is on custom stuff, I guess it‚Äôs not as bad as some other options.  At least if you‚Äôre using Perspective.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: For sure. Especially with perspective.  A lot of our stuff is in vision mainly but moving to perspective.  The whole reactive and HTML aspect of the front end is opening up some neat integrations with other operational aspects allowing for quick time to value.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôd say 1 or 2 depends on the rest of your architecture. We went with 1, because we‚Äôd have multiple consumers of the edge data, rather than just Ignition. It also keeps the door open to plug in any other application to consume, or use something else than Ignition for SCADA. #2 is a bit of a vendor lock, although changing from remote tag providers to MQTT isn‚Äôt too much of an investment. Like 200$ per edge instance. The custom logic for Cirrus link isn‚Äôt required if you use mqtt transmission and mqtt engine modules.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Both options have store and forward as well.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Thanks. The MQTT transmission / engine modules only does SparkplugB ? Since MES can't read SpB then the only way to sent MQTT with Ignition is custom event scripting?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Depends, you can setup transmission to send as Sparkplug in plain json. No compression and no protobuf.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I think it shouldn‚Äôt be a lot of time to create one script that can be used for tag change event on all your tags. You‚Äôd need the edge compute add on for Ignition in order to do this effectively though.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So, isn‚Äôt that ‚Äúnot Sparkplug‚Äù technically?  I thought protobuf is a required part of the spec?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôve been slightly puzzled over that option as well, but it actually came in handy at some point.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Yeah the MES vendor is looking for a certain MQTT message structure so if they are flexible with receiving that type of message then maybe.  But then I go down the road of the namespace only restricts to 3 levels due to SpB restrictions.

I guess the idea of creating a single periodic event then packaging all the MQTT message in a single payload might work but then we are going around the store and forward engine which I really want to use. (but maybe I'm overvaluing store and forward...)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think it‚Äôs a great option.  That‚Äôs one of my recommendations for improvements to MQTT and Sparkplug -  content types.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why bother with MQTT at all?  Write an ignition script to make a REST call to your MES in whatever format they want.  Still event driven.  No reason to force fit MQTT here.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Trivial to implement a local store and forward approach with the file system and a timer.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: If you‚Äôre ‚Äústuck‚Äù with your MES, it does sound like option 2 is good for this case. You can always go mqtt from Ignition platform to the enterprise level if so needed.

Author: jbonhage155

Content: Yes defintely stuck with the MES, ha ha.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Totally agree with Rick, no need to force fit mqtt at this level if it‚Äôs just way too much fuzz to get to the benefits. You can also integrate to the MES in whatever mechanism makes that integration most effective (and good enough).

Author: jon.forbord
Content: And build your ‚ÄúUNS‚Äù inside Ignition.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: if I had to go with reliability, I think Ignition gateway network is the way to go edge to datacenter. Then from the gateway I can publish MQTT, OPC-UA, REST , etc... but at least I know all the data made it up to the datacenter to where MES will consume from.

Author: jbonhage155

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Just don‚Äôt forget the MES also produces data. So the arrow goes both ways.

Author: rickbullotta

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I think this isn‚Äôt too far off from many UNS implementations. You get the legacy data however you need to do it, using Ignition as the data hub, and setup mqtt transmission module to publish when it comes time to connect the site to the enterprise level. So you have a ‚Äúlocal‚Äù UNS inside of the site level Ignition platforms.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: then with MES to plant floor maybe that's where to use MQTT, once that tag is updated Ignition will trigger an event script to write back down to the equipment.

Author: brodi07
Content: I don't have much experience on ignition and thank you for information. I wonder that Isn't ignition supports plain MQTT ?  Do we just have to use sparkplug b?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think you're optimistic in thinking that the MES system will have triggers or events that you can hook into.  In the case that it doesn't, you can simply use the same REST API approach from Ignition but use a timer event to trigger a refresh/pull from the MES system.  I strongly discourage you from using stuff like database triggers in the MES database - that's fragile, dangerous, and may cause lots of problems when versions of the MES update.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Who is the MES vendor?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Exactly if that‚Äôs your Center piece then use it to handle the translation.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Ignition supports publishing plain MQTT via scripting, but Cirrus link made the mqtt transmission module, which takes the tags in Ignition and converts them into spark plug B. It is probably not too hard to make a module or scripts that will do the same for plain mqtt, but you will then loose all the benefits of spark plug B. The mqtt enigne which subscribes to mqtt and converts mqtt topics into Ignition tags will read plain MQTT, json, spark plug B and a couple of other payload formats.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: What I‚Äôm trying to say is that you don‚Äôt have to use spark plug B, but you can buy an Ignition module that makes doing sparkplug B very easy. So if you want to do plain, don‚Äôt buy that module üòÖ

We can use Ignition as UNS. However, in order to send MQTT payload to MES, it is necessary to write a script suitable for MES in ignition again. Am I correct?

Author: koios6274
Content: How do you normally "use" tags from [MQTT Engine] ?  Meaning, do you reference those directly, do you build a UDT w/ reference tags to MQTT Engine?  I know there are a lot of different ways to do this - just curious what others are doing / have found work well

Author: mparris
Content:
The more dynamic way is to have the Sparkplug node to use templates , which would be ingested as UDTs... Then you can have scripts that scrape the tag tree for certain UDTs to display them /process them, in the specific way each UDT requires etc.

I didn't put that amount of work in, so I just did a rigid structure that my script parses... Which assumes each folder under the specified root folder is structured the same way, like a UDT

I've never used it, but Edge Sync has something to do with how to synchronize projects from a central Ignition Gateway to the edge nodes.

Edge IIoT has to do with how to move tag data or of the edge instance. They also enable you to run project scripts on the edge node with Edge IIoT

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Perphaps @MParris has some insight to the Sparkplug B device? What's the point of the devices in sparkplug B? How are you supposed to use them? They are completely optional as far as I'm concerned, and it's group and node ID that uniquely identifies the node..

Author: mparris
Content:
The Sparkplug "node" is the hardware or application that actually speaks MQTT/Sparkplug.

The Sparkplug "device" is something that is connected to the "node" via some legacy protocol or non-Sparkplug protocol. So the node published it's data on behalf of the device.

Having the device separate allows  an application to subscribe to only the device data, instead of all the data that the node has.

When making custom nodes, we have used devices to represent virtual segmentation of data, for example a node could have devices called "Fast Analog" and"Slow Discrete input", which allow other clients to not get  bombarded with analog if they don't care about it

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Thanks, we're doing excactly this. As I like to abstract away from the hardware design, I'm using the device to subdivide the node-namespace to have the opportunity to do as you say, rather than to represent each physical PLC. I'm anyway providing a sourcepath property as a means to get to the data source when and if needed.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
What brand machine tools are you seeking to connect to?

Most CNCs are implementations of Fanuc, Siemens, or Mitsubishi controls.  For example, Mazak uses Mitsubishi.  Makino, Murata, and Nakamura-Tome use Fanuc.  DMG MORI and EMAG use Fanuc or Siemens.  Because there is variation in controls, there is variation in connectivity.

With the exception of Siemens, it's rare for machine tools to have a native OPC UA server.  And even so, most Siemens SINUMERIK are more like the previous generation Siemens PLCs (e.g., S7-300).  Long story short, you will most likely connect via the native protocol.

[Native Protocols by Control Platform]
Siemens:  S7 comms
Fanuc:  FOCAS
Mitsubishi:  MELSEC

If you're lucky, you might have an MTConnect interface. 

Kepware has native drivers for these native protocols as well as MTConnect above.  These are all included in the Manufacturing Suite.  You can create OPC tags that will connect to registers (e.g., R1000.1) in the machine tools.  These tags can then be exposed as an OPC UA server for Ignition to connect to.  I would imagine a similar approach can be taken with other solutions such as Litmus.

[CNC] <- native protocol or mtconnect -> [Kepware] <- OPC UA -> [Ignition]

Some of the control platforms offer their own software-based OPC UA or MTConnect gateway product.  These can be used in place of Kepware.  Fanuc's FASOPC, as @jpmoniz mentioned, is an example.  These gateways poll the machine tool's registers over the native protocol and expose them as an OPC UA or MTConnect server.  

It's worth mentioning that these products usually don't account for the variation in implementations of machine tool builders.  For example, Makino and Murata implement Fanuc controls in very different ways.  As a result, what registers one polls over the native protocol will not necessarily be the same from machine builder to machine builder.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
To sum it up:
-Determine whether or not the machine has any "modern" connectivity embedded (e.g., OPC UA, MQTT, MTConnect)
-Know the machine builder, model, and memory table documentation
-Know the control platform
-Know the native protocol of the control platform
-Know what gateways can convert the native protocol to OPC UA

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, we (Litmus) will interface with the CNC through a native driver or a common protocol.  Those tags can then be exposed as an OPC-UA server for ignition, and/or sent elsewhere (DB, Cloud, MQTT, etc.) via integrations.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Okuma's controls are Fanuc or their own proprietary "OSP".   If it's Fanuc, you'll use a FOCAS driver.  If it's OSP, you'll need to discuss this with Okuma.  I know Okuma markets MTConnect support, but as with all industrial automation standards, the devil is in the details.  Real world adoption varies depending on the model, options and customizations.  You might be able to use an MTConnect driver with OSP.

Like most machine tool builders, they'll be happy to sell you their own data collection software.  But, you'll need to verify if it can be used as a gateway and not as their own substitute for applications that you would prefer to use (e.g., Ignition).

Author: jon.forbord
Content: IoT Edge (mqtt Transmission module), subscribes out of the box to DCMD and NCMD topics in Sparkplug, which makes it possible to write commands from other Sparkplug nodes. As for subscribing to ¬´flat¬ª mqtt topics, you need the mqtt engine module for Edge. It‚Äôs an optional addon as Edge module for 200$. A slight suboptimal workaround is to set up memory tags in Ignition Edge and write to the DCMD topic to write the value to Edge from other nodes.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: How ‚Äúnot as expected‚Äù? I would try triggering a forced rebirth every 24 hours. The timestamp may or may not change though. Haven‚Äôt tried it.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
are you using History? There's a 'Max Time Between Samples" to force an update ---
"Normally Tag Historian only stores records when values change. By default, an "unlimited" amount of time can pass between records ‚Äì if the value doesn't change, a new row is never inserted in the database. By modifying these settings, it is possible to specify the maximum number of scan class execution cycles that can occur before a value is recorded. Setting the value to 1, for example, would cause the Tag value to be inserted each execution, even if it has not changed. Given the amount of extra data in the database that this would lead to, it's important to only change this property when necessary."

https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC80/Configuring+Tag+History

Author: mparris
Content: I've set up a gateway script that browses the tag provider for some key tags. The script then creates an array of information for Perspective Screens to use to build their displays. This array of information is stored into a memory tag. All the top-level visualizations are bound to this memory tag, so when it changes, then it drives changed in the visualization.

Author: mparris
Content:
I rather than having the gateway script run based on a timer (every five seconds), I thought about making it more event driven so it's not running if there are no new equipment. But I got concerned about MQTT Engine creating events faster than the script could run if adding a lot of equipment at once.

Looking back on it, I guess a middle ground would have been to run the script every 5 seconds to see if data changed, and if not then do nothing, but I didn't think of that at the time ü§£

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
for sending edge data up to a main gateway/MQTT broker, what would be the best method if we want to utilize store-and-forward capabilites? 
But our edge PCs are really full Ignition since each edge connects to 5-10 PLCs per manufacturing line. (can't use the edge version)

So the MQTT transmitter utilizes store and forward when sending to the gateway engine but I'm not sure that is necessary we we can  utilize gateway network to send data up to the main server, then from there do the conversion to MQTT on that server?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: another option -- remove the Ignition gateway in the fog completely (replace with HiveMQ or something simliar) --- then at the plant edge PC's put the tag historian module on each of them so data is never lost and run scripting to publish vanilla MQTT to the broker.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: the goal of this effort is to have a new MES consume data from the plant floor, but also flexible enough that other systems can come along and consume the data

Author: jbonhage155
Content: basicially Ignition is a middleware to the plant floor data. What do like about having a centeralized Ignition gateway is all edge PC's can report into it, then we can run visualization modules from there if the plant want to start leveraging other features (and using it like a SCADA which they currently do not have)

Author: dep05d
Content: The edge/fog gateway network option would work, so long as you can tolerate edge data loss if the fog gateway goes down.  I think the historian + vanilla mqtt may just end up extra work for little savings.  You could have MQTT Transmission running on the fog gateway's "[MQTT Engine]Edge Nodes" folder to effectively relay and buffer the sparkplug data to another broker offsite.  Also, absent the fog Ignition, most brokers (Hive, EMQ, Solace, Mosquitto, Rabbit) have the ability to bridge brokers with guaranteed delivery.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Ignition edge can do more devices than 2 for a price.. I‚Äôm not sure where the crossover is, but I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs more than 10. ‚ÄúBest practice‚Äù.. I don‚Äôt know, but we use Ignition edge with the store and forward enabled with mqtt transmission module.

Author: yaz0002
Content: If you need any help using the THiNC API for your Okumas reach out to me.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: As @dep05d suggests, the architecture really comes down to how much data loss is acceptable - and of course: cost and complexity.  Also, it's not just about data loss, it's also considering the edge cases of duplicate data being accidentally sent and the impact of loading on the collective system upon reconnection.  There are scenarios where you might never be able to "catch up", and do you want to spend those precious resources shoveling up old data or new data?

Author: patanj2
Content: I am guessing that is because there is no Jython3. An advantage to them to using a Java based scripting engine is better integration of python code with their exposed api.  If they switched to a standard python it would make integration much more difficult.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
There actually is/was a Jython3 project, but it has been mothballed for a few years, though some activity pops up occasionally outside of the dormant Github repo.  However, there are ways to get decent scripting performance even if you're out-of-proc.  Not trivial, but possible.  And if done correctly, very scalable. The problem comes with shared state, but within the same machine, that is mostly solvable.  I wrote some extensions to Rhino (the original Javascript engine for Java) to integrate the ThingWorx object model into it.  Initially it was primarily in-proc, but because of the abstraction we added for accessing properties and invoking services/firing events, it became somewhat more distributed.  

GraalVM has a lot of activity, and might be an interesting alternative to Python 3.  I would contend that most of the stuff you're doing in local scripts *should* be lightweight and not long-running.  Thus many of the things you could envision doing in Python 3 because of the rich data manipulation libraries is probably better done in lambdas or microservices and called from the scripting environment anyway.  Better scalability and isolation.

Anyway, it's all doable to some degree.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's an interesting challenge for more complex products - there's an old saying that "you never get a second change to make a first impression".  If that initial experience isn't great because of a lack of foundational knowledge by the prospective user/customer, poor documentation, inadequate onboarding content such as training and examples - the results can be very counterproductive.  Sometimes a hybrid approach where the prospective user experiences the product but against synthetic or staged data/devices can be more effective in those cases, since it takes out a few "degrees of freedom".

Author: espen7732
Content:
I think that some of you probably have some good knowledge of various solutions to use with ignition.

We are starting to use ignition in building automation. Previously we have used iFix and Citect, on local servers.

The buildings we manage usually consist of KNX control of light/heating/vav. Bacnet, opc/ua or modbus for communication to Ventilation, heat pumps, oil boilers, solar systems, pumps etc.
Very often the bacnet is a requirement from the client. Especially in jobs for the state or municipality.
There is great variation in how much equipment going into the scada system. A small building can be just a ventilation system.
A building I'm working on now consists of. 

8 ventilation systems
20 circulation pumps
12 energy valves
4 Heat pumps
1 Electric boiler
2000 knx components
Solar system
blind control
UPS controll
Reserve power
+++

So a building can have 50 tags to 10 000 tags.

Some of our customers have their own VPN lines between the buildings, and their own ignition server. While other customers want to connect to our ignition server in the cloud.

I'm think is a good solution to use an Ignition Edge Solution on buildings with more than 2-3 ventilation systems.
But how many tags would a wago edge computer be abel to handel? https://www.wago.com/global/c/plcs-%E2%80%93-controllers?f=%3Afacet_product_Produkthauptfunktion_5200%3AEdge%20Computer%3AresultType%3Aproduct&sort=relevance&pageSize=20

Author: espen7732
Content:
How big (tags/devices) must the building be before a ignition server licens is better? I see it 100 dollers per device i would like to connect to the edge server.

I also want the option of VPN from outside (service PCs) into the customer's technical network. We have PLCs and ventilation systems standing on these networks.
I have looked at these for a VPN solution. https://www.tosibox.com/for-sites-tosibox-lock-150
or https://www.tosibox.com/for-sites-tosibox-610
Anyone have any recommendations?

I'm also thinking about just to use the VPN solution, for example a tossibox where we only have 1-2 ventilation systems. VPN (Tossibox) to the ignition cloud server.
Is this a good or bad Ide?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: You're way out of my wheelhouse, so just a couple of recommendations, RTA has gateways that could help with the BACnet stuff.  With the volume of data/tags you're talking about I don't see how you do this without a UNS like architecture. If you want more info on RTA, I would reach out to @Jill_RTARocks.

Author: espen7732
Content: Thanks, for your replay. Ignition can receive bacnet directly. When I get it to the ignition edge server it can send it to the Ignition server. And we have used VPN from a building to Citect without any problem. But I need more info about how many tags a ignition edge can take. And what kind of hardware I then need. As for the UNS we use Cross-disciplinary Marking system - TFM. Thise is a marking system for buildings i Norway. +AAA=NNN.nnn-BBnnn.XX +AAA=Location code. =NNN.nnn=System code. -BBnnn = Component code. XX=TagFunction. Eks. +BY5534=360.001-RT401_PV  Thise is building BY5534, Ventilasjon nummber 1,  Supply air temp, _PV=Process value, measured temp

Author: espen7732
Content: A other eks. Eks. +BY5534=360.001-RT401_SP  Thise is building BY5534, Ventilasjon nummber 1,  Supply air temp, _SP=Setpunkt. We have thise on all components and variabels we are connecting to. We have then made UDTs that connected to thise components in Ignition.

Author: espen7732
Content: most of our communication uses Bacnet. We take modbus, KNX, M-bus etc. into Wago PLC and we also send it on to Bacnet. It is often required that all communication to the scada systems must be on Bacnet

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I don't think as far as # of tags that it matters what version of Ignition you're running, they all come from the same installer. Edge just has device limitations (and probably others), so it just depends on how much hardware you throw at it, though at some point you'll max out what java can handle.

Author: .stibbits
Content: You get 2 devices with the Edge license and each additional device connection is $100. I don't know if there is an artificial limit though.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I didn't realize each additional client to an Edge license was that inexpensive. That might solve a problem I'm facing that I will get to in a moment.

While I also believe there is no tag limit inherent in the software, don't forget the importance of hardware limitations on the usable number of tags. One client, at my recommendation, bought the OnLogic IGN600 (they now offer the beefier IGN610) which said it was good for up to 8,000 tags. While it is great hardware, we only have a few hundred tags but a fair number of pretty complex HMI screens, and running both the gateway and the HMI client on the same PC causes the HMI to lag badly. CPU usage remains low but RAM usage is too high, likely hitting the page file hard. Good to know that we could just add additional PCs and the $100 license add-on since the final machine build will have four operator positions (only one built so far).

Author: hobbes1069
Content: When possible (on Linux) I always try to use zswap or zram. It will dynamically allocate memory and compress on the fly (in memory swap), there's some CPU overhead but it's not that bad and as you stated, it doesn't seem to be the problem. Obviously how much compression you get depends on what you're compressing, but it's generally assumed it can effectively double your memory.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Zram is the default on many distros now.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: If you're booting from an SD card (or any kind of flash memory) make sure you're using BRTFS. It's a COW (Copy On Write) filesystem which is much better for flash type storage and aids wear leveling. It also offers transparent compression which can significantly boost I/O performance on slow devices like SD/USB sticks, etc.

Author: koios6274
Content: I have a question for the group.  Say you have an Ignition server and you are using the Cirrus Link modules and MQTT Broker (distributor module).  Say you have 10 edge gateways all pushing information to this server.  You can see all the tags in the MQTT Engine tag provider.  If you want to actually use those tags to build screens - do you reference the tags directly , do you build reference tags or a UDT that point to the MQTT Engine Tags, or other?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: We use Tulip instead of Ignition, but I have been a part of a few of the trainings with Walker. He makes use of a tag/property called `parentPath` which is relative to the current location in the namespace. I would highly recommend not using static absolute paths. That would prevent auto discovery. This is also why it's so important to have your UNS setup in an ISA 95 structure, along with internal standards. You need to be able to know where the data you need is relative to where you are.

Author: .stibbits
Content:
I typically create UDTs with reference/function tags and a path property that points to the MQTT Edge Gateway path. Structure as much as you can on the edge gateway. 
The goal is to make objects.
A lazy way, is to expose tag providers under the OPC UA Server settings and then you can drag and drop tags from the MQTT Engine into your tag provider you are using.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Both, directly and referance, but the basic status and control screens are directly. Referencing when building UDTs from multiple sources in addition to mqtt.

Author: thunt.career
Content: Is there a way to use aggregate functions that reference a path but not direct tags? For example tag = /Site/Area/Avg Compressor Output Pressure; instead of /Site/Area/Line 1/Compressor/Pressure + /Site/Area/Line 2/Compressor/Pressure + /Site/Area/Line 3/Compressor/Pressure you'd have SUM(/Site/Area/+/Compressor/Pressure). Usage would be so Line 4 is auto-discovered and updates the Avg pressure calc without programming.

Author: thunt.career
Content: If you are displaying a dashboard for each edge gateway, you could create a dashboard folder/topic in the edge gateway. This could be used at the local edge gateway on a dashboard display. Then at the central server you could have the same dashboard display, use indirect or expression bindings and have button scripts or the Tag Browse Tree to set the bindings to your specific edge gateway.

Author: thunt.career
Content: You could also create reference/derived tags in a "dashboard" folder/topic at the server gateway to the specific data points you want to display. In Perspective or Vision you could dynamically modify the source path on those tags to tie to whichever edge gateway. Assuming space is limited, you could have arrow buttons to cycle through each edge gateway and look for bad quality on the "next binding" to prevent continuing to cycle.

Author: thunt.career
Content: If you want all data displayed on one screen from all edge gateways and "auto-discover"/"auto-dashboard" there would need to be some kind of script to search through the tag tree and create a dataset of all desired edge tag paths or similar.

Author: joshuastover
Content: If all you have is a hammer, every problem looks like a nail‚Ä¶ will take a look at this article shortly

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
With Industry 3.0 for a long time we only had hammers. The tools weren't there for 4.0. And then people wanted screws, and we only had hammers so we got creative and made it work.

And then I think we were slow to pick up screwdrivers, especially as the first screwdrivers were not the best. But we have electric screwdrivers now, and we can even use them as hammer drills.

I think I've flogged the analogy to death now. But with so many good SCADA options available,  why would you want to use power BI, unless for a bit of fun.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôve kind of had this question myself over the years, what makes SCADA special? And the question has recently gotten relevant, as some IT people think SCADA=dashboarding, so why not just use powerBI or grafana or insert your favorite visualization tool..  So how do you describe a SCADA to a 7-year old. I think of SCADA as a plumbers toolbox, a set of tools a plumber uses to do plumbing. There are other tools you can use to do some plumbing, like a wrench or even some of the tools in a carpenters toolbox. The result may even be functional, but the result would have been better, more efficient and more robust if done by a plumber with his toolbox.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: There are many plumbers toolboxes sold around the world, but they all have a set of tools in common.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
For SCADA these are: 
- A tag engine (a real time database containing the current status of all the objects in the SCADA, everything you see on screens are using the tag engine to show the current state of what you see)
- Alarm system (categorizing alarms, storing alarm event information, when, where, what etc)
- Drag and drop visualization 
- Timeseries database for historical data.
- Scripting (for whatever you can‚Äôt do with the built in tools)
- Communication drivers to controls hardware or common protocols (two-way). 
(Did I miss anything?)
All of these tools are in addition sharpened to industrial use.

Author: akoscs
Content: No idea about ignition, but in general: SCADA is a PC software. It does not have a firmware in the strict sense of formware. It has a development software, where you create the SCADA project and a runtime, where you run the SCADA project (in many cases the only difference between them is what your license allows you to do). I guess the runtime might be seen as kind of a firmware, but because it runs on an OS (mostly Windows) and not on bare metal is it not called a firmware. SCADA does have kind of a driver. It has modules which can read//write form industrial devices (and provide interfaces to other comms protocols) which are very similar to drivers, but are not OS level drivers, since they use the devices in a PC which already exist and have drivers (e.g. the network card). The UI is one element of a SCADA, the other ones are a historian feature (a database like feature to log and query data). Alarms and events (which might be like notifications in PowerBI), you are able to implement scripts in all SCADA, you have some kind of recipie management. From the top of my head that is it, but Walker Reynolds has a great video on SCADA and what are its main elements.

Author: akoscs
Content: maybe reciepie management could be part of the list?

Author: donpancoe

Author: donpancoe
Content:
It's funny, because I started in SCADA with Archestra System Platform, templates have always been there for me. A Wonderware support person told me at the time that less than 50% of their sales came from System Platform, the rest from just InTouch. So I am at least logically aware the UDTs are not "old school."

But modern or not, I wouldn't want to do SCADA today *without* UDTs. So that would have a direct impact on whether Power BI or the like could cut it as a viable alternative.

BTW that SCADA add-in for Power BI is also available from the same developers for Grafana.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The tag engine in Ignition was really the first thing that caught my eye. The way at least a couple other SCADA builds this is having a flat IO tag list, and then you have to build the templates in a different place and it‚Äôs all a bit clunky. In Ignition the modeling and everything is done in one place, and it‚Äôs for the most part super intuitive, flexible and just wonderful. I would call the BI/grafana SCADA add-in something along the lines of ‚ÄúSCADA-like visualization‚Äù. Cool, but calling it SCADA would be like calling an apple painted orange an orange.

Author: jj_dx
Content: Hello everyone, I have a question and was hoping someone could answer. I have created a UDT in the default tag namespace in Ignition. I have enabled transmittor to transmit tags from the default namespace to the MQTT Engine namespace. Everything works well if I can create a tag in default and refresh transmitter. The  tags gets transmitted to the MQTT Engine namespace. However, if I create a new datatype instance in default , it does not get transmitted. Is there a setting that I have missed?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: If zero udts are transferred, it could mean you‚Äôve set up the transmission to ‚Äúconvert UDTs to normal tags‚Äù, did you check this setting?

Author: dep05d
Content: Each time the tag ‚Äúfootprint‚Äù changes in the folders referenced by Transmission, you will need to refresh the transmitter. The MQTT Transmission tag provider provides status tags that tell you which nodes need to refresh.  You could monitor these on a timer or gateway tag change script and refresh as needed.

Author: mparris
Content: Probably not directly related to your issue, but manually adding tags to the MQTT Engine tag could open you up to other issues. The MQTT Engine creates and modified tags within that tag provider, so it's possible that it would overwrite your manual tags is there is a naming conflict.

Author: jj_dx
Content: Thank you all kindly for your help. I have the "convert UDTs to normal tags" setting disabled. Also, I am refreshing the transmitter as needed. I am adding the UDT/tags to the default namespace, not the MQTT Engine namespace. It is just strange that I can create a memory tag and it will get transmitted, but if i create a UDT instance, it will not.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Sounds like a bug. It should work.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Or there‚Äôs a conflict with existing UDT in mqtt engine, so the module ignores the new UDT definition. Tried deleting the UDTs from Engine?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Prior to refreshing the transmission module..

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Anyone have thoughts of running Ignition on Windows vs Linux? 
We are in the process of standing up new servers so its decision time between the two and wasn't sure if there's pro/cons to be aware of.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Any other software (extensions, drivers, etc) have an OS dependency?  What does your IT team know how to manage and support?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I once asked on the Ignition community forums if there was any documented performance differences, and there were none reported. That being said, Ignition is generally considered to be more performant on Linux. Once of the reasons is that you can run headless. Linux has a much lower memory usage baseline than Windows so you won't necessarily have to allocate as much memory in your VM.

Content: How many companies have a rigorous process for installing security updates on Linux in the OT domain?

Author: donpancoe
Content: I have a client with two instances of Edge Panel running on OnLogic DIN rail PCs with Ubuntu 20.04 LTS (at my suggestion). @Richard Shaw was giving me some advice on how to improve performance earlier on in this channel. My high-level takeaway regarding Windows vs Linux: Windows most often has one just one way to do *X*, but a Google search for 'how to do *X*' on Linux usually yields ~5 different ways to do *X*, all of which may or may not work on your distro, version, hardware etc. But at least we're not paying for the privilege. I think becoming more familiar with Linux helps. Just this morning, I'm still trying to wrap my mind around the different *sessions*, say where the GUI is running in one session, but if I SSH in, I'm in another session and can't necessarily see or change what's happening in the GUI session.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yes, separate sessions are somewhat analogous to logging in as a different user in Windows, only you're both actually using the computer at the same time.

Content:
If you want to see what's going on with the existing GUI session there are ways to do that. I've used teamviewer for linux in the past. You'll have to check their ToS to see if you can do that for free.
https://www.teamviewer.com/en-us/download/linux/

Author: donpancoe
Content: I just remembered I have an RDP client running on that machine, although I still wasn't sure if *that* doesn't also end up in another session. I will have to see if that is still working.

Author: donpancoe
Content: And I now remember why I don't do that more often. If the GUI client is logged in, I have to `kill -9 -1` before I can log in via RDP. That wasn't a problem today since the machine wasn't operating, but I certainly wouldn't want to do that to check in on a running machine. I will check out TeamViewer or something similar.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: How are you securing the RDP connection?

Author: donpancoe
Content: It's not on the open Internet. I have to use ConnectWise to get to a different machine on the same subnet then access it from there. I also selectively kill or run the client as needed. Now that I remember that it is not useful, I will just leave it off.

Author: eddiiee_
Content: The plan is to automate as much as possible. But initially the SAOP Equipment hierarchy won't be part of it, we will only open up for the future possibility to link/combine the information in the different hierarchies, i.e. create key-fields but not necessarily have a set standard for everything. So the current scope is to make the OT-signals part of a ISA 95 compliant data model with the additional meta data necessary to connect it to other manufacturing data. That way for instance the equipment and maintenance related data is not incorporated into the data model, it will be a separate but the OT-signals from the machines can easily be connected to other maintenance related data. Does that make sense?

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I will ask my own Ignition question. I have a client with two instances of Ignition Edge Panel. With demo licenses from IA, I got those talking over a Gateway Network using Edge Sync modules to a full (demo) instance of Ignition with the Historian module. From there I could get the tag history out to a PostgreSQL database and review it with Perspective. The client liked the demo, but is in a fundraising phase and didn't want to spend - at the moment - the ~$8k needed to make the demo permanent.

I have been manually running scripts daily to export tag history data to CSV files, and know I could use the Edge Compute module to automate this.

In the spirit of I4.0, I do note that the Gateway Network is technically a proprietary protocol, but it is convenient to set up and it captures alarm and audit data as well as tag history out of the box. Still, I'd be interested to know what other historian applications people are using with Ignition, particularly Ignition Edge. Thanks in advance for the advice.

Author: .stibbits
Content:
I may be off base here, but if you have the data in Postgres you can read the tag history. It is a little bit of a pain.. query the sqlth_te table to get your id and tagpath
Then query the sqlt_data tables for the specific id to get your value. 

I recommend also adding the timescale abstraction layer to your postgres and turning off the data partitioning. Looks like @zackscriven took a stab at this a few years ago.
https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/timeseries-db-for-postgresql/21770

Then, use what ever visualization/dashboarding tool you would like

Author: donpancoe
Content: Thank you for that info, I do think it will be useful. But one limit of Ignition Edge is that it cannot connect to a SQL database, that is a feature reserved for the full version of Ignition. So I had to connect the two Edge licenses to the full (demo) license then push to PostgreSQL from there. If that full license is not an option, budget-wise, I was wondering if MQTT could be used directly from Edge (also requires an additional module, but less expensive) to some 3rd party historian function. If we still wanted the alarm and audit data, I might have to map all of those to MQTT as well, whereas they are automatically captured by Edge Sync and Historian modules we were demoing.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
So the Edge historian doesnt cut it for this case? Would it be possible to expose the tags via the OPC UA server on Ignition edge and use Telegraf to insert to influx DB? 

https://www.influxdata.com/integration/opcua/

Author: donpancoe
Content: Another good idea. Thank you. The built-in historian for Edge is built on SQLite and self-prunes after 7 days.

Author: .stibbits
Content: Oh I apologize! For the amount I have used edge, I never realized you could not connect to a database. Glad I know now..

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Curious if anyone is using Let's Encrypt with a production server. I have tested with both HTTP and DNS challenges, but there are some concerns I have. The HTTP challenge requires Port 80 to be open to the server. DNS is more secure but requires an API call to a DNS. And the server needs to use a public domain (*.com, *.net, *.org).

Author: hobbes1069
Content: That's pretty much where I stopped looking at it and begrudgingly requested a cert/key pair from IT, which still only goes back to the company cert, not to a root CA. üò†

Author: thedavidschultz

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: Has anyone used Ignition's reporting module in a validated (GMP) environment? We mostly use SSRS for our reports but lack the internal knowledge to support and scale-up new reports. I'm toying with the idea of creating a separate reporting project in Ignition.

Author: asthomas
Content: Yes, we have used it for machines running in Azure.  Let's Encrypt publishes the IP addresses of their machines, so you can limit the firewall to only those addresses.  You can also use a shell script to open the firewall to port 80 only long enough to renew the certificate, then close it again.  A big advantage of Let's Encrypt is that we can use our own domain names for Azure VMs, not just the long randomly generated azure.com names.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: You can publish with Ignition to mqtt either using MQTT transmitter module (takes Ignition tags and publishes as SpB), or use scripting with system.cirruslink.engine something something to publish to topics. It should be fairly straightforward to setup a generic gateway tag event script that can be applied to the tags you want to publish. The latter option would then be normal mqtt not SpB.

Hello everyone, I am interested to know your favored approach when it comes to managing alarm setpoints in Ignition, or scenarios where you may choose one method over the other. The two methods I have used in the past are:

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yeah, some intermediary such as HighByte or Ignition and such.  Usually there's a little extra processing needed than just parsing and importing the CSV.  SQL Server has a "BULK IMPORT" statement but it really doesn't let you do any transformation (data types, renaming columns, etc)

Author: thunt.career
Content: Assuming defaults, TCP port 1433 for MS SQL Server. In order to encrypt you'll need to add Extra Connection Properties. You'll need to determine if you want to trust any server or leverage the trustStore. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/connect/jdbc/connecting-with-ssl-encryption?view=sql-server-ver16

Author: espen7732
Content: I have some problems connecting my Ignition/docker Installation with bacnet devices. I can see the devices and ignition from a bacnet client on a other maskin, but I can't get Ignition to connect to the devices. Has anybody use Ignition with docker and bacnet devices?

Author: mparris
Content: Are you binding your docker ignition network to "host" or are you using the internal docker network where the actual ignition IP address is a 172.x type?  If the second, then I suspect some broadcast or multicast traffic is not traversing correctly from one network to your ignition instance?

Author: donpancoe
Content: It is important how your Docker container maps TCP ports within the container to the IP address of the physical device on the network. So if Ignition is at <container IP>:8088, but your network sees <physical IP>:8088, you want to make sure those are mapped to each other.

Author: donpancoe
Content: Sometimes Docker will map TCP ports to random number, such that 8088 gets mapped to, say, 39427. They do this in case you are running a lot of instances on the same physical machine that all use the same TCP port. They can't *all* use port 8088 on the physical interface, so random numbers are assigned. You either have to set them yourself, or keep track of which ones are assigned.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I've been banging my head against the Ignition reporting module, particularly the script data source, and wanted to make sure there's not something I'm missing. My client wants snapshot reports at the start and end of each production run. There will be some other integrate-over-time calculations developed as well, likely in the PLC code, but just capturing a set of real-time tag values at a given point in time (at the press of a button, in this case) was surprisingly complicated.

I was able to get it done using the 'script data source' feature of the reporting module, but that ended up taking enough complicated Python scripting that I almost wonder what the point was in buying a platform (so much for "low-code"). The module is much more oriented towards querying SQL data over ranges of time rather than real-time snapshots. For the latter case, IA seems to promote the Transaction Groups feature provided by the SQL Bridge module, which is another license tier. In fact, the reporting module feels like it was designed with the express assumption that the SQL bridge module would be in place.

This has become more of a rant than a question, but any advice on how to do this better would be appreciated. For example, is there a SQL query that would return only the most recent record for each of the tags in a provided list? I'm sure there is, actually, but I couldn't even see where you would enter such a custom query in any of the reporting module settings.

Author: _dyland
Content:
The reporting module is possibly the most frustrating function of Ignition. But still less so than other reporting tools I have used, in my opinion anyways.

Sounds like you would be looking at the SQL Query Data Source or a Named Query. While triggering the report to run after the latest values have been logged by a script (possibly a tag event of a state tag?).

Without the whole story I cant say for sure but that's my quick thoughts. I have never attempted to use the script data source myself.

SELECT TOP 1 column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE condition; 

https://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_top.asp
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC81/Report+Data
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC81/system.report.executeAndDistribute

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Thank you for the info on the SQL query. I did try it in the "SQL Query" data source and sorta got it to work, but querying the Historian DB is tricky because of its complex table structures.

Instead, I tried the "Tag Historian Query" datasource with both StartDate and EndDate set to 'now()' and that seems to return just a single, most-recent value. I also tried using the CrossTab component instead of the normal Table component, and that offered a lot more flexibility in terms of dropping a mix of static and dynamic values wherever I wanted.

Author: _dyland
Content: Sounds like you are getting it figured out. Yeah, if you are using data from Ignitions tag historian things get pretty complicated pretty quick if you stray from their pre defined historian functions - like Tag Historian Query" data source.

Author: donpancoe
Content: I have a client who is reporting that Easy Charts in their HMI are updating 30 to 45 sec after they see other discrete indications on the screen have updated. Is there a way to optimize this performance, or is this just the nature of a historian-based chart? Are there any other ways to chart real-time data in Vision? Thx

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Historian-based charts do tend to have some inherent delay since they rely on historical data stored in the database. But you can definitely work on optimizing the performance of the Easy Charts. Firstly, assuming  the system meets all the hardware and software requirements for running the HMI and Easy Charts smoothly.

You could fine-tune the historian's settings to optimize data retrieval and storage intervals, which should help reduce the update delay. Additionally, you can add a buffering mechanism to store a small amount of historical data in the HMI itself. This way, the charts can display recent data points faster while waiting for the historian's data to update.

Leverage parallel processing and multithreading capabilities to improve responsiveness during data updates. However, it's essential to remember that real-time charting solutions tend to be faster, but they may not offer the same historical data analysis features as historian-based charts.

If real-time data visualization is a priority for your application, we can explore other charting components specifically designed for real-time data.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Thank you for the input! This is something I will be investigating over the next week or two, so I won't necessarily have answers right away.

Firstly, the PC running this HMI was underpowered, but the replacement upgraded performance by almost a factor of ten. While most things have gotten snappier, not everything has, implying there is optimization to be done.

I was wondering if this might be a case where slowing down the sample/update rate actually improves perceived real-time performance. I will have to investigate.

When you mention a "buffering mechanism," can that be done with UDTs, datasets or something else within Ignition, or does that require an add-on solution?

I will look into how moving off Ignition's default multi-threading settings could benefit, here. This processor, I believe, is a hybrid containing both Core  and Atom cores, with 8 cores total.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: With the caveat that I don't currently use Ignition but have participated in some of the workshops here, there's absolutely a way to do it, but it would probably take some python programming. I don't know what the best way would be but just keep appending to a list for a max length and then start pruning.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Short answer, yes. One common approach is by using Tag Historian within Ignition. This allows you to store historical data for specific tags over time. By enabling Tag Historian for the relevant tags and setting appropriate storage settings, you can create a buffer of historical data that can be accessed by the Easy Charts component or any other data visualization tool in Ignition.
 Also, you have the ability to work with datasets, UDTs, and other data structures. These structures can be used to manage and organize the data retrieved from Tag Historian or other sources, making it easier to display recent data points alongside the real-time data on your charts.

So you should be able to do this without an add on solution.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I am actually using Edge Panel, so I only have one option: the Edge historian But other than the 7-day pruning limit, that should work the same as the Tag Historian in the full license. In fact, in a fairly recent update, Ignition added the same internal SQLite Edge historian to the full-license version to provide exactly the same short-term buffering that we're talking about here, separate from an external historian.

So all this just means that it's strange that we are seeing the lag in our case. I will have to investigate further, doing my own experiments rather than relying on anecdotal data.

Author: vaughnturner
Content: That is strange, time for some root cause analysis.

Author: carbonnanotubes
Content:
Good day everyone! How is a dataset represented in Sparkplug B? To give a little more context, I am wanting to store the BOM in a dataset within Ignition Edge node that I would also want forwarded to our edge gateway but I am not sure how to format the payload to update the dataset. Would updating the BOM in ignition even trigger a Sparkplug B message to be broadcasted? 

Edit: I should also add that I am not building my interface within Vision or Perspective. I am building an external interface that I would like to communicate exclusively over Sparkplug B.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: No value in doing so.  Just represent it as JSON.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If you insist on it being Sparkplug B, there are a bunch of SDKs and libraries that will serialize and deserialize it.  It's a protobuf payload essentially, using the Sparkplug B structures.

Author: carbonnanotubes
Content: I know that but what is the structure of the payload to update Ignition? Is it an array of objects with keys that match the dataset structure?

Author: patanj2
Content: For that level of detail I would either look in the SparkplugB specification‚Ä¶.and/Or inspect the payload coming from a dataset published btthe MQTT transmission module from Ignition.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I can check, but we did something similar with document and datasets on a custom spB client we were building. We reverse-engineered it from a payload sent from Ignition. It makes use of custom properties. I‚Äôd generally say documents or json is easier to deal with in general in Ignition, datasets are cumbersome..

This is to say that analytics, workflows, applications, or integrations of any kind are additional software or systems to really start delivering real value. And each stage would include both hard cost and soft cost that mounts rapidly over time + opportunity cost.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: I increasingly question the benefit outside of Device-to-SCADA scenarios.  There is not much that supports it above the SCADA layer and it gets clunky when aggregated.  Additionally, the aggregated nodes (e.g., gateways, scada, historian) are generally hosted on well-managed infrastructure that do not necessarily benefit from the sort of state management it was intended for.  If it frequently must be converted and engineered around, why use it?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
The intent is when a new node connects, it triggers a refresh from other nodes to get current values. The upside is it gets all current values. The downside is there is a lot of network traffic. SpB was geared toward automation applications where this would not happen often. This is opposed to MQTT which was geared toward remote assets with intermittent connectivity, hence the retain flag. The transmission module  includes scripting functions which will publish retain flags. Link is below. Last I checked, an Ignition Edge Compute license will be required to enable scripting.
https://docs.chariot.io/display/CLD80/MT%3A+Python+Scripting

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I certainly understand the intent. But that‚Äôs exactly where retained messages help!  And the traffic overhead can be significant with even a modest number of clients connecting and disconnecting often. I‚Äôve proposed solutions that involve separating data and metadata, leveraging retained messages for both, and expanding metrics into separately subscribeable topics.

Author: jprocess
Content: Trying to understand the differences between Ignition Vision and Perspective, can someone explain the main differences please?

Author: og_grendyl
Content: @JProcess  Perspective is web based and is served to the consumer via web browser.  Vision requires a client app to be installed.  Development environment for Vision is more like a typical industrial HMI.  Both are still supported and developed, but my feeling is that between the two options, Perspective will be the future of the platform.

Author: jprocess
Content: @Grendyl hmm from their website it sounds like both are web-based, but cool thanks.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Vision and Perspective are both modules in the Ignition Platform. A basic breakdown of the software stack driving each will show that vision is not web based.

Vision is based on Java Swing and thus requires Java to be installed on the client (This is handled in the background in later releases). In Vision the project files are loaded from the Ignition Gateway and stored locally on the client machine as a Java Application. Java handles the updates from the Gateway Automatically and reloads the project files from the Gateway. This is the client app that @Grendyl mentioned.

Perspective is built on modern web technologies like HTML5, CSS, and JavaScript. Perspective projects are run within a web browser. When a user navigates to the project URL, the browser fetches the necessary files (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, etc.) from the Ignition Gateway.

Personally I like Vision for HMI / SCADA applications and Perspective for SCADA / MES applications. But that's just me.

Vision is a lot more familiar to those who are used to traditional SCADA and HMI software.
Perspective allows for easier responsive UI development and runs natively on mobile devices where features like GPS and Camera access are available.

Here is a Blog Post from Ignition that desdcribes when they reccomend to use each.
https://inductiveautomation.com/blog/vision-perspective-which-module-is-best-for-your-next-project

Author: asthomas
Content: Sparkplug is designed the way it is to work around a single fundamental problem: it wants to be a reliable report-by-exception end-to-end protocol built on top of an unreliable broadcast protocol.  The Sparkplug pathologies, like birth storms, are a necessary side effect of that.  The need to use non-retained messages is another.  The moment you introduce retention of NDATA and DDATA packets, you have to give up report-by-exception.  Separating the model from the initial data values doesn't help in a significant way - you still need birth messages containing the whole data set in exactly the same circumstances, whether or not those packets also contain model information.  In fact, since MQTT makes no guarantees about message order, separating them introduces a race condition.  I have implemented both Sparkplug B and Sparkplug 3 directly from the spec, and although Sparkplug has a number of points of fragility, there are very few decisions in the spec that I found to be unnecessary or inexplicable.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Simply not true.  Report my exception and retained messages are not mutually exclusive at all.

Seeing the same benefits as @Grendyl alluded too. Prototype fast and iterate fast.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Any good explanation for qos 0 on DDATA?

Author: carbonnanotubes
Content: It is not needed for sparkplug. To get existing data you trigger a NBIRTH or DBIRTH which will include all the data that that node or device has.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôll argue it is, if you‚Äôre using SpB as a source for storing event history, wouldn‚Äôt a lost package mean part of the history is lost forever with QoS 0 ?

Author: carbonnanotubes
Content:
no because the device that emitted that new value still has the new value. The difference between MQTT and Sparkplug B is with MQTT ensuring packages are received by each client is up to the broker where with Sparkplug B when a client comes online a NBIRTH or DBIRTH is triggered.

For example with my scenario I was trying to account for. I have a Ignition Edge gateway publishing tags to our local Ignition Gateway. The MQTT Engine module broadcasts those tags to other clients. What if one of those client goes offline for some reason and a tag that barely ever changes, changes? Each client is subscribed to DDATA and DBIRTH for the namespace, when the client comes back online and subscribes to that DBIRTH topic it gets all the data again. You can even manually trigger a rebirth as well to republish the NBIRTH/DBIRTH.

As for the connection between my edge gateway and my local gateway, you can enable Store & Forward. When the primary host id become unavailable all messages will be stored and sent once that primary host id comes back online

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Which is a HORRIBLE design choice.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Separating DATA and METADATA is one of the keys to making Sparkplug "C" better, along with automatic metric -> topic expansion and mandatory use of the "persist" flag.  This will solve most of Sparkplug's major flaws in just a few changes.

Author: carbonnanotubes
Content: Finally got it

Author: asthomas
Content: Yes, it is true.  RBE means that the producer and consumer agree on prior state at all times.  Exceptions are relative to the prior state, so if you don't know the prior state, you can't have RBE.  Retaining a single message that says "temperature is 40" tells you nothing about the prior state of "pressure". If you retain that temperature reading you are implying that it is somehow sufficient to know the current state of the system, which it is not.  The birth message contains a stale prior state, but if pressure changed between the birth and the publication of temperature, then a newly connected client has no way to know the current pressure.  So, to avoid the implication that a retained DDATA message is somehow useful, it is not retained.

Author: asthomas
Content: MQTT is implemented over TCP, which makes the following guarantee:  either every byte is delivered in order without loss, or the socket closes with an error.  There is already a mechanism in Sparkplug to resynchronize a newly connected client, so a failed socket results in a resynchronization.  Since a transmitted DDATA is guaranteed to arrive (assuming no disconnect), you don't need confirmation.  Why waste the handshake time?  QoS 0 allows you to pipeline messages.  QoS 1 and 2 introduce slowdowns of 2x and 4x network latency, respectively.  With MQTT, there's a third failure case - MQTT brokers don't guarantee that every packet will be transmitted.  They could be dropped due to a full queue.  In this case, the DDATA sequence number will be wrong, so the receiver will need to trigger a resynchronization.  That's a relatively rare event, so it's better to have the much higher throughput of QoS 0 and to accept the rare synchronization event.  Besides, QoS 1 and 2 make the full queue state more likely, so the resynchronization will occur more often.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @asthomas, you just advanced to level 5!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You‚Äôre looking at it from the publisher POV - I‚Äôm looking at it from the subscriber POV.  Of course the publisher needs its own state to know if something changed. But ‚Äúretain‚Äù is on the broker, not the publisher. Two completely different things.

Author: asthomas
Content: Not so.  Looking at it from the subscriber's POV, the subscriber wants to know the current state of all tags.  When it connects to the broker it can only see the most recent DDATA message.  Let's pretend that the DBIRTH was retained, which it is not.  The client has 2 pieces of information - the original state of the temperature and pressure, and the current state of the temperature.  It cannot know whether pressure has changed since the birth message, so it cannot know whether its view of the system state is correct.  In order to square this circle, the retained DDATA would have to contain the state of every tag, not just the most recently changed one.  And that is no longer RBE.  So, you have a choice - report by exception or retained state, but not both.  EDIT: just to be clear, this is not a general statement about MQTT or RBE.  It is a specific statement about Sparkplug.  The fact that Sparkplug sends all data on a single topic is the confounding factor here.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Ah - I finally see the disconnect, and it's addressed by of the changes I've proposed to Sparkplug.  xBIRTH should be just metadata, not data, in which case retained messages make a lot of sense.  If the metadata changes, the edge node can republish it with the retain flag.  Tooling and client apps can subscribe to metadata topics and get the latest info without any round trip to the edge node.  In terms of xDATA, I've proposed that the consituent metrics be expanded into retained topics/messages on the broker side.  This way, subscribers can subscribe to ANY topics and know that are likely they have the latest values.  This all relates to the "multiple metrics in a single xDATA message" issue.  Another option, but one that will take a long time to get incorporated into the MQTT spec, would be a "multi-publish" message type that lets a publisher publish more than one topic in a single message, each with its own payload.  I'm not gonna hold my breath on that one!

So I'm glad to see we're basically saying the same thing here.  Let's try and push the Sparkplug (and maybe MQTT) folks to implement changes to fix these flaws!

Cheers.

Author: asthomas
Content: As they say, the devil is in the details, and there are a lot of devils and details in Sparkplug.  Your best bet would be to join the Eclipse Foundation's Sparkplug working group.  That would help both to drive change and to understand the devils.  I doubt you'll see a Sparkplug spec that breaks up xDATA into individual MQTT topics.  That eliminates any advantage Sparkplug brings in terms of bandwidth.  You might see xBIRTH messages retained in a future version, but that will do nothing for the rebirth storm problem, and it will introduce race conditions that I haven't seen a practical solution for.  A multi-publish capability in MQTT would do nothing for bandwidth or throughput if you're using QoS 0, so you'd have to justify it on the basis of QoS 1 and 2, which Sparkplug rarely uses.  And, bear in mind that some of Sparkplug's flaws are due to MQTT's flaws.  I'm not convinced that they are solvable without also changing the MQTT spec or demanding that the broker be able to inspect the contents of Sparkplug packets.

Author: donpancoe
Content: Sorry I was out-of-pocket yesterday, but it sounds like you figured it out. The firewall is integral to Linux and fully restrictive of inbound traffic by default. UFW is Ubuntu's tool to manage the firewall. Disabling UFW, I believe, simply disables the tool but not the firewall itself.

Author: jeff_flow
Content: Definitely outside my depth here but will share something I recently learned. Once a UDT definition has been established, there is not a way to modify that definition without deleting the UDT and republishing. We ran into this issue when publishing UDTs via MQTT Templates of our KPI Metrics. Everytime we add a new KPI (change the def) to the Metric we would have to technically delete the UDT manually. It is suggested to overcome this that you use versioning within the UDT name.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I tested your used case and this is the behavior I would expect. While you are publishing an Ignition UDT, the Sparkplug specification treats this as a Template, which does not include the typical tag properties, like Scripting. The Engine UDT is "owned" by the publishing source so changes to them would not be reflected by the underlying tag instances. Because Engine converts the tag into a standard Ignition tag, you are able to perform scripting, alarming, history, etc., on those instances. One option is to create a local gateway UDT that references the Engine tags. If you continue to publish the edge UDT, you will need to create unique names for them. Hope this helps.
