Author: carbonnanotubes
Content:
@Ted Garrison  my vp of tech sent me this link https://docs.chariot.io/display/CLD80/MQTT+Transmission+Transmitters+and+Tag+Trees

this is the part that explains it

> Sparkplug Overview
> 
> All MQTT clients using the Sparkplug specification will publish MQTT messages consisting of a topic and payload component. For the Sparkplug B specification, which is used by MQTT Transmission, the Topic Namespace structure is defined as
> 
> spBv1.0/GROUP_ID/VERB/EDGE_NODE_ID/DEVICE_ID
> 
> where
> 
>     GROUP_ID is meant to represent a logical grouping of Edge Nodes. This can be a region, a facility name, or any meaningful grouping of Edge Nodes within your application.
>     VERB provides an indication on how to handle the payload of the message. This includes whether the message is a birth certificate, death certificate, data message, command message, etc.
>     EDGE_NODE_ID is the ID of the logical Edge Node. This is often the name of the system running Ignition with MQTT Transmission.
>     DEVICE_ID is the ID of a device attached to the Ignition instance. This can be a PLC or logical grouping of tags that represent a physical or logical device connected to Ignition.

I'm still not 100% sure what a device would be but as in the quote above, in my case the device would be my PLC. Though I'm not actually taking values straight from the PLC I've created UDTs to represent the data coming from the PLC so I decided I don't have any devices ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: A simple example would be a production line. The Group ID is the line itself as they may be multiple controllers on the line. The Node ID would then be the controller, as it is the point when the network stops and non-network information is gathered. The Device ID would then be the sensor itself.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Regardless of interface/protocl support, I would imagine it's preferable to integrate using the API.  

MES is really a bunch of transactions and rules sitting on top of a data model.  When an MES has support for telemetry / data access protocol like OPC UA (or MQTT), one is limited to capabilities of the MES to transform raw telemetry into events that are congruent with the transactions.  For example, if what is exposed over OPC UA looks wildly different (e.g., machine cycle count) vs what the MES expects (e.g., production record id, container, serial number, lot, batch, qty good, qty rejected, rejection code), it can be challenging.  A PLC or SCADA may not necessarily have all this information.  At some point, the automation events need to conform to the transactions and rules of the MES.  Some MES apps are more sophisticated than others at doing this, but there are limits.

If you need to workaround Ignition's publishing limitations or abstraction for Critical Manufacturing, DM me.  I have some ideas.

Author: jdingus
Content: After some investigation we are going to explore Keycloak which can integrate into Ignition as well.

Author: dale_99289
Content: Keycloak plus Ignition is solid. As with most authentication it can get complicated if you need multi-tenancy for a cloud application. Corso Systems has a decent guide on getting it all set up, and there are a number of folks hosting cloud-based Ignition systems using Keycloak.

Author: jdingus
Content: Good to hear.  Now that we know it‚Äôs solid on the Ignition side of things got to see how it fits into our C# applications.  Should be fine.  One negative is a single point of failure, solve one problem and create another.

Author: akoscs
Content: Keycloak is an open source tool implementing OAuth2, OIDC and SAMl protocols. If you use Office365 for example in the background you have Azure AD implementing more or less the same. So..you can connect that Azure AD instance to ignition. Much easier since you only manage one identity provider, which you do not host.

Author: jdingus
Content: We use AD for all salary users and we do plan on using Ignition to authenticate those users that way.  For our shop floor users we do not create AD accounts and that is where we are struggling to find a single identity provider for Ignition and legacy C# apps that cater toward the same shop floor users.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Have you considered using something like Okta Universal Directory?  UD could contain all your users and, for the salary subset, federated with AD.  Using Desktop SSO, salary users would get automatically authenticated in Okta when they log into AD.  When they launch an application in an AD session, they can jump right in.  If they launch an app outside of an AD session, Okta will prompt for authentication.  This is the same experience the shop floor users would experience.

Okta can be setup as an OID or SAML-based identity provider in Ignition.  The legacy C# apps could be reworked with an Okta SDK or used as-is by leveraging the Okta Access Gateway. 

What's nice about Okta is its lifecycle management capabilities.  It can orchestrate and automate all the provisioning of users in various applications.  It can be setup to monitor HCM or some source of truth for personnel data and make the necessary changes.  This can really help with environments with high headcount and/or turnover.  Manually administering identity can quickly become a lot of work.

Author: jdingus
Content: Excellent feedback js.  Okta looks very powerful.  Only concern I have at this point is licensing costs.  Looks like they break out pricing by feature.  With how important Auth is these days I would think the costs should be justified.

Author: kiwimalice
Content: Does the ignition reporitng module allow for tags to be written back to. Was hoping to ditch a spreadsheet and already have reports setup at the enterprise level

Author: donpancoe
Content: History tags and other databases are accessed with SQL queries. Real-time tags are accessed through *script* queries which are written in Python. The `system.tag.readBlocking` or `system.tag. readAsync` Python functions are used to read tags, but `system.tag.writeBlocking` or `system.tag.writeAsync` should also be available to use in those scripts. I would guess that the script only runs once when the report is first previewed or generated, however, so if there are any values that must be calculated in order to be written back to those tags, that would have to be written into the same script. I don't know if a separate *Tag Calculation Query* would work, for example.

Author: donpancoe
Content: Thinking, a few days later, about how report queries can reference other queries only if the referenced queries are *above* them in the list. This probably indicates that the queries are executed in list-order, top-to-bottom. So if the script query in question is towards the bottom of the list, it should actually be able to reference results of any query above it in the list.

Author: willemrs
Content: Hello, I'm trying to configure the Ignition Cirrus Link MQTT server modules to send out flat MQTT messages instead of Spark Plug B messages. It appears that the only internal option is to write a script and place it on a tag change event to get similar functionality as the SPB with report by exception. Alternatively, I've used a script that can crawl the hierarchy, similar to what was used in the Apache Nifi walkthrough video. What is the best approach to achieve this? Also, if we write a script that crawls through the tag folders, are we forced to publish on a timer? Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: While I'm not suggesting that you do this, another option is to write a simple app or a broker extension that listens to Sparkplug B messages and expands them into flat MQTT messages.  That's what I've done.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Here's some code you can experiment with.  Just run it as a standalone process using NodeJS.  You can configure the MQTT server and whether you want "flat" topics published as JSON or as simple value strings also.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There are plenty of optimizations and improvements that could be made to that code, but it'll give you something functional to start from.

Author: willemrs
Content: Awesome thank you.  Yeah Il give this a shot.  The internal publish scripts from cirrus link work to test things out but they seem pretty bulky when trying to publish even a relatively small namespace.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I ended up doing the same thing.  I query the tag provider then publish json payloads defined by the script.  It's by no doubt a hack.   I have it running every second and executes in about 59ms but it's only about 50 tags or so.  The problem with the script approach is there is no good way to compare whats changed to RBE.  I guess you could save last state to a tag array but thats gross.  That's why the tag change method is popular but forces you into UDT's if you want it to scale. otherwise it gets super tedious editing tags. It would be nice to have a non spb module that would make this more native and less of a workaround for missing functionality.  Or just use something like hive MQ edge and connect it to the OPC side of things and publish from there.  again not the best option but an option.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Random sidebar:  Why is non-Sparkplug MQTT referred to as "flat"?  Don't the topic limitations and the monolithic metric payloads in Sparkplug yield a more "flat" topic namespace?

Author: zeratall
Content: That has always been my thought, question as well lol.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I would think it's just the difference in publishing to the root. How it got coined as flat who knows.   If you talk in terms of topic depth I would think the same as you both.

Author: zeratall
Content: I think it also comes from how most producers publish their data, I know with Kepware, if you use an MQTT IoT Agent, it publishes all the tags inside an single topic. I think that's probablly pretty common for most producers. Which may be why some refer to it as flat, but I agree, JSON gives you a lot more flexbility, and if you use something like Highbyte you can expand or flatten that structure as you deem best. Which is actually one of the ways we use IH at NGC lol.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Good point. Wasn't thinking about it from a payload perspective.

Author: mparris
Content:
I agree, that "flat" likely came from not being limited to publish data within a hierarchy as defined by a specification, such as Sparkplug, which requires publishing data within the minimum topic structure spBv1.0/<groupID>/NDATA/<nodeID>

vs

flat MQTT allows data to be published with the minimum topic path, such as "myData" or "yourData" which can live at the root level of the broker

I think @Walker Reynolds coined the term. I assume it's synonymous with the term "vanilla MQTT"

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Just this: "spBv1.0/<groupID>/NDATA/<nodeID>" ü§Æ ü§Æ ü§Æ

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Almost, but not quite as horrible as OPC UA node ids.  This may be the worst IIoT technical decision ever made:

https://documentation.unified-automation.com/uasdkhp/1.4.1/html/_l2_ua_node_ids.html

Author: patanj2
Content: Options on MQTT transmission are SpB,  spBjson which is json but metrics still bundled in one payload,  or writing a script.  You can also use a dataOps tool to expand and publish as well.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I know what you mean. I only did it that way because I was lazy and it was my home lab setup. The problem looked like a nail and had my trusty hammer.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: But spBJson really isn‚Äôt a thing, is it?

Author: patanj2
Content: Not a standard and not customizable,  but it is an option in MQTT transmission module.  It is just the SpB payload formatted as json instead of protobuf.  I had to publish data to a Siemens Industrial Edge device for a dashboard and for MQTT that required the json format like an S7 based PLC would publish over MQTT. If I had to do it over,  I should have just integrated using the built in Ignition OPC-UA server‚Ä¶. It wasn‚Äôt that many tags.

Content: In my uber broker prototype this is what I'm using (after converting from protobuf).

Author: koios6274
Content:
I have a machine where I can log all of it's diagnostic data neatly into a SQL Table. There are maybe "50" different types of messages, and "10" or so of those messages we want to have alarms on.  I'm sure I'm over complicating, but how can I make alarms based off table data in SQL?  The "alarm message" is unique so I have a way to grab unique messages from the table.  I thought about having some type of AlarmUDT that has a QUERY TAG built to grab the TOP 1 from the table  and compare that to the previous TOP 1, and if it is different, and it meets the list of alarms then trigger an alarm (which would subsequently be fed into an Alarm Pipeline for notifications which is the ultimate goal"

It's often to easy to get into solutioning right away, but the root issue at the core is "I have data being logged into a neat organized SQL Table.  I want to alert people when certain rows get added that meet a criteria"

Author: joshuastover
Content: You're on a perfectly reasonable track. If you have more specific questions about how to implement we can find you a resource to get your questions answered.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The other way is to keep track of the timestamp of the last alarm, and then just subsequently query for alarms newer than that.  Or use an incrementing long integer unique value field and do something similar.  You'd need some place to keep state in either case.

Author: walker.reynolds

Content: If using a mixture of MQTT and GWN or even just one or the other - to make a UNS you need a MQTT Broker correct, as a minimum technical requirement?  So are people using the default tag provider on the 'enterprise' gateway as the UNS?   Then create publish scripts to publish this data to the MQTT broker if coming from the GWN.  Then you would have to create Reference tags to the MQTT Engine and other GWN tag providers so everything is in one location.   I know Walker showed screenshots of his UNS and it looked like it was in the default tag provider as there were memory and expression tags, which you can't add to a MQTT engine provider.    Thanks for the info just one of the confusing architecture ideas if using Ignition as the IIOT platform.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi @DSI_101 here's a comment from one of our Solutions Architects, Alex Klein, at Intellic Integration. 

 Alex Klein
MQTT and an IIoT platform such as Ignition are technologies used to facilitate a UNS. A MQTT broker by itself is not a UNS. The UNS is the structure of the data. It is possible to have a robust GWN as your UNS architecture if done correctly.

Author: rogerjgreeley
Content: Has anyone had issues with Tag groups with Modbus?  I am connecting multiple power meters using the Modbus TCP driver.  When grabbing tags out of the meter I am able to do the first few.  For all of the tags I setup a tag group with a value of 15 minutes called PowerMeter.  If use the default tag group, my tags populate, and if I change the tag group to the PowerMeter tag group the value becomes BAD.  I have an open ticket with Ignition and hope to work on it further today, but thought I'd see if anyone has ran into this issue before?  Here are the notes from my ticket with Ignition.... (FYI.... the current workaround listed does not work).

Author: rogerjgreeley
Content: I got a call back from Ignition and they had me go to the Modbus driver and uncheck Span Gaps.  This is the comment from Ignition "‚Ä¢    It could be possible that span gaps is unintentionally invalidating the tag quality when we are pulling in data for the rest of the tags "  It seems to have fixed the issue.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Roger Greeley, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: rma002
Content:
Is there an automated way to convert database columns into ignition query tags 

I tried chatgpt by giving it the csv file and tag xml but it hasn‚Äôt worked so far

Is this something I could do with transaction manager or named queries? So far I don‚Äôt think it could populate all the 2000 tags that are currently columns in a DB 

Thinking of maybe writing a Python script now

Author: pdmitriev
Content: Sounds like a straightforward python script. I‚Äôd rather not map 2k tags in transaction group üôÇ

Author: rickbullotta
Content: One other thought: define UDTs that correspond to the columns in a row? Fewer tags, grouped contextually.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Really depends on what the data looks like... Without knowing the structure it is really hard to give any advice - there are a lot of ways to get tag values from a database. Personally, I would stay away from Transaction Groups.

As Rick said above, I would map the data to UDTs.

I would add to that: Per UDT I like to do a single query tag with expression tags pulling the data out of the dataset.

But again, what direction you want to go is very dependent on the desired tag structure and database schema.

If you need the tags created dynamically, you will need to go with Python scripts. Probably a script that queries the database and creates (or populates existing) UDT instances.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Has anyone here ever connected Ignition Historian to TimescaleDB? I have a client that is migrating from straight Ignition Historian to a more event-streaming approach based around MQTT and InfluxDB (moving towards UNS and self-serve analytics). Ignition doesn't seem to explicitly support Timescale, but it does support Postgres, which Timescale runs on top of, and I have seen some posts on the Ignition forum indicating that this can be done. I am not sure, however, if such an integration would achieve our goals.

In short, I am wondering if there is an alternate / parallel path to our end goal (self-serve analytics) that can leverage the investment already made in Ignition Historian. This would be entirely at the edge, with MQTT still being our UNS strategy for connections beyond the plant floor.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why not just stick with InfluxDB?

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Just investigating the "free beer" options first. In addition to the costs of InfluxDB (which we would bear anyway under our primary plan), there is a $5k module to tie Ignition directly to Influx. Not saying that this module isn't worth every penny, but this is a PoC for a funding-limited startup.
https://inductiveautomation.com/moduleshowcase/module/kymera-systems-inc-influxdb-history-provider

Author: rickbullotta
Content: InfluxDB itself is free unless you need the HA scenario.  Maybe we can create a community supported free option?

Author: donpancoe
Content: That would be great. I sill have more to learn about how these platforms work under the hood (still mostly a hardware guy) before I could contribute significantly, but I was hoping some of the roll-your-own types around here might have already done some work on this.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Not Ignition, but I do export data from Tulip to a TimescaleDB instance. Short answer, it doesn't need to support Timescale directly since it is just a layer on top of Posgres. Simplying a bit, but there's two main parts to Timescale. The hypertable which you create, and the Timescale specific extensions (functions). The hypertable is transparent to the client and the functions are all used in standard SQL queries.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
https://learn.umh.app/blog/why-we-chose-timescaledb-over-influxdb/
I use timescale for my MING POC Architecture, basically because @Jermuk wrote this article

Author: hobbes1069
Content: The key, is when you do queries that take advantage of the TS specific functions, you often have to include and group by the columns which are distinct. Your timestamp within a state aggregation can not be a duplicate within a returned row.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Hopefully I explained that well enough, I'm not a SQL developer and am still learning with the help of ChatGPT.

Author: donpancoe
Content: All very good info. Thank you to everyone. One more question for now: we already have Ignition Historian writing to vanilla Postgres today. Could we just use Timescale on the back end? Or does the data have to be written into the tables differently from the start?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: It may be possible, but not recommended. I think a lot of the extensions are written in Rust, so while technically possible, it may be difficult to install the extensions on an existing database. I would highly recommend using their docker images, specifically the HA (High Availability) one. It's much larger because it's based on full Ubuntu instead of a smaller base image but includes the most functionality.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: You could then move your data into a new table, create the hypertable, and go.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: That way you could also play with the current data without affecting production until you decide to migrate.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Also, if not already setup this way, I highly recommend using the timestamptz data type (time zone aware) for your timestamp column.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Also, also, I highly recommend DBeaver as the database manager unless you have something paid/better. It had a little learning curve but it has a lot of functionality for a free product. The paid version has even more.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Influx 3.0 will flip that script.

Author: jermuk
Content: Really? first, they finally adressed a lot of the points in the article with SQL/flux, etc. but not all of them. they even doubled-down and rewrote their database a third time? that is definitely not good for reliability and maintainability. and because they reqrote it now 3 times, will there be in 2 years not a influx 4.0 which will be again incompatible?

Author: jermuk
Content: @jamesgresql, maybe a good question for you

Content: No doubt that the back and forth or tech stack, query language, etc has been an issue - but 3.0 really looks impressive.  I've been using the cloud stack since the edge stuff (free version) isn't until Q1 or Q2 of this year, but I do like what I've seen so far.  It's at least worth a look!  Cheers.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Sort of, not really.  

Ignition's Tag Historian is designed to work with regular database tables.  It has its own schema, compression, and partitioning.  It does not really make sense for anything other than module to query it.  It's very dependent on Ignition's internal data model.  If you've ever looked inside of other various process historians solution running on MS SQL, you'll have a familiar "well, this isn't exactly helpful" experience.

As Richard mentioned, Timescale is PostgreSQL + timeseries extensions (e.g., hypertables, interpolation, aggregates).  The relational functionality of PostgreSQL can be used alongside the timeseries functionality of Timescale.

You could use the Ignition Tag Historian module with this, but it would be no different than running using a "vanilla" relational PostgreSQL database.  The Ignition Tag Historian module wouldn't make use of Timescale's features.  It has its own special binding to the standard relational tables.

Apparently, some of have experimented with the tag historian module's optimization settings and converted the 'sqlth_1_data' table to a hypertable in Timescale.  It's not clear how well this works or is even optimal with Timescale.  A typical Timescale architecture would have more than just one giant "tag+time+quality+value" table.  Timescale can have multiple timeseries tables each with multiple columns.  This allows to optimize design to sampling, querying, use case, etc.  I would imagine all of timescale's partition and compression magic work better, out-of-the-box, in a typical architecture.

Another option would be to try the SQL Bridge module.  It's generally designed for logging complex events (i.e., rows) and not necessarily historizing tags.  It won't have the usual Ignition tag history experience and built-in visualizations of the historian module.  You could construct a stored procedure to interface with the timeseries functionality in Timescale.  It would be like constructing your own query.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Ignition has done an estimate here:
https://inductiveautomation.com/resources/article/scada-historian

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content: At the start with the Timescale setup you turn off all of Ignition's built-in partitioning/archiving. How much data is already there? you'd have to do a migration/conversion

Do you know if there is any write-up on how to set up Ignition Historian to work with Timescale? I had seen some posts in the Ignition forums, but nothing formal. Thank you.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I don't have the background knowledge of how the historian module works like @js so it looks like there is no direct way to do it. From what I could interpret from his post is that you COULD (not saying you SHOULD) have the Ignition historian push the data into a Timescale hyper-table, but then to take advantage of TS, the SQL queries would need to be external as the historian module has no idea how to use TS for it's internal visualizations.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Thanks for sharing.  It seems people have tested this, but I have not seen anyone conclude it's a significant improvement.

I would expect that hypertable writes would be faster than the regular tables.  Being a timeseries, it would have less transactional overhead than a standard table.  But, it's interesting that it's not significantly more performant than MS SQL.  I'm wondering if the "chunking" process is not as efficient when it's on just one very large table.

What I'm more curious about is the query and storage performance.  When it's one giant table with tags spanning in each row, how well does the partitioning and compression work?  There may be additional overhead to "unpack" the partitions and retrieve the rows of containing the tags and timestamps of interest.  The partitions in Timescale are time-based.  It's not clear if whether Ignition's historian table is optimal in this context.

Author: vikanchira
Content: The only way to know is to do the DIY test. Best wishes ~ üòÜüòÜüòÜ

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
If the Ignition tag historian moduleis used to write the to the hypertable-converted ‚Äòsqlth_1_data‚Äô table in Timescale, the module can still make user of it for queries.  The bigger question is if Timescale actually yields benefits with the very specific binding the Ignition tag historian module makes to the table.

Using transaction groups with SQL Bridge, you‚Äôre right.  The familiar tag historian module features would not be making use of this.  It would function more like a standard relational query.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Thinking about it a bit more there should be "some" benefit but not sure how much. You definitely wouldn't be able to take advantage of the TS specific aggregation functions, but with the table chunks being partitioned by time, timestamp heavy queries should still be quicker.

Author: pewright
Content: How stupid would this be? I'm working with a company whose IT dept operates under a cloud first approach. A test lab wants to deploy Ignition with a fleet of (eventually) about 80 plcs. The IT guys in charge of cloud are saying "we have redundant Internet connections to that site, you don't need an on-prem edge node, not even a VM".  They are asking why we can't "just try it". I've offered all the reasons I can think of (security, latency, etc) to no avail. How would you respond?

Author: ted.garrison
Content: "sure, we can try it. But when that connection drops and the factory shuts down, YOU can explain to the CEO/COO why we don't have an on-prem setup"

Author: d_leblanc
Content: I would think cost would be much higher. We have traceability systems that are bi directional. Some machines rely on part data that was created in another operation, interlocks that prevent the part from running if it didnt pass a previous operation or was rejected etc. If we lose connection, production is down until connection is restored. We only use on-prem.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: Is the redundant internet connection with different providers? last year there was an internet outage with 1 provider that affected 12 million subscribers and lasted 15 hours to several days in some areas. It affected internet, mobile data so in that case if the business relies on the connection to produce parts, they would be down

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Is it for SCADA or MES functionality? I would have less of an issue with MES but very reluctant for SCADA
I was going to suggest
- Ask It for the uptime measurements of the two connection last year. Essentially can IT prove that Cloud Based 
- Ask them what is the minimum latency and jitter that Ignition will work for for the intended application and what is the last years figures for that look like.
- Ask them for a breakdown of the expected cost of production downtime and if it will be absorbed by the IT budget.
- What is their maximum time to resolve issues.
    
But then I though, at some point SCADA will probably migrate to the cloud, 

As part of the Roll out, can you not do a proof of concept, One in the Cloud and one on-Prem and measure the performance.

Author: pewright
Content: So it is a product testing lab, not a factory producing finished goods. Impact of an outage is still high but capped at the VP of Engr level (loss of product testing data, not direct revenue), so not likely to hit the CEOs radar. But overall I agree with your point.

Author: pewright
Content: Yep, and i've seen estimates that about 95% of these projects are still done entirely on-prem. I'm in favor of the gateway instance being in the cloud but would still like an edge instance on prem.

Author: pewright
Content: yes, different bandwidth providers

Author: pewright
Content: "But then I thought, at some point SCADA will probably migrate to the cloud"  <-- I think this is the root of the question: if you had NO FEAR of ever losing connectivity, what would prevent you from running plcs off the cloud? No high speed fieldbus protocols involved, just ethernet-capable late model Mistubishi controllers running mechanical actuators all day, counting duty cycles and a few other attributes.  A single testing job can rack up ~ 5 million operations before the part fails, taking several days, so losing connectivity mid-job is the only real risk, and the loss is mostly wasted time. You have redundant connections with automatic failover to the cloud.

Author: mparris
mparris
Content:
Assuming (1) no failures in the system, (2) all communication can occur atop TCP/UDP, and (3) the worst-case latency is acceptable, there is no technical reason to exclude PLC from the cloud.

That said, engineering goes beyond what is feasible in ideal conditions and develop robust solutions through Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), Risk Assessments, and Cost comparisons.

After working through those processes, the feasibility if running Process Control (PLCs) in the cloud is typically eliminated.

Author: eddiiee_
Content:
A question about best practice for data storage that I haven't found googling around and reading the forum.

We're using the tag-historian to store all tags/data that we see fit in Ignition. And that's great to use their integrated graphs and queries etc to show data. But what I found is that it only applies to time-series data. 

For instance workorders doesn't really makes sense to store as a normal tag. Example. for every day/shift we have a workorder with PlannedQuantity, PlannedStartTime and PlannedEndTime etc, all the key parameters. Now I want to store all main workorder information + total energy used, total water, number of quality deviations and more for each specific workorder. To make it simple I would like to create a "workorder table" in the database. I have played around with transactiongroups but found them a bit clunky, so I'm thinking of scripting this as Event-data, to seperate from normal time-series data. This was done in the MES bootcamp. How are you handling this? Do you have scripts for storing to the database? Or are you storing everything through taghistorian? Transaction group? other? What's the best practice here?

There is a lot I could detail about this, but don't want to make a too lengthy post. Our MES is taking care of workorder data, but now we want to connect the data in Ignition to our MES into the UNS. That's why it hasn't been an issue. Feels like a super basic question but still a clear road forward has eluded me.

Author: douglawrie
Content: Works fine most of the time in my experience. No performance issues on gateways with ~10,000 tags in my experience. If you‚Äôve got a redundant gateway pair, however, you will have to set up some way of transferring between them which can be a bit screwy. I would say use Sparkplug if it‚Äôs an option. Some OPC-UA clients don‚Äôt like tags that update infrequently on the OPC-UA server. At least with Sparkplug nodes you can refresh them at will.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Seems to work fine for us.  We have gateways with about 100K tag in them and no major issues. Any limitation I have seen is more on the device driver communication side of things.  That limitation is more of the PLC hardware/fieldbus limitation anyways.  For example if you try to pull a ton ~>50K of tags/UDT's from a Logix processor. Things start to bog down.  Forces you into optimizing UDT's/AOI's and things like that but again not fundamentally  an Ignition OPC issue.

Author: nick1352.
Content: Guys , I am just wondering if anybody had experience to poll some data from any kind of BnR controller into the Ignition !

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Most B&R controllers have an embedded OPC UA Server interface.  You could use the OPC UA Client driver within Ignition to connect to it.

Author: nick1352.
Content: @js do you mean UDP Driver?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm referring to "vanilla" OPC UA (Client/Server TCP Data Access).  Ignition's OPC UA Client could connect to this:
https://www.br-automation.com/en-us/products/networks-and-fieldbus-modules/opc-ua/x20-bus-controllers/x20bc008u/

You mentioned UDP.  I'm assuming you're referring to OPC FX (OPC UA TSN).  I believe B&R implementation relies on UDP for transport.  OPC UA FX, while based on mainstream ethernet tech, is more like a fieldbus protocol in practice.  It requires specific hardware support among the network interfaces and switch.  While these have began to show up in some network components, they're not necessarily implemented by the products themselves.  Ignition's OPC UA Client does not support OPC UA FX.  If it did, it would need to be on a host and network with TSN support.  OPC UA FX is more relevant to a field application than a SCADA application.
https://www.br-automation.com/en-us/products/networks-and-fieldbus-modules/opc-ua-over-tsn/bus-controller/x20bc008t/
https://www.br-automation.com/en-us/products/networks-and-fieldbus-modules/opc-ua-over-tsn/switch/0acst0521/

Author: nick1352.
Content: @js thank you for reply , this is  the module that I am referring to it                  https://www.br-automation.com/en-us/products/io-systems/x20-system/bus-controllers/x20bc0087/

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @nick1352, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Ah, it's interesting that B&R also have support for Modbus/UDP.  One does not see this often.  So, you could theoretically, use the Ignition UDP driver, but you would need to define delimiters and compose scripts to parse the Modbus payloads.  The easier thing would be to use the Modbus TCP driver.  This does the parsing.  All you need to define is define the addresses.

The "vanilla" OPC UA module is probably the easiest option.  Unlike Modbus TCP, OPC UA is browsable.  You won't have to know which memory objects in the controller to poll or subscribe to.  They'll be exposed over the protocol.

Author: nick1352.
Content: But I couldn‚Äôt find any driver for BnR on OPC UA connection of Ignition!!!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Those are the companion drivers that get exposed within Ignition's own OPC UA Server module.  While B&R has its own propertiary fieldbus (POWERLINK), I don't believe it has its own native protocol.  They've always generally had some sort of OPC support.  You would use OPC UA or Modbus TCP.

[Ignition | Modbus/TCP Client] <-> [Modbus/TCP Server | B&R Controller]
[Ignition | OPC UA Client] <-> [OPC UA Server | B&R Controller]

Documentation:
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC81/OPC+UA+Client+Connection+Settings
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC81/Modbus

Author: mparris
Content:
This is a problem you will need to solve on the operating system that Ignition is running on.  Having two NICs in overlapping subnets is typically a network no-no.

Consider using an external Network Address Translation (NAT) appliance to get around the duplicate IP address issue.

Author: mparris
Content:
Something isn't right with that architect's response...

A single instance of Kepware can't fix the network issue of the PLCs having duplicate IP addresses.

Unless your architect is suggesting one instance of Kepware per PLC.  But that sounds WAY too expensive.

Author: mparris
Content:
Yes, I understand that problem.  Many deployments use this same approach: assign same IP address to each PLC to help maintenance.

An industrial NAT appliance will be your best option here.  If you aren't aware of any, Moxa NAT-102 is a great funtion-to-value option.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think he's recommending this based on that the host system will have multiple NICs.  Kepware as an application can bind a device channel to a NIC.  Most implementations use the default NIC defined by the OS, but it was more common in the past with serial communications to define a specific NIC.  Depending on the network topology, there are also some things that can be done within the OS or hypervisor (e.g., vSwitch).  But, this probably isn't scalable with more than a few nodes.

I agree a NAT appliance or even a proper field switch (managed, l3, nat) would be the way to go.  This is the only scalable way to get the device and network to look "normal".

Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks @js I didn't' know about that feature.

I'm also cringing at the inevitable situation with maintenance:

"Which 192.168.1 network is THIS cable for again?"

Even more cringe-worthy if the PLCs have standardized their registers, where the cables getting swapped flips the data without anyone even knowing it.  Ouch!

Author: rma002
Content:
For recipes, do we store in plc and in scada/mes as well? 
How does the handshake work? If my line has 10 PLCs each operating a certain unit
Would that mean I need to create one fixed parameter DB and and one DB with no values that can talk to scada/mes ? 

If my scada is down I want hmi to execute these recipes but then how does the handshake between all these PLCs work?

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: For an Ignition project I did I had the recipes stored in a database, accessible by the Ignition HMI. If the network goes down the Ignition HMI loses it's connection to the Ignition server and fails over to an Ignition Edge version of the project which is essentially the same but it did not allow the operator to load a recipe. It had to be entered manually if they wanted to change anything. All of the other HMI operations worked. This was only 1 PLC.

Author: sherman9236
Content: Is there a way in ignition to track the amount of data from specific tags in OPC-UA server?

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Here's some advice from one of our Solutions Architects, Michael Walker. 

https://opcconnect.opcfoundation.org/2017/02/analyzing-opc-ua-communications-with-wireshark/

He could also look in the Diagnostics for Server and Client on the OPC UA connection. Kind of difficult to navigate and I believe it wont tell you specifics about "amount" of data, more like counts of subscriptions, queues and so on.
I'm not 100% sure without trying this myself, but you should be able to export a wireshark profile and, filter to specific tag subscriptions and then add up the total volume of data captured on the wire.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
The Ignition sizing guide suggests a max of 10,000 historian writes per second per Ignition server, with a "large" configuration, but that's with Ignition's history module.  Canary is capable of faster writes, but hard to say where the bottleneck(s) actually are.  I'd ask them both.

https://inductiveautomation.com/resources/article/ignition-server-sizing-and-architecture-guide

Author: diederik9434
Content:
Hi everyone, I'm looking for a historian fitting for my usecase.
I have a beginning OEM that wants to collect data from its machines worldwide.

Ideally it should be: cloudbased, easy to setup & maintain, able to connect to MQTT and/or OPCUA and cheap

We very price bound and not very IT minded. Ideally i would have a historian as a service somewhere in the cloud. I dont know many of these. (Factry.io & Canary?) These are pricy. 

Second best option i could think of is to reproduce their functionality kinda DIY.
using cloud grafana, cloud influx/timescaledb and nodered connection i was able to make something.

other option is to have a local NAS with some docker containers and visualize locally (and connect over VPN?)

Anyone has some experiences/recommendations? 

Thanks! Diederik

Author: trentc
Content: I‚Äôm not the expert on this topic but i think generally you should get any value changes in the mqtt broker asap for distribution, because other applications may want to act on the data as it updates in ‚Äúreal time ‚Äú. This includes any services that would historize  it, which could be multiple services or applications. It seems like an extra step when you only have one instance of ignition but when you scale out with more applications, you might wish it was in the mqtt broker for access and distribution.

Author: francisco.olano
Content:
**[Remote] Seeking Ignition Consultants for Automotive Digitalization Project**
Hi Everyone,

We have an exciting project in the automotive sector aimed at digitalizing operations, and we're on the lookout for experienced Ignition consultants to collaborate with us. Our client is keen on streamlining their processes, moving away from Excel-based systems, and harnessing data from PLCs to monitor production efficiency more effectively.

Here's a brief overview of the project requirements:

**1) Elimination of Excel Dependency: **Our client is seeking to transition away from Excel-based tracking systems towards a more robust and automated solution. They aim to leverage Ignition's capabilities to efficiently manage data from their PLCs.

**2) Real-time Production Monitoring: **The primary objective is to utilize PLC data to accurately count good and bad parts in real-time. This will enable the client to promptly address any issues and optimize their production processes.

**3) OEE Dashboards: **Additionally, our client desires comprehensive OEE (Overall Equipment Effectiveness) dashboards. These dashboards should provide insightful analytics to help improve overall equipment performance and identify areas for enhancement. (**See attached images**)

If you're an experienced Ignition consultant with a proven track record in PLC integration, real-time data visualization, and dashboard development, we'd love to hear from you. Please reach out to discuss this exciting opportunity further and explore how we can collaborate to deliver exceptional results for our client: francisco.olano@spcpro.com .



Best regards,
Francisco Olano
francisco.olano@spcpro.com

Author: pocsgeza
Content:
At a client we will have an Ignition SCADA that will be above many subsystems. We have an internal software that would require some data points/events from Ignition. The most important use case would be accounting.

MQTT communication was not part of the original SCADA project so we are trying to get an approach that minimizes development time on the Ignition side.
Because there is time pressure until startup we are considering the following approach:

1. add the Transmission module to Ignition
2. create a tag collection in a folder with all the tags that are of interest to us
3. publish all that is in that folder with a transmitter to a broker
4. the clients internal application would then get the data from the broker and do any needed unpacking.

We already have a local simulation setup that does 1-3.

It we had more time we could maybe do some other approach.

My question:
As far as I know Transmission uses SparkplugB. Sparkplugs documentation mentions QoS 0. That makes me worried that I can potentially miss data points/messages that are required of accounting.
Am I correct in this fear and what can I do to mitigate it?
Would it be so hard to mitigate that I am better of buying and setting up the MQTT Explorer module?

Author: ricardo_maestas
Content: How dependent on getting *every* message do you want the solution to be considering it is expected to function in the real world? Different MQTT QoS levels can guarantee at least once/at most once delivery of a message, but all other things being equal the robustness of the underlying infrastructure can be as impactful as QoS. Making the appropriate architecture decisions and hardening the infrastructure will be more impactful than adding modules/complexity imo. One approach I've found useful to guide the architecture conversation- consider a BC/DR scenario where the accounting app does not get the data (or consider the business process they're using today without it). Will the solution be more fragile overall if complexity is added to the architecture? The answer could reveal where it's appropriate to draw the line.

Author: pocsgeza
Content: It is a good point that BC/DR is probably a bigger concern than any potential data loss from SpB.

Author: dk4.0
Content: Any suggestions on how we can limit the number of Alarms displayed in Alarm Journal Table to a certain number e.g. recent 20 alarms? Thanks in advance.

Author: darkthedude
Content:
There is no native way to limit the amount of alarms. You would need to use SQL and make a custom query to limit the amount of data you are seeing for example:

```
SELECT TOP 20 * FROM alarm_events
ORDER BY eventtime DESC
```
Or
```
SELECT * 
FROM alarm_events
LIMIT 20
```
Depending on what DB you are using.

Author: vikanchira

Yes, we developed Energy Management and MES Lite application on Ignition and offer them to the customer. 

You can use the main application as the parent project and inherit them to the child project. Seperate the tag provider and database for each customer.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Also what are the pros and cons in your opinion?

Author: vikanchira
Content:
We have standard library of Namespaces and UDTs for the applications in Ignition CE

If possible Edge IIoT Gateway, such as Ignition Edge IIoT, would transform the data into the standard format and transmit it to the application Namespace.

Otherwise you would transmit from the edge into an 'Edge' Namespace in Ignition CE. You then transform the tags into the Application UDT using expression and reference tags.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Pros => low cost, low barrier of entry

Cons => Lantency, Connectivity issues would cause problem. Even with Store and Forward you have to go back and backfill the calculation tags in the database.

Author: donpancoe
Content: Is there something in Ignition like a UDT parameter, but that exists at the project level? Most of my UDTs have a parameter called *SysNum* that identifies what cell the UDT is running on. When it's time to stand up a new cell, though, it's very time consuming to have to change that parameter on every instance of every UDT, then make sure they are all correct. I can imagine doing something like this with tags, but running `system.tag.ReadBlocking` within a script, then parsing the results just to find *SysNum* is tedious compared to simply direct-referencing a parameter value, e.g. *{SysNum}*.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: It may just be me, but I'm not following what you're asking.  Can you diagram it?

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Will diagram a bit later when I get a chance, but let me try with text for now...

IU videos show examples where you create a "tank" UDT, and give that UDT a parameter called *TankNum*. You can then use the multi-instance tool to create several tank instances at once and give each of then a unique value for *TankNum*.

Now imagine I create that tank UDT, and several other UDTs, with another parameter called *SysNum* that indicates that this tank (or pump, or valve or whatever) exists within a specific system/cell number. I could then build up a new System4 by using the multi-instance tool to deploy all the tanks, then to deploy all the pumps, then deploy all the valves etc.

But when I do that, I tend to forget some UDTs, or there were field modifications made to System4 that I want to propigate forward. So to build System5, I just want to export the project for System4, change a single parameter value within that project from 4 to 5, and have all the UDTs within that project now reference that single *SysNum* value rather than the each having their own *SysNum* value that has to be set or changed individually.

Author: ted.garrison
Content:
You can cascade parameters down if I remember correctly - so you coudl have a "System" UDT that then contains the others, and cascade the parameter.

Or, you could use scripting to "build" your structure.  system.tag.configure can do some great stuff once you figure out the syntax (which is relatively easy - just export to json a tag that is configured the way you want, and copy the json)

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
I'm a bit confused since tags are gateway scoped and not project scoped.
I'm gonna assume that by "project export for System4" you mean tag export for the System4 tags.

If the systems/cells always have the same structure, I'd create a system/cell UDT composed of tank UDT's (and pumps, and valves, and whatever else in there).
The "field modifications" you made to system 4 that you want to propagate to new cells, apply them to the system UDT template.
System 5 is just another instance then.

You can link your SysNum parameter of the child UDT to the parameter of the parent.
Screenshots attached show an example for a System 3 (SysNum = 3), based on a System UDT with 5 tanks.

Or skip the child parameter and link directly to the parent, but a bit less flexible.
You can also use tag providers, folders and reference tags, and create tags by scripting, and/or editing tag export JSON.
sometimes a UDT is not the ideal solution.

Good thread on this: https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/tag-structure-udt-setup-and-best-practices/76474/17

Author: _dyland
Content:
Yeah, Parameters are a UDT thing, not a folder thing. When to use each is an important architecture decision. UDTs at too High of a level reduce agility but standardize better. I myself, typically start UDTs at the Equipment / Asset level.

When it comes to parameters, sometimes it is what it is if you miss a few and have to backfill. There are ways to automate it further though if the need is there.

You can write direct to UDT parameters as though they were tags in newer versions of Ignition. You can nest and extend parameters in nested UDTs too. 

I attatched a sceenshot of nested parameters incase it helps.

Author: _dyland
Content: At a past integrator, we were getting to the point of productizing the base code. We went pretty deep into code generation for Ignition tags and AB PLC logic. Once we had the format and UDTs standardized, creating scripts to make the tags based on a dataset was pretty trivial.

Author: _dyland
Content: Tag exports are JSON as of v8, before that it was XML. You can import and export csv and xlsx as datasets through scripting though. Ignition has some baked in functions. A pretty simple workflow is import an excel file that populates a table, have the option to modify the data in the table, press a button that takes that table data and creates the tags at a specified parent path (ex. Tags/New Tags/ ... )

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Zack! 

- Transmission takes Ignition-tags and turns them into MQTT Sparkplug B.
- Distributor is broker, correct. 
- Engine takes MQTT topics and payloads (regular and Sparkplug B), and turns them into Ignition tags.
Transmission is usually used on the Edge, and engine is used on the central gateway (a consumer).

Author: jpmac.s
Content: I thought it was just me , but it seems the Cirrus Link offering is a bit confusing. Or everyone is right to an extent and uses it differently?

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
No.. but they are a bit confusing.    You can say one is a publisher and the other is a subscriber, but technically both of them will publish and subscribe‚Ä¶ not to add further confusion. 

But its all built around Sparkplug Edge nodes and host nodes. Transmission creates Sparkplug B Edge nodes. Engine can serve as a host node. A Edge node publishes DATA and BIRTHS, while host nodes will subscribe to those topics. The Edge node subscribes to CMD topics while host nodes will publish to those topics. Host nodes are typically SCADA systems, and Edge nodes are typically PLCs or Edge gateways.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Engine also can consume (and through scripting publish) regular MQTT.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: You have broken it down well there and it makes sense. Would you typically run Transmission and Engine on the same server?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: What are your thoughts on it?

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I will further confuse things with my understanding from talking to IA sales since my client has recently upgraded older Edge licenses specifically to gain MQTT.

You put Transmission on an Edge gateway and Engine on a full-license gateway. If you do both, the Edge and the 'core' gateway can fully communicate with each other over MQTT just as they would over the Gateway Network. 

However, both the Edge node (with Transmission) and the core node (with Engine) can publish and subscribe to a broker, and can both send and receive messages.

Distributor is the MQTT broker that has to run on a full-license gateway, whether or not that is the same 'core' gateway (with Engine) described above.

Author: donpancoe
Content: To clarify further, you could just put Transmission on the core node to give it pub/sub capability, but only Engine will give full Edge Sync capabilities without the GN. There would be no need to install both Engine and Transmission on the same core gateway. The former supercedes the latter.

Content: If you want publish a tag tree to vanilla MQTT is your best option to use the cirrus module scripts?  And do you still need the transmission module to do that?  I'm getting the feeling the transmission is SpB only?

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
More or less yes, the purpose of the module is to take Ignition tags and turn them into Sparkplug B. Natively Transmission will do Sparkplug B, it does support JSON instead of protobuf, and you can publish to vanilla MQTT with scripting. 

Both engine and transmission modules will support mqtt publish with scripting.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: You publish the entire tag tree with a fairly simple tag change script, but I have no idea how well that scales.

Author: donpancoe
Content: When you install/activate Transmission, it creates a folder called 'MQTT' at the root of your Edge tag provider. Any tag placed in that folder automatically publishes a SpB message on value-change of that tag, to a topic based on that tag's path. Any messages received on that topic will change that tag's value if configured to do so.

Author: donpancoe
Content: You can send SpB over JSON instead of protobuff, but it's still otherwise SpB. As noted, to send vanilla MQTT, you have to use scripting.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: To what group/node id will that be publishing?

Author: donpancoe
Content: I'm still coming up to speed on this, so I will have to look at that later.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Its been a while since i did a fresh Transmission module install, but I wouldnt explain how to setup Transmission that way. 

You setup connection to a broker, and then you setup transmitters, which can be setup to take all tags in a given folder, or the entire tag provider if you so choose, and turn that into Sparkplug B. It will natively enable an Engine to send commands to those tags.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: When you setup the transmitter you choose folder, group and node is, and device id. If you leave device ID  empty, it will default to the top level folder names as the device ID(s).

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Every time you modify the content of that folder with new tags or delete tags, or add metadata, you have to reset Transmission module in order to trigger a rebirth. New tags will not publish until that has been done.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I am testing the following Ignition script as a means to write arbitrary data to the Historian, or at least a different table within the same Postgres database as the Historian
`system.db.runQuery("INSERT INTO my_table (column_1, column_2) VALUES (value_1, value_2);", "My_DB_Connection")`

The query actually *does* insert the row into the database as intended, but the script throws a java.lang.Exception. As far as I (and ChatGPT) can tell, this is because `system.db.runQuery()` expects a PyDataSet containing returned values from the query, but INSERT doesn't return anything. I've tried different forms of  `try: except:` statements, but they don't catch the exception, probably because it is thrown by Java, or Jython, rather than Python.

Can anyone recommend a way around this? The client doesn't have the SQL Bridge module and doesn't have budget to buy it right now. Thank you.

Author: _dyland
Content: https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/appendix/scripting-functions/system-db/system-db-runUpdateQuery

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Thank you. That worked. Guess it pays to read all the docs myself and not *just* the part that ChatGPT recommended.

Interestingly, running `system.db.runUpdateQuery()` in the the Designer's Script Console threw an error - and did not work - if the Designer was in Read Only mode. That didn't happen with `system.db.runQuery()`.

Now to decide if I want to run this script on the client machine, or send a message to the gateway to have it run there.

https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/appendix/scripting-functions/system-db/system-db-runPrepUpdate
Makes it easier, faster and more secure (unless it's static values you're inserting).

Author: _dyland
Content:
Well yeah, Edge is not the full Ignition license. $900 gets you the bridge from OPC to MQTT. You can have UDTs and you can use scripting to contextualize the date at the edge if that is needed but you will still need a consumer of the MQTT Messages. If you need it bidirectional than that is a whole different story.

Easiest route is to just set it up. The trial should be more than enough to prove if Edge will work or not. You can easily try it with and without additional modules too.

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Edge cant be power up with modules like the MQTT Engine?

Author: _dyland
Content:
At that point, I would think about a full license without the perspective or vision modules.
Ignition Platform  is $1,100 + the MQTT Modules and keeps the door open to add more functionality later if the need is identified. Really depends on what you are trying to do.
The original question made it sound like you only needed data out, for that you should not need the 3rd party modules.

Author: _dyland
Content: My recommendation is still to just set it something up with the trial and see what works for you.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
In Ignition (8.1.39), I have a timer script on the gateway that, with a 5000 ms interval, should read a tag (int), add the number 5, and then save the same tag with the new value (a simple counter, in other words).

However, the script is running many times per second, despite being set to run at a 5000 ms interval.

testcode:
`def main():
    import system
    def myReadCallback(readResults):
        if len(readResults) > 0 and readResults[0].quality.isGood():
            counter = readResults[0].value
            newCounter = counter + 5
            system.tag.writeAsync(['[default]Test/TestTagInteger'], [newCounter], myWriteCallback)

    def myWriteCallback(writeResults):
        pass

    try:
        system.tag.readAsync(['[default]Test/TestTagInteger'], myReadCallback)
    except:
        pass
main()`

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Is it being triggered again on change?

Author: andersgustav
andersgustav
Content:
And when I start it, it takes 5 seconds for it to run the first time, and after that, it seems to run constantly.
After 30 seconds, the value of the tag had reached 380, meaning it had run 76 times when (in my mind) it should have only run 6 times.

Author: b_dawg_17
Content: Why not use the current time compared to a starting timestamp to measure time? Or is there a different reason you need a tag to increment by 5 every 5 seconds?

Author: andersgustav
Content: I currently have the function running in a script that compares current time to starting timestamp that is stored in a memoryTag, however this now and then fails and does not write the correct starttime to the tag. So I wanted to check if I could use a timer, and then found out that this goes to all my timer scripts.. Then it is a problem I need to figure out.

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
I have a couple suggestions for you:
1. When asking for help, think about the larger problem you're trying to solve, not just the details. It looks like you ran into a classic XY-problem (https://xyproblem.info/), where you asked for help to solve the wrong problem.
2. The Ignition forums (https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/) are going to be a much more helpful place to get answers like this. I'm not saying you can't ask for help in this channel, just that you'll consistently find fast and quality help there (for these types of questions).
3. When bugs are happening at random times, I like to use Ignition's loggers to passively collect debugging information. That tool might help you find more problems in the future. (https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/appendix/scripting-functions/system-util/system-util-getLogger)

Author: mickgriddle
Content:
Hi @RayKeh, if you're trying to connect to the DM Broker as an Ignition Gateway, you won't be able to.  Either it's not an ignition MQTT Broker or the 8088 port is blocked on the server. (I'd guess Zack is using Mosquitto or something like that to get it up for us to publish to.)

So as long as your MQTT Transmitter module connected to tcp://45.76.236.64:1883 you should be able to publish your tags to the Broker.
If you're wanting to see the tags from the DM Broker in your Ignition Designer, you'll just add tcp://45.76.236.64:1883 in your MQTT Engine module. as a server.  Then in Tag Browser, Navigate to MQTT Engine and You'll see it listed under Edge Nodes.

Author: jonathanswisher5228
Content: What is the point of adding a custom namespace for the MQTT Engine? When I add the All namespace for the topic subscription # it turns all my tags red, but the values do still update. If I remove the custom namespace the tags continue to update and are not red.

Author: mickgriddle
Content: That's a good question, but yeah I did the same, deleted the custom namespace and the tags are showing good quality now. Thanks for the heads up!

Author: mickgriddle
Content:
I think I'm starting to put together how this works.  So the MQTT Transmission module publishes via SparkplugB.  Since in the MQTT Engine, we're defining a Custom Namespace for all tags (using #), it uses that **instead** of the SparkplugB namespace that exists by default in Ignition causing stale (red) tags.  We'd normally create a Custom Namespace if the topics **aren't** using Sparkplug and define those topics in the Subscriptions field.  Since MQTT Transmission publishes using Sparkplug, we don't want to define a custom namespace for those tags.  I'm guessing the reason we're running into these issues when Walker didn't in the videos is because we're using more recent versions of Ignition and the MQTT modules than what Walker was in the videos. 

I could be pretty far off, but that is what I've been able to make out of it from reading Ignition's MQTT Engine documentation.  But I do want to play around with it a little more when I'm not supposed to be working and instead I'm thinking of this stuff. üòÅ

Author: Deleted User
Content: Check out the documentation within https://docs.chariot.io/display/CLD80/ME%3A+Configuration.  Within the Namespaces Custom section about 3/4 down in the page, it states, ‚ÄúWe recommend disabling the Sparkplug B default namespace if defining a custom namespace.‚Äù  Perhaps Ignition is having trouble parsing when a custom namespace is defined with Sparkplug B enabled.  The reason the data is not red when the custom namespace is removed is because the Transmission Module is publishing SparkplugB and the Engine can parse without an issue.  I may be wrong but this is what I am thinking.

Author: mickgriddle
Content:
Yep I saw that too!  What happened when I disabled SparkplugB and only used the Custom Namespace is I was unable to see the payload, similar to MQTT Explorer since it doesn't support SparkplugB.  Did you do the same and get a different result?

Oh nope, I reread, yep I'm with you there, I think it's causing issues when both the Custom Namespace and SparkplugB are both hitting the same Topic. Like The SparkplugB namespace is handling it properly but then the Custom Namespace tries and screws it up haha.

I was going to look at the logs within the gateway to see the exact error but haven‚Äôt had a chance today.  Normally, I try to follow the recommendations within the docs.  üòÇ

Author: mickgriddle
Content: What I ended up doing is creating  a custom namespace and adding MickWeiss/# under subscriptions. (MickWeiss is the topic in my personal MQTT Broker where my shellyplugs at home are sending payloads.)  Once that was done, tags from the DM Broker were still red so I stepped away.  Now coming back this morning, the SpB topics from the DM broker normal good quality, and I'm also able to see my personal shelly plugs tag in good quality while having both the SpB and Custom Namespaces enabled!

Author: Deleted User
Content: üëç awesome, that makes sense (subscribing to # wants to parse everything, subscribing to MickWeiss/# will not try to parse spBV1.0/# topics from the custom namespace).  Thank you for letting me know!!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Break it up.  Parsing those massive metric payloads will be fun.  Dumping an entire namespace of a site-level SCADA into a pub/sub framework designed for moving data from remote devices usually does not turn out well.  Unfortunately, there exists marketing material online that portrays this as viable without acknowledging the effort required to make it work.

Better yet, don't use SpB at all - especially if there are no consumers of it "north" of the site.  Ignition can be exposed as OPC UA subscriptions.  The easiest thing to do would be for HighByte connect to this and then model/govern the payloads and topics going to the MQTT broker.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
That's not what your diagram shows - you show OPC UA into Ignition.  If you have OPC UA drivers or devices, HB can obviously connect them directly.  If you're proposing "native" protocols then it could look like:

 PLC -> Native -> Ignition -> OPC-UA -> HighByte -> vanilla MQTT -> MQTT Broker

...or...

 PLC -> Native -> (Kepware, Softing, Software Toolbox, etc) -> HighByte -> vanilla MQTT -> MQTT Broker

Author: dsi_101
Content: Use a Gateway tag change script and use a wildcard ([default]RootFolderName/*) in the tags section to the folder you want to send data. So every data change in the tags below will run the publish script.In the script get your topic by using str(event.getTagPath().getParentPath()), Build your folder structure as you want for your topic, replacing the [default] in the tagPath, then use cirruslink.engine.publish(broker, topic, str(payload).encode(), 1, 0) to publish the vanilla payload.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: It depends

Author: zack.scriven
Content: thank you for sharing this code!

Author: zack.scriven
Content:
```
#publish flat MQTT to UNS in Ignition
tagPath = event.getTagPath()
parentPath = str(tagPath.getParentPath()).replace("[default]","")
itemName = tagPath.getItemName()

topic = "%s/%s" % (parentPath, itemName)

payload = event.getCurrentValue().value

system.cirruslink.transmission.publish("DM Broker", topic, str(payload).encode(), 0, 1)


```

Author: dsi_101
Content: For all Gateway Tag Change scripts it is best practice to use the initial change flag and tagQuality so you don't fire the script on saving the project or tags going to bad quality.  I also don't put code in the gateway tag event script and put all scripts in the project library. This way they can be exported one by one to be used in other projects. With gateway tag change - there is no way to export / import.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Question - trying to access the Ignition OPC-UA server from a 3rd party client (even from another Ignition server). I've checked every box I can think of - I've set the bind addresses, endpoint addressses, turned on "allow anonymous", allow no Security, opened the proper port in the firewall, and nada.   Anyone been thru this before?  Figured I might get a quick answer here.. if not, I'll head to Inductive's support..

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Self Reply -   gotta put the IP in the binding list in the FIRST position.  Needs to be like this: 0.0.0.0,localhost   Not like this:   localhost, 0.0.0.0

Author: .stibbits
Content: Yes. It is the one thing I always forget to do and I never write it down. I like to punish myself at times.

Author: dramon93
Content:
Can someone help me with SPB messages? I‚Äôm new to SPB topics and am testing the cMT-SVR-200 to publish data from the COM2 port.

Issues I'm Facing:
1. GroupID and NodeID in Ignition:

- When I use longer topics for GroupID (e.g., "Enterprise/Site/Area/Line") and NodeID ("Edge"), Ignition Engine doesn‚Äôt read the SPB messages.
- With single-word GroupID and NodeID, Ignition reads the messages, but it places NBirth, DBirth, and NDeath too high in the topic hierarchy. Is this expected behavior for an edge device?

2. Automatic Publishing of "Local HMI" Device:

- When GroupID is set to "Enterprise" and NodeID to "Site", Ignition can read and show the tags in the MQTT engine, but the device always publishes the "local hmi" topic, even if it‚Äôs empty, and it doesn‚Äôt publish the COM2 port tags.
- This results in the "local hmi" name appearing at the "Area" level in the SPB message when it should be an edge topic.

Questions:
Is there a way to resolve these issues, or am I misconfiguring the setup?
If I start adding devices this way, will it mess up the hierarchy in my UNS?

Any advice or solutions would be greatly appreciated.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
What are your hardware resources?

The namespace you see here is composed of parsed JSON, Vanilla, and OPC-UA. When I run an initial push that sends the entire namespace over the broker, I barely use 7% CPU and 5MB of memory. Ignition doesn't even raise an eyebrow because of it...

Author: andersgustav
Content:
Approximately 5000 of all the tags are from CMMS, fetched via REST API in Node-RED and pushed to a namespace that parses JSON (where the checkbox is checked). There is then a tag change script where they are published as flat MQTT in UNS (via system.cirruslink.engine.publish).

It is this push that triggers all the tags in the namespace I showed to be republished.

Author: aronsemle
Content: This is a bit o f a technical question, but is anyone using the node-red Ignition module? https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-ignition-nodes

Author: aronsemle
Content: I'm asking because we're working on a HighByte Ignition module that makes it easy to read/write UDTs from/to Ignition. On a tech level, the node-red module connects to Ignition over a websocket on the default Ignition ip/port. So if the gateway is setup with a certificate, auth, etc node-red uses that to authenticate. The positive is you only need to worry about one port in your firewall, the negative is you may need to make gateway level changes to secure your node-red connection (they are coupled).

Author: aronsemle
Content: The alternative tech approach is to host a completely separate server in the ignition module on it's own port with it's own auth/security settings, independent of the gateway. This seems easier/more flexible to me, but curious what folks think? I'm leaning this way

Author: donpancoe
Content:
Cross-posting my own question from the IA forums...

I am having data analysts run scripts built around `system.tag.queryTagHistory()` in order to get "wide" tables out of our Historian (Postgres), suitable for use within analytics tools like JMP.

I need to add more analysts to this group, but I don't like giving them all full Designer access just to have them use the Script Console. Is there a way to recreate this function as a Perspective app so they can use it in their browser? Failing that, could I do it in Vision? Or are there other ways to go about this that I am missing? Thank you.

Author: donpancoe
Content: Is there a way to access the Ignition Gateway domain from an external Python scripting environment? Meaning that I could use `system.tag.queryTagHistory()` in another Python environment to access the Historian data?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Would the power chart with an export to csv do?

Author: donpancoe
Content:
The shortcomings of exporting from the Power Chart are primarily: 1) Having to pick all the tags for export from a list is time-consuming for the user, and 2) I did not see a way to programmatically specify the time interval between rows.

With info I got from the IA forum, the solution will probably be to use check boxes, drop-down lists etc. for the user to configure the variables, then call `system.tag.queryTagHistory()`, hopefully getting a yay or nay indication that it worked or not.

I was also hoping to build a more generic-use Python script console though, since I so often use that for experimentation. ChatGPT and I could extract the script from a text area object and execute it using the Python `exec(script)` command, but getting the console output to appear in the Perspective window proved problematic. Many "can't write str to text stream" errors ensued.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I can think of a few ways to do this, but you'd need to be cautious not to indirectly introduce SQL injection or other risk.  But basically, use the WebDev module to expose a more dynamic query capability as a REST API, and call that externally from Python code, a Jupyter notebook, whatever.  With a little creativity you could provide tag browsing and a date picker as well, along with optional aggregates.  You could hide the complexity of query/script structuring behind that.

Author: donpancoe
Content: I'm now realizing that providing full scripting access could be just as dangerous as providing full Designer access, which is what I was trying to avoid with this exercise. This advice could still be useful for building better SQL-based applications though. Thank you.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You could also write a wrapper around the system.tag.queryTagHistory() function and expose it as a web API.  That's what I would do.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: @Don Pancoe If you have the webDevModule, this is what I‚Äôd do. Create a getMethod ¬´wrapper¬ª for tag.queryTag‚Ä¶
