Author: mrseanwallace
Content:
The correct IP address and credentials for the broker are in the description from below the relevant videos (2.5 & 2.6), and are different to what is contained in the video itself. 

If you have more than one server in a server set, they act as a redundant set of servers. 
From the Cirrus Link documentation: 'The Sets tab contains a list of server sets.  Each set represents a logical grouping of MQTT servers.  When a set is referenced by an Engine configuration, a single connection to one of the servers in the set will be maintained. The other servers will act as failover in the case that a connection with the first is lost'. 

Typically, the OOTB server 'Chariot SCADA' is in the 'Default' set. If you have not deleted/disabled the Chariot SCADA server, your custom one will act as a redundant failover to it. 

You have 2 options - delete/disable the Chariot SCADA server, or create a new Set, and assign your custom server to that.

Author: xamp4248
Content:
I have a question regarding the MQTT broker provided in the DM course. Does it support the persistent property to buffer data and forward it when the subscriber is online?

Currently, I am using two Ignition instances, one as a publisher and the other as a subscriber. I am sensing a few data points from one Ignition to another via our public MQTT broker, and I am monitoring the tags using the Easy Chart.

When I disable the MQTT transmitter in the publisher (the first Ignition), the values are stored and correctly updated in the subscriber side(2nd ignition instance) after the publisher connection is restored. However, when I disconnect the subscriber (the second Ignition server) and reconnect it after a few minutes, the buffered data does not appear on the subscriber side.

This indicates that while disabling the publisher works for storing data, disabling the subscriber does not retrieve the payload history. All of this data is using Sparkplug B (SpB) format.

Could you please provide insights into whether our MQTT broker supports this feature, and if there are any specific settings or configurations I should check to ensure that buffered data is received by the subscriber when it comes back online?

I could not see any QoS level or retain flag setting?

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
SpB relies on store and forward mechanism on the publisher, rather than the broker keeping a buffer of messages until the subscriber is online again. This is because SpB forces the use of QoS = 0. 

With QoS=2 and the clean session flag = false, in theory the broker should buffer the messages per MQTT spec. This is not the mechanism used by SpB. 

Instead, SpB uses the concept of primary host, and the publisher monitors the birth and death of a primary host (ie subscriber), and if the primary host disconnects from the broker, the publisher will start storing messages and will only send these when the primary host is back online.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: For Ignition, it means you have to setup a primary host in your broker set in Transmission module.

Author: xamp4248
Content: Thanks, Jon. I will check this out. However, I noticed that the Node-RED SpB node has an option to set QoS level 2.

Author: dobb_meister
Content: Thank you for pointing me in the right direction here. I found the details in the description

Author: xamp4248
Content:
Thanks, John. It‚Äôs working now‚ÄîI‚Äôve tested SpB from both Ignition and Node-RED, and everything is functioning as expected.

@Grey Dziuba , have you tried the FlatMQTT buffer storage with Ignition using the flow you shared earlier (Store and Forward with MQTT and SQLite)? I wasn't able to see the buffered values in Ignition. Any insights?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: If you set QoS=2 you‚Äôre technically not compliant with the SpB spec.

Content: i just started with ignition and was wondering was is the limitation of the platform? so lets say you have a broker, data ops, historian etc.. in the ignition and it works and as you scale why would you maybe use highbyte or maybe some other visualisation tool for an exemple? i mean it seems like you can use ignition for almost everything but there are probably some limitations in either functionality or performance or ignition has some kind of "roof" when it reached full potential?

Author: aronsemle
Content: Ignition performs great, and if you just have a single site it might be all you need. The real question is are you doing dataOps or SCADA? If you try and use Ignition to do both, that's where we see issues. Sites will make changes to SCADA that impact your dataOps. Separating the two functions leads to a more scalable solution across many sites. It's nuanced, but that's the core of it. Many of our customers have Ignition, and many started and backed away from using it for dataOps as their dataOps strategy matured.

Author: .stibbits
Content: To piggy back off of @aronsemle, there comes a point when pulling and pushing data into higher level systems from your model becomes more of a task within Ignition and using something like Highbyte helps immensely. Not saying it can be done in Ignition but, there are tools that speed up the process and can help demostrate value quicker!

Author: jpmac.s
Content:
Hi,
What approach are people using with connecting Ignition to Siemens S7-1200 controllers:
Ignition Drivers
OPC server on controller
Kepware drivers

Any performance upsides to any of the approaches?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Connecting with OPC UA subscriptions to Kepware's "S7 Plus" driver is probably the way to go.  This driver supports browsing, tag generation, transport security, and more granular control over reads/writes.  Ignition's Siemens driver does not have this.  When you factor in the tag browsing/import and transport security and the better performance, "S7 Plus" leaves the onboard OPC UA server with a lot to be desired.  If there were a consumer utilizing these, perhaps the onboard OPC UA methods or information modeling (with SiOME) might have some benefits.  These aren't relevant with Ignition as the consumer.

@Sam.E can probably chime in with more details and benefits.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Thanks for advice, im aware of the limitations of using the native driver. Im wondering if there are performance buy offs.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think those limitations are a pretty big deal.  Especially tag import.  They more than justify Kepware.

As for performance, with the more granular options on tuning the reads, I would imagine so.  I've generally observed Kepware used in deployments with higher tag counts, higher-speed reads, buffered structures, etc than Ignition.  Especially on the AB drivers.  It's also beat out other solutions for Fanuc CNC and Fanuc Robots.  I have not encountered S7-1200 applications with intense requirements for an apples to apples comparison.  I do know quite a few S7-1500 users have determined that everything else is second best to Kepware or the S7.NET+ library

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Completely agree on Kepware.its convincing the end user to buy another license is the only hurdle , so i want to have facts first.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
well said @js . background is that we spent a bunch of time and money to build a driver for Siemens' new proprietary PLC messaging standard. There aren't many companies that have done this. the benefits of the new protocol are as mentioned - symbolic tag names, auto tag generation from device, TLS for transport security. from a performance perspective, to be candid, it's not necessarily a FASTER protocol in every scenario than the old S7 register-based standard (the legacy protocol's large 960 byte data blocks really help with speed), but unless you have to move hundreds and hundreds of thousand element arrays at sub 100 ms intervals you probably won't notice much difference.

generally speaking, the BEST reason to use this new standard is: 1) tag generation from controller (so much time saved in register-to-tag mapping), and 2) because it allows a user to continue to use Optimized Blocks in the Siemens controllers. If you wnat to use Ignition with an S71200 or 1500 you must disable Optimized Block Access for the targeted Data Blocks, and other integrated PLCs or other Siemens systems may be relying on Optimized Block Access.

Author: sim_sam3
Content: or you could use UA, but embedded UA servers will not (yet, maybe ever) offer similar performance to either proprietary standard.

Author: jonathanswisher5228
Content:
this was key:

> If you use a gateway tag change event on a UDT, you should be able to get the entire struct in one json

I remember trying to set my tag change script to a folder, but that did not fire off when tags under it changes. If I use a UDT and set the tag change script path to this UDT whenever I change any tag under the UDT even several layers down I get a tag change event that includes the entire UDT structure. This was another key piece I was missing.

Now a problem I see is that if I use a wild card (*) to a location of UDTs, when a tag changes in a UDT the tag change script does not fire off for the UDT, but for the specific path under the UDT. This seems like it could become a pain to manage having to put each specific path to a UDT in the tag change script configuration. Any solutions out there to help with this problem?

Author: _dyland
Content:
I agree with some of this like the need for a more modern scripting engine. Maybe GraalPy is a good compromise?

A lot of ignition installs don‚Äôt use MQTT, so while I would like better integration to tags and UDTs ( Like a publish option in the tag editor, similar to how tag History is configured), I don‚Äôt want to have to pay for it in every license. Particularly when it wouldn‚Äôt even be used. 

On that same note, I use Ignition as an HMI, SCADA, MES, and/or IIoT platform. Depending on which scope I am using Ignition for, I need different functionality. The current Module based licensing approach makes this feasible. I don‚Äôt want to pay for all of the features of an IIoT platform when I am just programming an HMI. 

This is the same reason I don‚Äôt think that they are ready to converge Vision and Perspective into a single offering. I am going to get some heat for this, but I still think that Vision is better for HMIs and traditional SCADA applications. Modern SCADA, MES, and IIoT I prefer Perspective. Add to that that the dev environment for Perspective is nowhere near as polished as Vision ‚Äì they have a lot of work to do before they can kill Vision off. The inbuilt drawing tools are a good step, but they need to address a few bugs and UX issues too.

Their historian sucks, but rumor has it that is going to change in 8.3 so ill hold judgement until then but for now, QuestDB has PGWire support so it can use the Postgres ODBC and Ignition treats it like any SQL Database. 

The thing about Ignition is that a lot of people use it for a lot of different things. Currently they balance that fairly well. It‚Äôs not a perfect platform but it does each of its jobs better than most of the competition.

Author: _dyland
Content: I am working on a project right now where we convinced them to use Ignition in place of 7 PanelViews. We were over $10,000 cheaper in just Hardware and Licensing. I could not have convinced them on Perspective, especially if added IIoT functionality increased the base price. Its just Core, Vision, and Historain. We can add IIoT features in the future after we get a modern platform in the facility.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: To replace the panelviews - are you using a touchscreen with Ignition Edge on it so you don't have to worry about losing comms back to the main Gateway?

Author: _dyland
Content:
It depends - if it is just one HMI than yeah that's the way to go. If there are multiple, like 7, we have a full Ignition license with unlimited Vision and Historian. 3 0r 4 HMIs is where the price of Ignition becomes cheaper than the PanelViews (Depends on the specific part numbers). Limited Vision helps too if it is less than 5 HMIs.

When it is a full license, we keep the Gateway and Clients on the Controls network (and away from the internet) just like the HMIs would be. We try to keep the gateway in the PLC panel.

That way if the network goes down they can still run. If the controls network goes down the Remote IO racks and VFD Panels go with it so losing the gateway connection is the least of the worries.

Even with a remote HMI (Panelview) losing connection to the PLC is a possibility.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Gotcha. So you're colocating your gateways right out on the floor.  We haven't gone there yet - they're all datacenter VMs.  So far we've only needed Edge out on the floor in a couple places.

Content: Ive done it both ways. Pros and Cons to each. Just depends on the needs of a partictular situation.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It probably takes more engineering resources to offer a "historical tag provider" than a data store.  One needs the former whether the data store is something open source or a proprietary third party offering like Canary Labs.

I would imagine IA sells a fair amount of gateways with just the SQL Bridge, Perspective/Vision, and/or Alarms.  There are lot of use cases where there is a need to visualize current states or log transaction events.

In some industries, there is no SCADA or a traditional concept of it.  They don't really think of data in a time series way.  They think of data as discrete events or logs as well as aggregate calculations of those events. Their data structures tend resemble the backend of an MES or QMS more than that of a historian.  The data from their control systems will consist of mostly booleans as well as some counters and timers.  It's rare for their assets to have analog input cards and produce variable process data.  If there are decimals, it's like test or inspection data that is captured once per cycle.  If there are any sort of visualization above the machine layer, it will be an Andon or area/plant HMI(s) indicating states, counts, and time durations.  Most of the data gets logged into relational databases and/or MES systems.

Author: _dyland
Content:
From my impressions at ICC, I might be wrong as I'm writing this off of memory... 

A lot of the big changes are under the hood.

All of the configuration is now in JSON files, allowing for better git integration. It sounds like the SQLite database is going away completely. 

The configuration files so have full support for secret vaults (they mentioned hashicorp by name). The configuration also supports configurable deployment modes as well.

The redesigned Gateway UI hides the fact that it is built on a fully exposed API that is extensible and follows the open API standard.

The initial launch of the historian is built into the gateway, QuestDB is a great addition and being built in they reduce the latency. Presumably this will greatly increase the ingestion rate. But even that is a superficial feature of their new Historian API that they heavily implied would be open to other historians, event streams, and databases in the future. 

Event streams adds immediate support for Kafka. But again, this is just the first implementation of a new functionality. Lots more coming.

8.3 is a major overhaul of the backend, time will tell but talking to the developers and QA team at ICC this is a bigger release than 8.0 was. But it mostly reduces the technical debt and allows for agility and growth moving forward.

Another big one for people still using vision is that they are changing the client communication to match what perspective uses. I have to play with this but from what I can tell that means that clients will use webhooks to get values on exception rather than the existing poll response method. Allowing for a much better user experience in Vision.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
to quote @Dylan DuFresne "It Depends", and once people in the US log on , you'll get better Igntion advice

So just to check,
You want to 
 - Connect to Shop floor Devices.
- Connect to ERP - What is the ERP by the way?
 - Collect and Normalise that Data into the UNS
- Store the Data in your Historian
- Are you planning on using Ignition to do some calculations, present some reports and visualisation? or a different tool
- Is this for 1 site or multiple?

Just in case you have Kepware already on site, and existing SCADA and an existing Historian
Try to sign up to the historian from Flow, they might push you up the list if they know you are building something.

And then the Big one why are you doing that, what problem are you trying to solve? What is the POC?
If you know that it really helps focus and direct projects
Maybe take a step back and do a DTMA and write out the Strategy, It makes it a bit easier to decide the correct tool? 

What have you on site? any existing SCADA or Historian to leverage.?

but 40k? the Ultimate  package is 33k 

But as @Rutger Van Aelst says, build what you need on the Trial, and then you can know the cost better.

Author: _dyland
Content:
As @Mark O'Donovan said, it depends‚Ä¶ but that is one of the benefits of Ignition ‚Äì You don‚Äôt need to know everything out the gate. You can start with the modules that meet the functionality you need. Personally though, in the last 10 years I have never found one of the pre-priced packages to be the answer.

A common starting point for me is one of the visualization modules (Vision or Perspective) and the Tag Historian Module. From there you can get started with Connect Collect Store from the plant floor. Utilizing UDTs to organize the data into a consistent and normalized namespace for use with the Historian and External Data.

From there, if we are talking ERP integration ‚Äì the Web Development Module is a great addition that allows you to create REST endpoints in Ignition that external systems to access.

The Cirrus Link modules come in when you need MQTT. So if that is part of the strategy, you will want those early.

I stopped using the SQL Bridge Module years ago. It caused more problems than it solved in my experience. Not because it had any bugs or anything, but it made it too easy for people who don‚Äôt know what they were doing to overload a database or device. I do all my SQL interaction with Tags, Named Queries, and Python scripts.

I have used the Reporting module extensively as a large customer required PDF Reports. While I liked it better than Crystal Reports, I really fail to see any value in PDF reports these days. So‚Ä¶ I try to avoid this one.

If you are starting at a site level, with a data oriented use case ‚Äì I would start with this and add things as needed. Unless it is easier to get the budget for the whole thing‚Ä¶ Than you will want to evaluate the other modules further‚Ä¶. As stated above ‚Äì It Depends.

Author: _dyland
Content: --- And I still use Vision for HMI / SCADA while I use Perspective for SCADA / MES / IIoT.

Author: _dyland
Content: If you are going headless, I would drop the SQL Bridge and add the Web Dev Module.

Author: trentc
Content:
When you say "expose the historian" are we talking about if we have the historian to an SQL DB? why not query the DB direct by other applications?
Or are we talking about an internal historian that isn't to an external SQL db?

Author: _dyland
Content:
Nothing is technically stopping you from just querying the database.

But there are a lot of reasons not to.

Security being the first... In some cases, it might be easier or better to secure Ignition than to expose the database directly.

Prebuilt functionality to handle the partitioning and aggregate queries. This functionality is not trivial and Ignition doesn't provide any documentation as far as I know - I have seen some people on the forums that reverse engineered it but it would be a pretty large effort.

Some applications wont support direct SQL integration - A Rest API will probably be more broadly supported.

Author: _dyland
Content: Really it would be a combination of some KPIs or metrics calculated from the Historian published over MQTT and the raw data being exposed over the REST API.

Author: trentc
Content: Gotcha, thanks. Those are all good reasons and justification for MQTT + RESTAPI

Author: _dyland
Content: Depending on how you handle Metadata - Having the Tag path and Details about the Gateway that produced the metric would allow the application to know what to query for the historical data too.

Author: thooor9411
Content: Has anybody tested Factory Talk Optix and compared it to Ignition? what are your thoughts?

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
If you need flexibility, multi-platform support, and customization, Ignition is the better fit. If you're already deep in the Rockwell ecosystem and want a, Rockwell-backed solution, then FactoryTalk Optix may be worth a look, but Rockwell products tends to lead to vendor lock-in, as it‚Äôs heavily integrated within the Rockwell ecosystem. This limits flexibility and can bind users to Rockwell products for optimal functionality.

Ignition is built as an open platform designed to solve problems across various hardware and software systems without forcing it's users into proprietary dependencies. Ignition‚Äôs architecture enables easier integration with other systems, allows more control and choice. 

Also, Ignition gives you a free, repeatable 3-hour trial. FactoryTalk Optix offers a free version and a 90-day Pro trial but requires you to set up an account and organization through Rockwell‚Äôs FactoryTalk Hub.

If trying before committing is key, Ignition offers a more straightforward, continuous trial experience, so you can build full solutions before you buy.

Content:
This is just me
And I have not modified a SCADA since 2021
Or built one since 2018

soü§è üßÇ 

MQTT is my Preferred way to communicate from L2 to L2, L2 to L3 ,L3to L3 and just about to comms to L4 but that is really an API to MQTT Gateway 

OPCUA is a perfectly acceptable way for L2 to L2 comms, but to me a bit inferior to L3 to L2 but I can leverage it if I need to. 

L2 to L1 Tbh it's normally the native driver

I hate messing around with API's, a couple are ok

Content:
Curious to hear your opinion on these as well!

For me personally, very short:

AVEVA System Platform I've worked with a lot until version 2017, through multiple m&a, still think it's a great system
+: objects having unique identifiers so a change in name or hierarchy doesn't break everything, more out of the box / addon functionality and widgets
-: windows only, more complex to set up and manage, AVEVA fans always shouting it's so much more powerful than Ignition without backing it up, and comparing Ignition with InTouch standalone which is bs imo, no public available pricing info

WinCC OA don't have any experience with (so purely from what I see online and talking to people, went through some docs but long ago)
+: .NET, supposedly can handle anything, large scale installs
-: m&a (very separate island within Siemens still from what I understand), steep learning curve (or so I'm told), pricing (or so I'm told)

Frameworx don't have any experience with (so purely from what I see online)
+: .NET, multiple scripting languages, transparent pricing, unlimited licensing model, sounds great at least on paper
-: looks dated, don't know of any installs myself, seems like a smaller install base

For now, Ignition stays on top for me.
Happy to be schooled in why others are better!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Neither is really all that scalable. They‚Äôre both monoliths.

Author: _dyland
Content: Could you Elaborate?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Neither was designed for scale in the context of how you‚Äôd scale a cloud based architecture. You use either a ‚Äúbigger box‚Äù or you consciously divide the big app into smaller segments. 

That said, to your original point most SCADA systems have more consideration for distributed execution.  At the same time, the dividing line between HMI and SCADA has blurred.  When I think HMI these days I think more of a dedicated panel on a machine.  By that definition, many things like Optix are just as ‚ÄúSCADA-ish‚Äù. 

Out of curiosity, are you seeing many deployments of headless SCADA out there these days?  Seems like that‚Äôs an increasingly common approach vs even a few years ago.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I like the fact that we have lots of options! Looking forward the taking the new Tatsoft stuff for a spin as well.  Ignition/IA‚Äôs growth has put everyone else on notice - you can‚Äôt just rely on your brand loyalty and you gotta step up your game!

Author: _dyland
Content:
Yeah - I will add that neither was built for cloud deployment. Ignition is always going to be limited by Java, even if it is running on K8s or something... 

I still see SCADA as an on prem part of the stack though so if we are talking about scaling SCADA platforms than I had assumed that the "Bigger Box" or "More Boxes" was the methodology.

HMIs that are ‚ÄúSCADA-ish‚Äù are actually something that I am really excited about and that is where I would classify FT Optix. So if we are comparing I would put it next to Tatsoft Edge HMI or Ignition Edge Panel.

I am not seeing any headless SCADA in my real world circles but I am hearing about Headless MES and IIOT Platforms. But the lines between these HMI, SCADA, MES, and IIoT are getting pretty blurry.... so it really depends on how you define them.

This is even leading to architectures where one might use Tatsoft Edge HMI or FT Optix on the plant floor and Ignition as part of the MES stack or as an IIoT platform.

Part of the issue in talking about Ignition is that there are people that use it in very different ways - Just on this Discord there are people that would call it an HMI, a SCADA, an MES, or an IIoT Platform.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Lots of options are what I am excited about - this is less about brand loyalty and more about not trusting Rockwell due to past experience.
Also, comparing an HMI to a SCADA platform feels kinda silly.

I just had lunch with some Siemens Guys this last week looking into their options. When I get time after this next startup I am excited to try out System Platform and FrameworX too.

Compitition is a good thing.

Author: _dyland
Content: I am sure that in the end each of these platforms will have their pros and cons - depending on the specific needs I am sure that there will not be a single best option for everyone.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yup. Agree with all of the above.

Author: jose_83775
Content: Somebody already used tensorflow or sklean inside the ignition? I know that according with the Ignition's documentation is not possible, but what if?

Author: _dyland
Content: Ignition uses Jython. tensorflow is built for CPython. Very Different implementations of Python.

Author: jose_83775
Content: but, there isn't any similar package as sklearn, numpy or pandas for jython?

Author: _dyland
Content:
Not that I know of. Jython is largely obsolete, the Python ML libraries I know of use C or C++  which means no jython compatibility. 

In theory you could use a Java one though that may require you to build a custom module...

Also, I would seriously question using it within Ignition. I wouldn't want to lock up the JVM of a production environment due to some ML algorithm. 

Why not decouple it as a different service?

Author: _dyland
Content: The JVM bottleneck and Jython limitations are the main two pain points with Ignition in my opinion

Author: rickbullotta
Content: This üëÜüèº - decouple it for myriad reasons.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Can an Ignition reference tag reference a UDT?

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Haven‚Äôt tried referencing an entire UDT. Just tags inside other UDTs

Author: _dyland
Content:
I never thought to try but since I already had Ignition open I was curious to see what would happen... Here is what I found in my 5 minute test.

A Reference Tag of type "Integer" throws a "Type Conversion Error" when pointed at a UDT.

a Type of "String" results in a JSON string with key value pairs of tag names and values.

a Type of "Dataset" results in a dataset with a single row and column with the JSON string in "value[0,0]"

a Type of "Document" results in a nice JSON object of key value pairs.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Interesting. Can you select the UDT type as the reference tag type?

Author: _dyland
Content: No, just the basic built in types.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Feature request!

Author: ted.garrison
Content: At first last night, I was thinking - why would you want to ref a UDT.. but this morning, I'm like - well, that would be an easy way to make the same data show up in multiple namespaces, without having to maintain 2 different structures if you add a tag to the main UDT, it would just showup in the other...  I do like that idea.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: You can make your own custom property for that if you so please. In this case the reference tags is a document data type.

Content: Hey folks, its my first time using ignition and Id love some advice. I have created 4 simulated devices that are sending measurements as tags, and now I need to visualize them in time series. Im getting something wrong here right?

Content:
From what I have seen on the forums it looks like most users are use REST calls. There is a third-party module available by Kymera for InfluxDB History Module, I've never used it myself, but you may be able to get a demo from them.

https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/kymera-systems-influxdb-history-module/25773

Author: darkthedude
Content: I usually use SQL databases either MSSQL, or Postgres to store data. Ignition has the historian which can be tied to the database to store tag history its very customizable. I've also seen Canary used as a historian I believe they have a free module, but I think canary is a paid product itself.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Lots of ways to store tag history.

The built in option is Ignition Historian, If you want the timeseries optimization there are posts on the Ignition Forum detailing how to get it working with Timescale.

Other Options are the InfluxDB API, MQTT To Telegraf, Canary, or as mentioned above the Kymera  Module. 

You can use QuestDB as a Database Connection using the PGWire support or Telegraf.

Telegraf has an OPC-UA input plugin too.

Another options is to use the MongoDB Module and some scripting to capture tag change events.

You could use a SQL Database with the SQL Bridge or custom scripts.

Sparkplug-B to Snowflake if you are looking for a cloud option.

Or even more traditional Historians too, Ignition's OPC-UA Server could be used to connect to a lot of more traditional options.

Coming soon is is Ignitions Power Historian (QuestDB) in 8.3 as well as FLow Software's TimeBase Historian.

--- Just to name a few options

Author: stickyburn
Content: Thanks for the info both!

Author: _dyland
Content: For the record, I woud start with the built in historian, especially if you are just getting started. If you want to get fancy try it out with Timescale.

Content: https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/tutorials/ignition-historian-guide

Author: hobbes1069
Content: One thing I really like about Timescale is that it's built on top of Postgres, which is very mature, but also allows me to keep regular transaction or informational tables in the same database and do table joins to provide context in reports or materialized views.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Yeah - I am on Postgres as the default short of a specific client request.

I really like Timescale for the Ignition Historian because it allows me to use the Ignition Historian and all of the functionality that comes with it. Ignition doesn't know the difference between it and any other SQL database.

As a raw Timeseries, I am really liking QuestDB.

As a Historian, I am eager for the  TimeBase Beta.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Haven't had a chance to dig into QuestDB yet. I did attend a webinar or two for CockroachDB, which looks interesting.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Trying to setup Timescale in a container for use with Ignition in a container at home.. getting a weird error.. gonna have to start over.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: does the default Postgresql driver in Ignition work with Timescale?

Author: _dyland
Content: Timescale is just an extension for PostgreSQL that enables time-series workloads, its still postgres.

Author: _dyland
Content: So yes, you just set it up like any other postgres database in Ignition.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Thats also why I like QuestDB - It has built in PGWire support, Ignition thinks its Postgres when I set up the connection.

It also supports InfluxDB's Line Protocol which makes it compatable with a lot of existing tooling.

Author: _dyland
Content:
But for Timescale with Ignition the power is in the fact that Ignition still makes it's own tables through the Historian Module - You just go back and make it a Hypertable.

https://github.com/aRaymo/Using-TimeScaleDB-with-Ignition/blob/main/README.md

Author: _dyland
Content:
Gotta give @Zack Scriven credit here, he started the forum post that details this.

https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/timeseries-db-for-postgresql/21770/15

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Make sure you use the correct container. The default only has the basic TS function. The "HA" version includes the full toobox but is also a much larger download (Full Ubuntu). Also, the two versions store data in different places. The documentation is now updated after I brought it to their attention when I lost all my data.

Author: markwes.11
Content:
Yes we have. Around 35% more expensive to go with SaaS vs. self-hosting for us.
One big advantage of self-hosting is sustained usage or negotiated discounts with AWS. Depending on your commitment with AWS, you can get servers for up to 50% off the list price.  
Second, please check your failover or redundancy requirements. Our plant teams got VMware infra, and failovers were easy. Best practices for cloud (as per cloud-certified engineers) require DBs and servers across zones. Essentially this makes Ignition quite expensive to host compared to on-premise.

Author: _dyland
Content: There are some best practices that can be followed in the PLC code itself as well as some creativity in the tag groups. I would dive deep into the memory allocation and network protocol of you given PLC. The best I have managed is 40,000 - 50,000 tags ranging from 250ms to 60 seconds using a modern logix processor. Most of my projects end up in the 20,000 - 40,000 tag range (more of you count memory and expression tags). A lot of that is not necessarily due to "collecting" everything but because I bring back all configuration, calibration, and scaling data so that it can be set from the HMI/SCADA. No excuses for a service call to change a timer....

Author: _dyland
Content: The Ignition Forums go really deep into this so I would start there

Author: willemrs
Content:
I think I may be going in circles here, so I'm looking for feedback on the best approach‚Äîor insights from anyone who has tackled something similar. I'm using the Cirrus Link MQTT modules to host an on-site Unified Namespace (UNS) within Ignition. Since we started building out the UNS, I've been publishing the namespace via Sparkplug B (SPB) and flattening it using the Node.js script Rick Bullotta linked here, with a few modifications. This setup has allowed other applications to access raw PLC data from Ignition alongside everything else.  
Now, we want to start publishing work orders into a specific topic with another application directly into the namespace under "ent/site/area/workorders," which would appear under our MQTT engine provider and be brought into our UNS tag provider through a script. However, this approach creates a loop: Ignition republishes the UNS data into the same topic it‚Äôs reading to create tags.
One solution might be to separate the transmitters and skip transmitting in certain areas, but I'm unsure if that's the best approach. Any guidance or alternative strategies would be greatly appreciated.  We have published into a separate topic outside of the ‚Äùent/‚Äù topic structure for some other sensors that worked but seems like an extra step in the long run to just duplicate all the items we want in the UNS just so Ignition can read them.

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
I would give your VM a larger disk size to run on. Looks like Ignition is almost maxing out its available space (94% utilization).

And if you‚Äôre still having issues getting the gateway to start up, you can find logs (sometimes called ‚Äúwrapper‚Äù logs) in the installation directory. Under the hood, Ignition is just a Java process running an Apache server. There‚Äôs a lot going on, but it all happens within the context of the JVM, which starts (is started by?) a ‚Äúwrapper‚Äù which logs things that happens during that Java process‚Äôs execution.

If you turn on one of the several debugging options in your `ignition.conf` file, you can see those logs in the Windows Event Viewer as well.

I hope this helps! Happy Thanksgiving everyone! ü¶É

Author: andreasvogler
Content: Interesting! How does the load balancing work? On AWS I found "An Application Load Balancer supports load balancing of applications using HTTP and HTTPS" ... but isn't a Ignition Gateway Network plain TCP? Also Tags are not automatically distributed over the nodes of this "Cluster" - right? This is not cluster technology. Or is it? Is the data from the On-Premises Ignition servers replicated to the cloud? If yes, is it one-way? or bi-directional? to which backend? 1 or 2? and if we add a 3d node?

Author: vikanchira
Content:
For backend, the load balancer will only distribute to the primary server and fall back to the redundency. They aren't horizontal scaling. Alternative is to connect some sites to one backend and other sites to the other. The backend license cost will be double, not +50%.

For front-end, when using a load balancer, it is important to turn on ‚Äústicky‚Äù sessions to ensure the connection stays consistent for at least one hour. The Front-End Gateway has to be completely stateless. It gets its data from the Back-End Gateways using the gateway network and the SQL database service.

Manual for setting the scaled-out architecture are here:
https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/tutorials/tutorials-and-helpful-tricks/scale-out-architecture-guide

https://inductiveautomation.com/resources/article/ignition-server-sizing-and-architecture-guide

https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/system-architectures/scale-out-architecture

Author: andreasvogler
Content: Thanks for sharing the documents. I understand now the Ignition Scale-Out part here - it is splitting one Ignition to FE & BE Servers. I still would say that this is not a cluster ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Author: vikanchira
Content: The front end is kind of a cluster.

Author: rma002
Content:
Unfortunately, you‚Äôll likely need to conduct a hands-on proof of concept (PoC) with various platforms to truly understand their capabilities. In my experience, many Ignition-focused integrators have limited knowledge when it comes to integrating Azure IoT services. This often leads to inefficiencies, as you must ‚Äúspoon-feed‚Äù them every requirement, ultimately wasting both time and resources. Instead of relying solely on presentations and demonstration videos‚Äîwhich may not sufficiently convince senior management‚ÄîI recommend moving straight to a PoC.

It‚Äôs worth noting that some ‚Äúdigitally transformed‚Äù integrators may immediately propose deploying solutions like HiveMQ or other costly brokers. These options may not fit your infrastructure, strategy, or budget. In many cases, a simpler, more cost-effective broker like Mosquitto would suffice. However, these integrators often remain fixated on a limited IIoT technology stack‚Äîcommonly including Ignition, HiveMQ, HighByte, or Canary‚Äîand rarely consider more flexible alternatives.

Moreover, the heavy reliance on expensive tools makes it difficult to justify their adoption in European plants, which often lag behind the U.S. market in terms of digital maturity. Ultimately, it‚Äôs best to be prepared for these challenges and to start with a PoC that validates your chosen approach before committing to any high-cost solutions.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I've had similar observations of integrators. Their business models are to deploy what they know with very repeatable service patterns. It does not necessarily factor in eventual "co-management" of the solutions with end users as well as their autonomy to extend, ideate, and build further solutions. Also, the business model for many integrators is to sell hours for projects rather than outcomes or technology strategy.

I think a really important thing that end users overlook from the "choose which solutions" or  "how do I convince/justify..." scenarios is having clear use cases and business outcomes defined. Yeah, it's technology and there is a desire to not single thread an architecture to a single use case. But, by POC'ing through a use case, it infuses the org's unique technology/data/people culture into the evaluation criteria. That knowledge is impossible to gain through architecture diagrams and product demos. It provides a better picture of what is required to deploy, maintain, up-skill, and scale.

Long story short. Step one is not to buy software or get caught up on justification. The focus should be on finding a strategy rather than choosing a technology stack. Wholly outsourcing strategy does not usually lead to great outcomes. Get your hands dirty with evaluations. Allocating resources, especially time, to evaluate is probably more important than anything. 

Could you dive deeper into limited IIoT technology portion? What, in your mind, is less limited stack and flexible alternatives? How are you typically approaching this?

Author: blabladudelioe
Content:
My question would be, what do you want to achieve with Ignition? I love the tool, but I am not sure if I would use it as my "IIot Platform". If your main goal is to build applications for use on the shopf floor or close to it, Ignition is the straight forward choice. If you want to build a Smart Factory (I4.0) infrastructure (this is my understanding of an IIoT Platform), it probably makes sense to consider other tools as well. My next questions would be:
- What use cases do you have in mind?
- How to you want to handle machine conectivety?
- Where do you make data transformation to get a necessary degree of normalization?
- How should data be stored beside relational databases: Historian, Timeseries Database? 
- Where should additional logic live, e.g. for KPI calculation? Do you want to develop everything in Python2 in Ignition or do want to have separate services, that could live on even when you decide to kick Ignition out at some point?
It does not necessarily have to be either Ignition or the Azure IoT Product pallet. Pick the parts that suit your needs.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
While I don't disagree with any of your points, also be careful for analysis paralysis and overcomplicating things from the start. Time = money.

If there's a reasonably priced platform that can handle the bulk of it, that's also popular and with great educational resources so people can get trained and onboarded quickly, why not just start there.

Yes maybe it's not the absolute perfect system for every use case you have, but nothing is stopping you from splitting off or even completely replacing later on.

Author: blabladudelioe
Content: I think what you describe is the typical hands-on, lets do it approach, which a lot of people who worked on the shop floor have. And it sure gets shit done. But if you are not in the position to press the buy button, but rather need to convince people in management or from your IT department, you need to show them that you consider other factors, like how your tool integrates with other stuff in the company. It seems like @Andrew Camm needs to show management why Ignition is a better fit than Azure IoT. The questions above are a starting point to make this decision more transparent.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
A few things here:
- Cost Transparency - Simple, predictable pricing with modular licensing - no surprise fees or complex pricing tiers like ThingWorx. Sales quote based on approval
- Open Architecture - Native support for 150+ industrial protocols and standards. OPC-UA, MQTT, REST API. ThingWork has 3 main methods which are Kepware, MQTT extra*, RestAPI
- With Ignition you can try 100% and see all the documentation. WIth ThingWorx, you will only see powerpoint slides and their own demo. Good luck seeing public user documentation and developer's documentation.
- I am not sure if your use case needs it but Ignition's Enterprise Administration Module that help to manage the fleet is cruital for a lot of the applications. ThingWorx doesn't have something like that.
These are my opinions, I might be wrong. Feel free to correct me if I am. For me ThingWorx is something you hear of but don't really get to try. Ignition is something I can use to manage my Fish tank at home using 99% of their platform (maker edition).

Content: Why isn't Ignition as popular in Europe?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
There are a lot of Ignition Users in Europe, but lets say why is Ignition less popular in Europe than in the US

A few likely explanations
is it is a US software, so it grew organically int he US first and is spreading out, so it is just not as far along its curve as it is in the US

So for the first few years they might not have been looking at Europe let alone having sales people speaking, French German, Polish , let alone ones the can understand many Irish accents.

there was also possible a bit more of a crowded market, I don't have figures but Wonderware, and Rockwell had a much larger share of the SCADA Market in the US, than in Europe. Siemens and Schneider probably adding a bit to that.

But I really suspect, ,from talking to US integrators , they felt ripped off and put over a barrel by Wonderware and their distributors in particular in a way I don't see speaking to European Integrators. I had a great relationship with my Aveva reseller, they really act like a partner in solving problems, both for customers when I was an Integrator and more so when working for an admittedly massive end user.

And Rockwell attitude to end-users is anecdotally worse.

Author: r.pop
Content:
Building off what Mark said, I think Ignition is growing quite rapidly from what we are seeing. Being a Italian headquartered company, we are seeing tremendous demand for Ignition projects in EMEA. 

There's now a couple of European distributors as well as several integrators.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: We‚Äôre also seeing a lot of growth. Just two years ago, there was maybe 2-3 Ignition integrators in Norway, there are now 23, and for the early adopters the business is boomin!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I guess it depends on where and what industries in Europe. I have observed Ignition present at major automotive, pharma, pulp & paper, utilities, and packaging operations. I would consider is relatively popular. What the motivates the question? 

As to why it's less popular than in the US, here are some thoughts...

In large markets like Germany and France, there is a tendency to buy and/or transact locally. Having local producers certainly has an impact. Familiarity and localization is a bigger factor in some markets than others. In Germany, international television and film have dubbed audio translations. In Sweden, there are retirees that grew up watching American television.

In smaller markets, the buyers are more pragmatic. The Nordics, in particular, appear more comfortable adopting new or lesser-known solutions. They have significant industrial bases with a lot of automation and problems to solve. Ignition seems popular there. Other markets, particularly Eastern Europe, seem to be more conservative and follow the mainstream. This might be due to the lower cost structure and number of foreign-owned operations there. For risk-adverse multi-nationals seeking to deploy globally, it's historically been easier tap into the reach of Siemens. I'm sure "no one ever got fired for buying Siemens" has been uttered in many languages.

The make up of utilities and OT system integrators between the US and Europe is probably another factor. In the US, for example, there are tens of thousands of municipal water utilities. There is a whole cottage industry of small SIs that support them. In Europe, a lot of the utilities are national or regional systems, often privately operated. SCADA and industrial automation, in general, tend to be very risk adverse purchases and projects. The larger the projects, the more complexity and risk to manage. As a result, there have probably been more opportunities for integrators to "take a chance" on Ignition in the US than in Europe.

Author: vikanchira
Content: Ignition is also relatively unknown in South East Asia. Reason being most manufacturers here are discrete manufacturers and end users who are mostly at the Industrial 3.0 level. Just automated the production but didn't care about interconnected data. The machine makers and the hardware companies are the one that are know and own the distribution and software support. You end up seeing more of the software that are tie to the hardware like Siemens, Schneider, Mitsubishi, etc.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Its because both servers are setup in the same server set, so it treats Hive as a redundancy failover. Make a separate server set for each of them. The transmitters need to be assigned to a server set as well.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Were you looking for OPC UA A&C support client-side or server-side?

We have a number users with more contemporary PLC or DCS solutions with native alarm instruction sets. Much of that gets exposed over the OPC UA server interface as A&C. As a result, our OPC UA client can read this and any structured data within. This is the only area where I've seen A&C adoption. Are you looking to just read the alarm events buried in a PLC or are you looking at doing management and acknowledgments from Ignition?

I do think it's interesting, though, for Ignition to function as an A&C server. It has a great alarm module. It would be nice to consume SCADA alarms in a more structured way like we're starting to see with some newer control systems. It seems like a lot of the SIs resort to workarounds of improvising their own alarming within tag providers or creating queries to the alarm journal.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Client side..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Just collecting them..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôve got the Acks handled. That‚Äôs just a method call.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Ignitions OPC UA support is very limited.. server is just tags, zero metadata.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Frankly seems almost to be lip service

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It could be that it's such an extreme minority of the installation base is using A&C. It also doesn't help that A&C and structured data types are kind of a pain to implement. Large-ish effort for low reward. They could probably add another native driver or add subscription support for AB's native alarm objects (e.g., ALMD, ALMA) and it would probably exceed the number of users that would adopt A&C. It seems like for every ten S7 in the field that supports A&C, there's less than one with a program making use of it use of it. It feels like there's a lot of legacy programs running on contemporary hardware.

What are your A&C nodes? S7-1200/1500? Did you have to put in effort (e.g., updating firmware, updating programs) to make this happen or have you been receiving machines from machine builders this way in recent years?

Author: 8elahr
Content:
I had a few problems this morning trying to get ignition edge running on a Edge Gateway.
My setup is Docker compose as template in Portainer.

I was about to ask for help here, but had success, just right before I was about to hit the send button.
So I edited the post to share it in case any one of you is trying the same.


services:
  gateway:
    image: inductiveautomation/ignition:latest
    ports:
      - 9088:8088
      - 9043:8043
    network_mode: host
    volumes:
      - gw-data:/usr/local/bin/ignition/data
    # env_file: ignition.env  # optionally specify variables in a file, or using `environment:` below
    environment:
      - ACCEPT_IGNITION_EULA=Y
      - GATEWAY_ADMIN_USERNAME=admin
      - GATEWAY_ADMIN_PASSWORD=Password
      - IGNITION_EDITION=edge
      - TZ=Europe/Berlin  # see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones#List

    command: >
      -n docker-test
      -m 1024
      --
      wrapper.java.initmemory=512
      -Dignition.allowunsignedmodules=true
volumes:
  gw-data:

Author: sp00k4228
Content:
My take:

**1.** I'd say so, yes. As long as you get a good understanding of the core components. You'll need at least a foundational understanding of all the topics (tag groups, tag history, tags, udts, transaction groups, databases and basic scripting to name some). The more "hands on" experience you get, the easier it will be to solidify the different concepts (which can sometimes seem abstract, depending on your experience) into actual knowledge.

**2.** Not that i know of. As long as you have an idea of the core concepts you need to learn, you could look online for demo projects, use AI to generate some mock up tests / project ideas for you, etc. *Ignition Exchange* also has a lot of resources.

Author: dsi_101
Content:
Doing some work for an OEM where they have remote sites and we are pushing data via MQTT to allow analytics to be performed outside of the edge.  The totalizers onsite are odometer style, typically 15 or so. Using these totalizers we do numerous calculations and display on dashboards in the cloud for their people and also have plans to "sell" the data to their customers.  If the customers don't buy the subscription they still want the data to help learn about their process. 

Currently in the cloud, Canary subscribes to the data to store it via the MQTT.  Only issues with this  have been if the some totalizers might not change very often and since there is no data change there is no data in the historian to say get last hour of data. Which isn't a big deal just had to work with that exception in the code.

We then use Ignition and the canary provider module to connect and request the start and end data to get hourly, last24hr, today, yesterday, last 30days totals. To then run scripts to perform the calcs for the KPIs.

So here is the question. 

The specific calculations that are performed on each totalizer  are currently  being done in functions in Ignition and are running every 5 minutes to update.  With only two sites there is definite slow down with the calcs not the gui.  I tested just duplicating the sites calcs to 10 and the gateway was having a hard time. I am using async calls but just doesn't seem Ignition is up to the task. Considering finding a replacement for the calculations to send the data back to the Broker for perspective to still show the dashboards.  Going down the route for a POC where I converted the python code already in Ignition to a Python 3 and running on its own next to canary using the API directly,  but not seeing much improvement at the moment, but still early in development testing. 

Really just looking to see what software could be used that could handle up to 50 sites as this company grows.

Author: patanj2
Content: Why not do these as Canary calculated tags?  And just read results from Canary?

Author: dsi_101
Content: Thought about that but would be to hard to maintain, just don't see the scalability.  Having to deal with all the calculations.   Plus having to historize the results and pay for bigger historian size

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @DSI_101, you just advanced to level 4!

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
8.3 beta is now expected early Q2, and release is just 2025 now.. will 8.3 be the version that never came.. in the meantime 8.1 has been in maintain-mode since September..

They aimed high, perhaps too high with 8.3.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: And Python 3-support is nowhere near..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôm curious what‚Äôs the main holdup. The power historian, the drawing tool, the gateway api, refactoring everything to file-based.. ?

Author: _dyland
Content:
8.2 is already the version that never came... In my opinion, 8.3 is coming at a Major point of growth for IA as a company - a growth point that is rarely easy to navigate. 

At the same time 8.3 is probably the biggest release they have ever done. Both In refactoring the backend as well as new features. 

The last biggest release was 8.0 and honestly that one didn't go over too well, it introduced a lot of bugs and after 1 one project I stopped using Perspective all together until 8.1 when most of the bugs were ironed out. 

8.0 also introduced a breakpoint in the upgrade process, which meant that older versions had to go through a multi step upgrade process to get there. 

My best guess is that these two things along with the memory of the painful (but exciting) launch of 8.0 is making them cautious of releasing too early. 

And to be fair, I would rather have it delayed another 6 months than be broken on release.

Author: _dyland
Content: Also, Jython is the scripting language, while it's outdated it's seriously not a big deal ... If you want a full IDE you shouldn't be writing the code inside of Ignition anyways.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Depends if you want to leverage Py3 libraries though, doesn‚Äôt it?

Author: _dyland
Content:
Sure, but as someone who has personally pushed Ignition to its limits and made a hobby of weird integrations with Ignition I have only run into one use case that was relevant to production where I needed a python3 library and had a case to run the code inside of Ignition. 

Usually, when I am getting to that point I really need to reflect and ask myself why this isn't running as a separate service. If I need those libraries there are probably other reasons to spin up a FastAPI server or Flask or something. 

The exception was the lxml library, because Rockwell's L5X stores logic in the comments of the XML... All of the compatible libraries ignored the comments.

Author: _dyland
Content: And don't forget, Jython has access to Java libraries as well there have been a couple times where they python one way python 3 but a Java library had what I needed.

Author: _dyland
Content: I don't mean to defend it and say that they shouldn't update it but they have already announced that they are looking into allowing more languages for scripting, they are even exploring an API that lets people extend the scripting languages themselves.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I'm just saying that it's not nearly as big a deal in practice as it sounds on paper. 

I would also assume that's part of why it hasn't been "fixed" yet.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Another example of wanting a python3 library was when I was doing an incredibly stupid test and wanted to use Tensorflow or any library that had basic search algorithms... I ended up writing a few algorithms from scratch and everything was fine. 

That was for a Maze Maker and Solver game but is not code I would ever want to execute in ignition in any real environment.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It‚Äôs all of the AI, ML and data science libraries I‚Äôm thinking of.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Agreed, that's the gray area. It's also muddied by Ignition being a lot of things to a lot of people. 

In the Context of SCADA, I wouldn't want to risk the algorithm spinning the VM out and affecting production. 

IIoT is a bit different, specifically if it's just monitoring. That said, if Ignition is being used for the device drivers I wouldn't want to risk the connection. If Ignition is just hooked up to Kepware, then it's possibly a different story. 

As with everything, it's all in the details. I would love the addition but IA has smart people there, if it's not added yet I would believe that the quantity of people asking for it hasn't reached a mass that offsets the resources to implement. 

I would love to see some research but I would still bet that most people are still using Ignition Primarily as a SCADA, followed by simple MES applications, followed by light IIoT. 

(I specifically said most people, not most installs on purpose)

Author: patanj2
Content: I also think this is as much a Jython vs C Python issue as it is Python 2 vs  Python 3.  If the goal of the scripting language is give the developer access to the Ignition SDK,  I think it is not a big deal.  If you are trying to use common data analysis libraries such as pandas, numpy, sklearn,  etc.  then I can see how that is a bigger deal.  But also at some point a developer needs to consider what should be done in the iIOT platfoem vs another tool.

Author: _dyland
Content: Also keeping in mind that anyone can create new custom modules for ignition. That do basically whatever they want. Including wrap the data science libraries that are available in Java.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Just numpy and pandas would be very helpful.

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
Try not to perform the same slow calculations more than once, especially for lots of data. If you want totals for the last 30 days, for example, and you're already calculating daily totals every day, then just save that data once it's been calculated once and perform the calculation on the aggregated data instead.

Like, if you had to add parts over the past 30 days, first add up parts for the day and store the total, then you only have to add 30 numbers together instead of possibly tens of thousands. It really sounds like an algorithmic optimization problem when you're talking single digit numbers of calculations to do every 5 minutes.

If you're running inefficient algorithms, then changing your software, language, hardware, aren't going to fix the problem. Aggregate, save, aggregate, save.

Author: patanj2
Content: Haven‚Äôt had to do this, but what I would do is write and expose the Cpython functionality via API using a framework like flask and then call that from jython.

Author: _dyland
Content: Fast API is my go to for this type of stuff. Though it does add a lot of complexity for the team that has to maintain it so I try not to if I can help it... Despite my defense of Jython, it would be nice to have the option to use cPython libraries.

Author: dsi_101
Content: Thanks for the reply,  I have thought of that, but with the calculations done in the cloud and the edge sites on cellular when there is disruptions and say you do the calculation every hour and store to a sql database , it makes it hard to backfill that data through the calculations. Not sure of a automatic way of doing that. With the calculations working off of the historian don't have to worry about that.

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
Do you always know when the last piece of data was entered? And does the historical data ever change?

If your answers were "yes" and "no", then you could simply wait to do the calculations until you've received data from after the end of that time period you're aggregating data for. It doesn't have to happen exactly on the hour every time. Even if you waited 24 hours after collecting the data to aggregate it, then you'd still benefit greatly from not having to recalculate 29 days worth of data every 5 minutes.

Is any of that possible in your use case?

Author: dsi_101
Content:
The data is coming from analyzers and flow meters totalized odometer style. So the data is consistently changing.

For instance. One flow would be Infeed GAL. Need to get the start and end value for the metric to get the total Infeed GAL. Then run that through another 5 calculations to get Uptime, Efficiency compared to outfeed flow, GPD etc... that is just one of the many calculations.  

Gets really tricky with times,  these sites  are throughout the country so I have to take into consideration Timezones and Daylight savings to make sure we are getting the right start and end times for hourly, daily, yesterday,  last 24 hours, last 7 days and last 30 days calculations.

Author: mparris
Content: Agreed with this.  If you can't solve the network problem, it's likely better to stand up a proper local database that will easily accomodate 30days of data to recieve your records from your shop, then stand up a proper replication to the central server when connectivity is present.  I wouldn't describe this pattern as Store and Forward but it's more in line with database replication which as Remus mentioned is a different class of solution.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: We are doing an Ignition SCADA conversion project and for the historian we have been using TimeScale DB in our dev server. We are considering switching over to TimeBase.  Does anyone have thoughts around trending data via an API call to TimeBase?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: okay deal, how much do you know about Ignition?

Author: .discrete
Content: Why the switch from Timescale to Timebase?

Author: _dyland
Content:
You can do it. No problems there, you will lose the built in integrations with Ignition Components though. If your application is a traditional Process Historian and Ignition is the SCADA I would be worried about losing some of those integrated functions... But Timebase Explorer does have some of that, it's just probably not going to be accessed through the Ignition Interface (Though technically you could build it with the API and say Apex Charts).

That said, there is a lot of power in both options and some trade offs to each. 

One would be to consider who else is going to work on it, and how adding an additional outside component can affect their onboarding.

Also depends on the rest of the architecture and what is being historized. If Ignition is handling the device connections there is something to be said for keeping it all contained.

But if there is data coming from many different angles, Timebase can connect and store the data without requiring Ignition as a middleman. 

I can make a case for both right now. My current stance is if it's just a basic Ignition Deployment to keep with the Ignition Historian. 

But if it's a larger initiative or a more integrated architecture the door is open to external ones - like Timebase.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Just weighing it up atm, ive been playing around with TimeBase and im really impressed with it.

Author: jpmac.s

Thanks Dylan,
 losing that ability to browse the tags and configure tags for a small project makes TimescaleDB a better option at this point. Considering they dont have an engineer on site it needs to be simple for them to trend. Appreciate the insight

Author: _dyland
Content:
I do want to stress though - they are not loosing that ability, they are loosing the built in Ignition Functionality to natively do it in Ignition. Timebase Explorer does a lot.

And I am saying this with the assumption that by TimescaleDB you mean Ignitions Built in Historian using Timescale as the SQL Database?

Author: koios6274
Content: I use Ignition to do a post to HighByte webhook listener all the time with varying payloads.  You can then use the webhook event to trigger a pipeline, and use whatever came through in the payload as needed, so if you are capturing downtime reason data or whatever you "send/post" it to a webhook listener in HighByte and have a pipeline trigger off that.  I had all that working *before* callable pipelines and haven't refactored anything yet.

Content: Just a note for checking for duplicates doing an "Upsert" on the output connection from SQL is going to be your best friend

Author: koios6274
Content: *Upsert performs an Update if there are matching rows, and if there are no matching rows it performs an Insert.*

Im using API call using highbyte to get the data from sql for the dataset (binded in the data property of the charts). Im using bar charts

There's an arrow function/function call on the background color per each Bar that check if the data. The Y value of bar is the Cycle Time, and x axis is the Step number. 2) Is there also a a way i can re run the Function Call which is on the props.BackgroundColor of the dataset?

Author: carlos_mari_46361
Content:
Hey everyone!

I‚Äôve got two quick questions about Ignition:

From the UNS training or IIoT University videos, it sounded like Ignition Docker wasn‚Äôt fully recommended because of some bugs. Has anything changed? Is it stable now?

For a PoC, I‚Äôm thinking of not using Kepware and just going with Ignition‚Äôs built-in support for OPC UA, Modbus, and MQTT. I know Kepware has great connectors, but for standard protocols‚ÄîI expect Ignition handle it well enough?

Thanks! üôå

Author: gregory.g.
Content: Ignition in docker runs perfectly. We are running it in Production

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Gregory G., you just advanced to level 6!

Author: _dyland
Content:
Ignition works perfectly fine in docker - I have been doing it for years and if you count my demo and development environments I have spun up hundreds of Ignition Gateways in Docker - I cannot think of what bugs they would be reffering to? Maybe it was recorded before he official image? There was an "Unofficial" docker image a few years back.

As for Kepware, Having used Ignition for over a decade now - I have never once used Kepserver as the drivers for anything that Ignition already has built in. If it were a brownfield install that already had it I would use it but idk... It feels like one more thing to configure, maintain, and keep backups for. I have even done some pretty extreme tag counts from PLCs and there are issues at the high end but following best practice you shouldn't see them until the counts get into the 10s of thousands (depending on the driver Modbus, Siemens, Allen Bradley will have different limitations from each other). Im doing a project right now where we have 12,000 tags from just one of the ControlLogix PLCs for example. Eventually the Device Connections will become a burden on the Gateway's JVM Resources but that is where multiple Gateways / Ignition Edge can come into play.

Author: tyler092335
Content: When you deploy multiple gateways what are you commonly using to centralize the tags? Are you using the cirrus links mqtt modules or ignitions gateways network. I like how nice cirrus links engine pulls all transmissions together into a central communication folder, but the updating of udts on the edge is frustrating that you have to delete the engine tags and udts then retransmit. The gateway network is messy with all the communication folder but you gain not having to delete stuff when you update a udt.

Author: _dyland
Content:
It depends - Neither option is perfect but I basically treat SparkplugB like Ignition's Fieldbus at this point. 

I haven't had time to sit down with it but I am planning on testing a hybrid option of both pretty soon.

Author: _dyland
Content: Honestly, most of my experience is pushing a single gateway to its limit... I have had a fairly large number of clients over the years who didn't believe me when I said we were hitting the capacity of the gateway.. I had one we pushed to I think 500,000 tags, a dozen projects, 20 or 30 vision clients and a dozen PLCs before it finally met its match. After 100,000 tags and two years prior to the crash I started to tell them it was coming.

Author: _dyland
Content: Finally this last couple years I have been able to better sell in the needs earlier on in the planning process.

Author: _dyland
Content: Long way to say that I am still discovering the best ways of connecting multiple brokers myself.

Author: tyler092335

I have both the gateway network and cirrus links running. We are trying to find that happy medium and right now we are using control with the gateway network and mqtt for ‚Äúdata transfer‚Äù between softwares. If you are interested we can collab on what we are doing and what you have planned in your future hybrid system

Author: jpmac.s
Content: GAN is fine on a solid network connection and use SpB for more contrained networks. The last multi-site architecture we designed in conjunction with IA and we had both, because the GAN does alot more than managing tags.

Author: dsi_101
Content:
I switched to using the GAN over using MQTT - It is so limiting in a process environment.  Then Using the tag history splitter / sender service for Canary at the edge to send to central Canary historian. 

Using MQTT either through reference tags or the MQTT collector doesn't give good Historian data when it is report by exception tied to the UNS. If I need to query data at midnight to get a total for the day I can't, because there is no data there if the value didn't change in the last 10 min. Using data straight from the edge using the periodic historian sampling is the only way for process plants. 

Seems like a lot of what is discussed in this discord if for discrete manufacturing which doesn't translate to cement plants, power generation and water / wastewater.

Content: I work at a discrete manufacturing facility, and we have a full Ignition license set up on our server. We want to connect some of our production lines to the facility server, but I'm not sure what the best approach would be. The production lines each have 1-3 PLCs, but they are using ip addressing that conflicts with our facility network. The two options I've settled on (although if someone has a better suggestion I am open to it) are either to use a NAT device or to use something (maybe a small industrial PC?) with 2 NICs that can run Ignition Edge. I'm leaning towards Ignition Edge, as I have experience setting a similar situation up, but was curious if anyone had some thoughts or their own experience with this.

Author: _dyland
Content:
It's really hard to say without a lot of specifics.
Those are 2 of many valid ways of doing it. 

I would consult with your IT and Cyber Security teams (assuming you are representing operations) and see how this plays into the larger plant network and strategy. Once these three teams are aligned, these decisions make themselves.

Author: koios6274
Content: Buy an Opto22 Groov Epic with Igniiton Edge.  LAN side to your private PLC betwork.  WAN side to your "plant network".  Consume all data via Ignition Edge and publish via MQTT Transmitter to Ignition. No re-IP or NAT needed, and you can also now go online with private side PLC via port redirect

Author: koios6274
Content: NAT is cool technology but not understood by all and will lead to complications. Re IP is often not feasible.  Drop in a secure Edge GW that can talk to the LAN side and WAN side. Opto 22 Groov Epic does exactly this. I've used many to onboard different lines/areas or "islands of automations" where all the PLCs are on a typical 192.168.1.x network. You only need 1x IP on the WAN side and can even be DHCP with your IT group.  MQTT is one directional firewall rule sourced from edge gw destined to broker, so very IT friendly. One rule from "mfg VLAN" to "server" = multi source single destination TCP/1883 (mqtt) or TCP/8883(mqtts) by default

Author: koios6274
Content: this also gives you advantage of store&forward buffering at the edge depending on how reliable your network infrastructure is.  You no longer have your central ignition server "ask" for data and have to deteministically know what is out there, your data comes to you.

Author: dustin0101
Content: This is basically what I was thinking with an Edge deployment. I like the Opto22 products but wasn't sure if it's overkill for what I'm trying to do. Thanks for the suggestion.

Author: paulqingliu
Content: Hello, I am looking for someone with experience in migrating iFIX to Ignition. Thank you!üòÄ

Author: _dyland
Content:
They are very different platforms, there will not be a direct "migration" process.

Identify functionality that is currently in iFix and piece it out (scripts, screens, historian, alarming, tags, internal databases, etc).

Then it is prioritizing, strategizing, and roadmapping. 

Duplicating functions as needed and phasing out the iFix equivalents over time, and eventually... once everything is migrated to the new platform (ignition) spin down iFix and move forward with the new platform until next time.

Author: paulqingliu
Content: thanks. Is there a tool to help this process move faster?

Author: _dyland
Content: Not really, on the technical side. Unless you are looking for project management tools?

Author: _dyland
Content: They are very different platforms.

Author: paulqingliu
Content: I guess iFIX doesn't support JSON format?

Author: _dyland
Content: It has been years since I was deep into iFix and even then it was an old version. So I really don't know that off hand.

Author: _dyland
Content: Though for the scripts, an LLM might be able to help speed up the time to reverse engineering. Especially when digging through copious amounts of VBA. If I remember right most of the iFix files are XML or some other form that can be opened and toyed with.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I would start by inventorying the functionality, tags, and screens in iFix and then go with a small part of what is in iFix and build it in ignition and go from there. A full migration in a single project is usually a recipe for disaster.

Just don't forget to keep a roadmap in mind.

Author: _dyland
Content: Even if there was a simple conversion tool, I wouldn't recommend it. As they are very different platforms a 1:1 conversion would miss the nuance and best practice that is different between them.

Author: _dyland
Content: Really just wanted to drop the advice that any integrator who wants to treat this as a single "Migration" or "Conversion" project should be cut out of the conversation. This is almost always an iterative process... Way too much "You don't know what you don't know" up front.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Depending on the size and scale*

Author: _dyland
Content: If it's a legacy iFix install I'm assuming it's not too small of a scale. That stuff was expensive.

Author: _dyland
Content: My experience quoting any full on SCADA replacement has been that it is always more than it looks like up front - so I stopped quoting full replacements... I also had quite a few projects back in the day where we came in after another Integrator had just straight up walked away... Usually it was two sided but almost always a miscommunication on scope that wasn't usually known by either party up front.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: I dont know iFix but we have done plenty of Ignition migrations in a single project

Author: _dyland
Content:
Yeah, I have too - every one I have done would have been faster, higher quality, and less stressful if they hadn't been. 

Except for some really small stuff.

Author: _dyland
Content: The number of things the client didn't know going in... I have found it best to rebuild with the problem statements in mind - reverse engineer the old but rebuild with use-cases in mind rather than a direct replacement.

Author: _dyland
Content: That said, I'm in a rut of preaching against "Integrator Lock" right now. The End-User taking smaller bites makes it a lot easier to move on if they find themselves with the wrong partner.
