Author: kelltek
Content:
Hey guys, I am looking for some help revamping a projects architecture. Is there recommendations or better documentations on best practices for the data structure?

I have a fairly large hub and spoke gateway network. 12 gateways at remote sites, all with different assets and data structures. UDTs of these assets are defined at those gateways and they provide store and forward service to a remote historian at the hub (along with alarm services)

This project has grown and the previous engineer decided to unify the model by creating duplicated UDTs of every remote gateways UDTs but as derived/reference tags. At a smaller scale this worked fine but is becoming difficult to scale. 

Initially I thought about just building everything and just referencing the remote tag providers directly but when communications are down I am unable to see the data structure. In the reference model, even if a remote gateway is offline tags all still live on the front end but their quality just drops. 

Any advice? I would love to slim down UDTs and eliminate some redundancy but I would love to get some opinions from guys with a little more experience.

Author: mparris
Content:
I recommend the NAT approach rather than the Ignition edge gateway approach. 

You may have another reason to access those PLCs that has nothing to do with Ignition, such as automatically backing up the PLC programs.

NAT will enable the ignition use case now and others in the future. 

What CTownKyle says about NAT is so true... Not all NAT appliances are created equal and none of them are intuitive and there are so many options that is impossible to compare across vendors. 

All that led me to commission an intuitive NAT application to run on general PCs. Still a work in progress, but will be happy to share some videos when it's complete.

Summoning the wizard: @varghesejm

Author: varghesejm
Content:
Happy to take you through these:

https://www.traceroutellc.com/blog#NothingButNAT

We have done NAT on AB, Moxa, Hirschmann, Siemens, Helmholz, Siemens, Phoenix Contact, Fortinet, Check Point, Weidmuller, Dynics, Cisco, Antaira, eWON, RedLion, and probably another dozen.

And as @MParris mentions, also gone custom where desired.

NAT is a great solution for many things, but not everything.

Author: .killnine
Content:
> You may have another reason to access those PLCs that has nothing to do with Ignition, such as automatically backing up the PLC programs.

Yes! Where I was at before we put our programs into source control with a checkout-checkin mechanism (to avoid having multiple instances of the program being worked on at once) and it was so nice when a device died to have that. 

I don't have that here (yet) and it's bit us a few times. 

Kinda unrelated to your main point but glad other people do this, too.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Yeah, it‚Äôs a compromise between pros and cons. With Tulip you‚Äôre getting SaaS whereas with Ignition you get a license and have to host it yourself either bare metal or VM, etc. 

With Tulip you get access to Postgres / Timescale without having to worry about performance tuning.

With Tulip you can access things like a wide range of devices built into Tulip Player, or cloud based vision using off-the-shelf webcams.

Lots more but at the end of the day it comes down to whether you need those features, how far away from no-code your company wants to get. Do you want to hire or contract full stack developers?

I love Tulip, but the price prevented it from being an option at the moment.  

I also wouldn't say you need to hire a full stack dev to get a lot out of Ignition.  I have very little programming background, and I've been able to build a basic MES being self taught from youtube, chat gpt, and the forums.

I'm still trying to demonstrate the value in self ownership of digital transformation to my organization.  I wanted to start small, build something useful for the front line operators, and continue to grow.  Perspective unlimited cost us around $15k, so nobody bats an eye, and I can take my time developing as I want.  

Down the line I can see a world where I'd use both Tulip and Ignition, but Ignition is the lowest cost option to get started playing.

I forget the exact figure, but you pay per interface, and it's an annual recurring fee.  Vs Ignition is a one time cost and if you get unlimmited you can have as many interfaces as you want.

Tulip is still 100% worth the cost - the platform is truly impressive, and the cost is in line with lots of other industrial software.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: I‚Äôm writing an MQTT module for Ignition at the moment, I‚Äôm considering only providing publish functionality as a scripting function. This is mainly because publishing is event based, so if Ignition is publishing, it is most likely already script driven, and write blocking to a tag is just double handling the data. Does this make sense?

Author: dawd
Content: So no bidirectional tag bindings? Just an MQTT analogue of system.opc.writeValue?

Author: dawd
Content: Are topics still shown in the tag browser?

Author: system24seven9226
Content: That‚Äôs correct, tags don‚Äôt actually exist in MQTT, so it‚Äôs an artificial concept and causes race conditions.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Topics all self populate in the tag browser, same as normal, but writes don‚Äôt work there.

Author: dawd
Content: Makes sense to have a publish function to avoid double-handling and race conditions

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @dawd, you just advanced to level 4!

Author: dawd
Content: Why not offer both and leave it to the end-user?

Author: dawd
Content: writeBlocking has similar pitfalls as it is

Author: dawd
Content: .publish() for heartbeats (for example) and situations in which race conditions / queuing issues might occur

Author: b_dawg_17
Content: Is the publish function going to be asynchronous? Or will it block until it gets some confirmation from somewhere?

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
I ask because what you‚Äôre doing with the tags makes it way too convenient to not want writing capabilities on every single tag. What I‚Äôd do if they were read-only is write a script that adds the publish function to all those tags in the onChange event and make them read-write myself.

So your dilemma, from my perspective, would be whether you want me to implement the write functionality myself (don‚Äôt put slow shit in your onChange events, you‚Äôll learn some hard lessons about it later down the line if you do) (also, do not trust ‚Äúme‚Äù as a dev to implement according to best practices), or do you make the tags read-write yourself (maybe handle an edge case or two, maybe not) and save me from being tempted into creating some weird workaround?

Basically, because you‚Äôve already populated the tag structure and implemented the read functionality already, I‚Äôm going to want to treat it like every other tag. You‚Äôve made it too convenient lol.

I can also see an argument for enforcing intentional (responsible) usage of the publish function by making the tags read-only. There is something to be said about making something look different to communicate that it should be used differently.

I‚Äôd say, ultimately, whatever you choose, make your design decisions clear to your future dev users. You can‚Äôt stop them from shooting themselves in the foot in every case, but you can light up the intended path so those looking for it know where to go.

I hope that all made sense!

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Asynchronous I think, I‚Äôm not sure what confirmation I get for a publish yet.

Author: b_dawg_17
Content: MQTT is mostly a one-way communication protocol, but idk if there‚Äôs tricky stuff happening under the hood that you might need to block for.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: To be honest, development time is limited so I‚Äôm trying to focus on critical functions

Author: system24seven9226

Author: system24seven9226

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Also in MQTT there is no requirement for a tag to exist to publish data into, so if you are dynamically populating your namespace, having to build a tag then publish data to it is a pain as a user. With the publish() option, you can land data anywhere in the namespace as required.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not true at all.  There's a protocol level ack.  And depending on your QoS level, a whole lotta acking going on.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: I guess that will make a return value for the publish() system at minimum, which means that either I make a blocking function for publish or we do asynchronous with a callback

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Definitely shouldn't be blocking.  You can have a blocking *facade* from an API point of view, if you want, but behind the scenes it should be async.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: BTW, you don't need to write this from scratch.  I'm sure there are countless open source implementations you can start from.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: I‚Äôm working on the HiveMQ libraries, but you still need to define the behaviour of the ignition interface

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Blocking as far as blocking the ignition script until completion, much the same as the system.tag.writeBlocking() that is commonly used.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also consider the error case of course.  One option is to have a blocking scenario (with timeout) and throw an error or use an error/success code.  The other option is to mimic most async libraries and have an error callback and a success callback.  You also want to consider how you'll handle retries (since it's not clear how/if some of the MQTT client libraries handle it), plus it might be a behavior you want to customize.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: I feel like retries are some time off in my dev pipeline, so far I have tls encryption and auth with username/password working and also self populating tag structures in a managed tag provider in ignition, working with vanilla MQTT. Code is also on GH

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's my understanding that for most Tulip customers, it's multi tenant. It's built on modern SaaS architecture. There isn't the risk that a tenant can crowd itself out or the underlying infrastructure can be over subscribed. 

The bigger considerations for performance would be driven by how apps are configured and the problems they solve. For example, it probably is not best for granular tracking of a high speed automated progressive stamping process, but rather the human activity around it. The storage and retrieval of those automation events might be outside the norm of a typical Tulip customer. It might be better paired with other solutions or consider an alternative that's more in the focus.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For most manufacturers, I believe it's possible to hit performance objectives with MES in the cloud or hosted remotely. 

The first thing is to make sure there are proper commercial grade connections. It will be something like a fiber circuit marketed as a WAN (carrier/metro ethernet, MPLS) or Dedicated Internet Access (DIA). It will have an SLA and terminate on the carrier's backbone network. A lot of manufacturers have small branch offices colocated at their plants and have historically gotten by using broadband services. These are "best effort" networks for small business and residential. They are not appropriate for operations.

The next thing to consider is database design. Big transactional systems like MES and ERP can require periodic tuning. What a developer originally built schema and procedures for may not necessarily align with how an end user implemented and is using the app. Take a pareto approach of focusing on the heaviest utilized and poorest performing queries. Study the execution paths and learn where the bottle necks are. Work to drive down execution times and likelihood of timeouts.

The third thing to consider are the integration patterns. An MES is not a node on a fieldbus. It can be really inefficient to serially process many events in a short period of time. For example, if it's a high speed process with piece-level traceability, it may not be necessary to transact on each piece. Operationally, it may not make a difference whether the event was transacted with millisecond vs second/minute precision. It might not matter to the operator or process if the events are delivered together in a batch. The events could be timestamped at the origin, but they could be packaged more efficiently.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Tulip has a fat client that runs on the local OS. I would imagine some of the dependencies or static data for the Tulip app is cached when an app is downloaded/launched. The app is reactive and appears to know what to fetch from the server. It's not a full retrieval and render on each click, if that makes sense.

Author: markyfreeds
Content:
Haha, no magic tricks. We were writing to the UNS via the cloud hive mq broker. Tulip has an MQTT option for machine datasources, which is one of the ways tulip can be event driven and feeds into their machine pipeline / feature. 

Tulip can also write to these data sources. Besdies that, the tulip player or local client is performing all sorts of other activities like rendering the interface and executing app and device logic on the edge. 

If apps get complex or use bad practice, you can start to feel it in the app for sure, but we kept our app purpose built.  I also built a custom widget to make the injestion of MQTT events -> visualization much faster. As always, there are many ways to build a solution and how you choose to build it can have implications to performance.  Generally speaking... calls to external systems can take >500ms, and this includes calls to your edge device... so I try to pick where and how I want to spend those ms, often times deferring to automations for time-insensitive tasks.

in the case of my app at proveit, i decided that i wanted the button push to give the operator immediate feedback (i demo'd this on stage, this button). the button was a single trigger action, but behind the scenes the automation performed a bunch of other CRUD+logic.. which made it appear snappier...because there is no reason to make an operator wait if its of no value to.

Author: golden_quail_28507
Content: Hello ; I have a small issue related to ignition redundancy ( I am at the beginning with Ignition); I try to explain the actual configuration so maybe someone has some hints for improvements: I have a master gateway  running a Mqtt broker (Distributor) + a client (Mqtt engine); the data is published from another gateway (Edge) using the Transmission module; The edge gateway has a redundant pair (another same Edge); According to the doc file of the mqtt modules, the Transmission module is able to bufferize (locally) the data while the connection is broken with the main gateway ( that is working almost fine when I have a single Edge gateway); But when I use the redundant Edge pair there is a "big" time interval (~10 sec) when the data is lost (that is the time since the MAster Edge disconnects till the BAckup Edge takes over); I tried to play with the mqtt modules settings (timeouts, history settings) but I was not able to improve the functionalit; any ideea? is there any trick that , when the master disconnects, the backup Edge takes over quicker but also  with recovering (from the local buffer) the "lost" data (the data that the MAster should have transmitted while it disconnects). thank you for any idea/suggestion

Author: du5tins
Content: In the edge gateways are the group, edge node, and device names in transmitter all the same? They should be different at the edge node level.

Author: golden_quail_28507
Content: hello; I don't get it; so the 2 edge are intended to be a redundant pair (master + backup); so the configuration on the backup edge will be identical with the master; the 2 edge gateways are connected to the same equipment (PLC); the only issue is that when master disconnects (from any reason) there is a delay till backup is taking over

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
Hi, not sure if this would help with your issue or not, but I would make sure the redundant pair is set to ‚Äúhot‚Äù fallover. That way, the redundant server is already processing the same events in parallel when connection is lost. A ‚Äúcold‚Äù start would have to initialize all the connections the master had on the redundant gateway on startup, which might be related to your delay. Again, not sure if it‚Äôll solve your issue, but it might be worth looking into if you haven‚Äôt already. The redundant edge gateway is the one with that setting, I believe.

If that doesn‚Äôt solve it, you might have a bug/feature request on your hands. As always, check the forums:
https://forum.inductiveautomation.com
and check/post on the feedback site too:
https://ideas.inductiveautomation.com

Author: jpmac.s
Content:
Hi,

I have a project where we are converting a Movicon SCADA system to Ignition, the controllers they are using are Siemens S7-300s. The tags are being packed into DBs and transferred across in byte arrays.

My question is what is the most efficient/cleanest way to unpack those bytes into bits within Ignition? 

What I have done is create expression tags that reference the byte using the getBit function and unpack them that way. 

The other way would be to just reference the bit directly in the OPC item path DB120,B582.1, but will this put more traffic on the controller?

Any suggestions? Cheers.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: The Siemens driver optimises on its own, adding expressions is just wasting processing as it‚Äôs less optimised. Normally it will grab the byte from the plc then extract the bit locally. Also expression tags abstract away from real tags making tag diagnostics not work properly.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: So would you code the bit directly in the item path?

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Yep, one tag, one bit. How many tags are you pulling?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: 472 bytes on one PLC , the project has around 30 PLCs still to come online, not sure about the total tag count.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Probably need to watch your tag overload, max pdu size is 240bytes

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @system24seven, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: system24seven9226
Content: May need to use two driver instances for same plc with half the tags on each of it starts going over 5% overload

Author: jpmac.s
Content: What would be the impact by using getBit on an expression v addressing each bit directly?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Is this a limitation on the ignition driver?

Author: system24seven9226
Content: No different to direct access as it pulls just as much data to get the bit, it just also loads up ignition and makes the tag database a mess and hard to maintain or troubleshoot

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Nope, hardware limit on a 300 from Siemens side

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Also there are limits to how many connections you can connect to each different model, that includes hmis, wincc, pg etc‚Ä¶

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Ah okay thank you, on the single data packet, if i split the array into mutiply byte arrays will that get around the PDU limits?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Or is that total

Author: system24seven9226
Content: I‚Äôm not sure what you are referencing by ‚Äúarrays‚Äù, ignition doesn‚Äôt read arrays from Siemens, only the basic data types.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Im refering to the db in the PLC

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Pretty much every tag is packed into db120

Author: system24seven9226
Content: The driver will auto split into pdus, but I‚Äôve had issues with bad tags etc when you don‚Äôt get it right, trial and error sometimes helps.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Awesome thanks ! Super helpful

Author: system24seven9226
Content: A DB is just a defined memory area, it doesn‚Äôt have a structure unless you fill it with arrays and udts. Ignition just references basic data types using the db address and the offset from the start of the block. It only pulls bytes that you ask for part or all of

Author: dawd
Content: @Server Moderator  üòí

Author: sim_sam3
Content: Actually yes it is, Siemens S7 (legacy register-based protocol) permits up to 960 PDU size but there is additional nuanced engineering required to implement fragmentation at application protocol layer / layer 7. We had to add this about 15 years into the life of our basic Siemens driver ~2014 timeframe, so it had a really good run until we felt enough pressure to support it. Large, ‚Äúunmodifiable‚Äù arrays were a major contributing factor.

Content: Anyone with the Ignition Core certification able to advise on whether the training course is really required? If you complete the credential course and have a good read of the manual - will this be sufficient to pass the exam?

Author: system24seven9226
Content: I can‚Äôt speak for the course, but you‚Äôll need a lot more than just finishing the credential and reading the manual. Core is about applied skills, so 12 months of working on client projects will get you a lot further than study.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Gold is just another level of complexity on top of that, with more in depth experience required.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I never took the paid training and none of the engineers or techs I sent to it considered it very valuable. They went over the basics. Not much more. 

I think I recall a conversation where one of our engineers told me about how they taught the WebDev module in the advanced course, and how they introduced an easy point for SQL injection with the implementation they tought (there are ways to do it securely). 

We used it as a faster path to certification than going through every video when speed was the priority (say an engineer had 3-5 years of experience but couldn't take the test without 40 hours of videos or the training course) - the training usually resulted in less calander days to certification.

It's been probably 7 years since I took the Core test myself, but I remember a lot of things I hadn't seen yet on the test. Alarm Pipelines and reporting Module to name a couple. On top of some things that even then I thought were odd ways of doing things... And ways of using the template repeaters in vision that I still strongly disagree with today. 

Basically, there will be stuff on there you haven't seen before. Ignition is a big platform. 

I usually scheduled 3 days for a relatively new tech or engineer to complete it. Even though they recommended 8 hours.

Author: iiot_goat
Content:
The new Core Test (released a year or so ago) is a 100 multiple choice question format. The old Core Test has been rebranded as the Ignition Design Challenge. They claimed too many integrators were using the Core Test as a way to train people and it diluted the value of the certification, and taking way too much time for their team to grade. Yes you learn enough in the official training class to meet the requirements to pass the Core Test, and you get a certification for taking the class, however the class doesn't go into as much detail as you might need to complete a scalable Ignition project if that is your only experience with the platform. 

Personally I think IU is a great tool for people who are familiar with other SCADA platforms to learn how things work in Ignition, however it is absolutely terrible as a way for people new to SCADA or software development in general to learn the platform. The best tool for learning Ignition was the old core test, so it is a good thing they rebranded and released it for free, although you don't have the benefit of having it graded so might miss some efficiencies along the way if that is your first time doing an Ignition project.

Oddly enough the "new" Gold Cert is the same as the old Gold Cert, it is still a project brief you have to complete that gets graded. Based on the reasons for moving the Core Cert to a multiple choice test it is surprising they didn't move Gold to a multiple choice test as well. Yes there are more complexities involved at that level as you get into database queries and whatnot, but Wonderware System Platform tests have always been multiple choice and that is a much more convoluted system to work in.

Author: iiot_goat
Content:
My training regimen for anyone new to Ignition is this:
1. Do the Ignition Design Challenge so you can learn how to build a project, get familiar with the docs and how to search the forum.
2. If they are in a cycle where you have to complete IU to take the Core Cert then do that, but if you aren't required to do IU like they have it set up right now skip IU entirely.
3. Take the Core Test
4. Go through the Gold Test Study Guide and get familiar with that, or better yet get access to an old Gold Test and go through it to see all the things you need to learn for the actual test
5. Sign up for the Gold Test and knock that out.

Anyone who has done any Ignition work including database integration should be able to complete the Gold Test without a lot of hassle. It is probably 2-3 days of solid effort if you're familiar with the platform, and it doesn't require any huge leaps in terms of what you need to build beyond most customer facing projects.

My point still stands though, Ignition Certification used to be something that stood out when I was looking over resumes. Now it doesn't really stand out either way...

Author: enlace3444
Content:
Clear Picture SA Framework

Hi everyone ‚Äî I‚Äôve been developing a new design framework called Clear Picture SA to help improve industrial dashboards using Situation Awareness (SA) principles.

Just completed the first round of testing with Ignition:
üîé ‚ÄúInformation Timeliness‚Äù in Ignition
üåê https://framework.clearpicturesa.com/sa-principles/information-timeliness#ignition-perspective-supports-information-timeliness

The goal is to evaluate how well different platforms support real-world SA design patterns ‚Äî one principle at a time. 

If you‚Äôre working with Ignition and care about dashboard clarity, I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts ‚Äî or any ideas for future tests.

Open to feedback, suggestions, or conversation.

Author: thunt.career
Content: In the ignition example it looks like the pump is not running when timeliness is applied, not that the data is stale. For real time dashboards and control, the big wire overlay with error when data missed updates. I'm not sure what use case I would use transparency for.

Author: enlace3444
Content:
Thanks for the observation, @Travis Hunt . With the black background, the pump appears to fade to gray instead of showing transparent behavior. I've updated the background to light gray and added a "Pump Stopped" state for comparison. The distinction between Running, Stopped, and Stale data is now more visually apparent (see the first attached screenshot).

Transparency is just one visual technique to convey Information Timeliness. Another is the use of "time delay" bars beneath each asset to indicate how fresh the data is. The core idea is that the most recent data should draw the most attention. In the third screenshot, where multiple assets are presented at once, the visual fading helps to quickly assess the data freshness of the assets

Example use cases:

- Lab Sample Monitoring: In pulp and paper or water treatment, lab values might be entered manually on a schedule. If an entry is missed, performance tracking gaps emerge. Timeliness helps expose those misses.

- An analytics or data collection process constrained by resources (e.g. low RAM) may stop updating values without triggering any errors. In general, this applies to any situation where data updates are missed but no system failure is registered ‚Äî or made visible to the operator.

Author: singhnitish.disc
Content: What would be a good industrial stack? High byte and ignition or do they have overlap in some way?

Author: singhnitish.disc
Content: Context: We have been doing UNS pocs for a few months and now at a point where we must look towards data ingestion, semantics, heirarchy in a more professional way than just node red and Mosquitto offer.. we want to build business user interfaces, do governance, define data pipelines from and to our UNS broker etc etc..

Author: _dyland
Content:
Depends on the current state of the brownfield environment and the needs of the business. What are the first problems that you are building a UNS to solve? What tools already exist? Do you have a controls network yet? 

For the site level:
Some combination of Ignition, Flow Software, Highbyte, and Litmus as platforms on the infrastructure layer of Historians, Databases, and Brokers. Is often a good place to start. 

Between them you can make a lot of different stacks that - "Connect, Collect, Store, Analyze, Visualize, Find, Report, and Solve" 

You might only need one or two of the platforms right away, and you might stop at two or three before jumping into the enterprise application layer where everything expands. 

(Also, Don't sleep on Timebase Historian)

Author: singhnitish.disc
Content:
Current state: node red flows for pushing data changes from erp. Node red flows for connection to machines mqtt broker and transforming to UNS namespaces

Streamlit based dashboards

Custom frontend to display data of historian ( yes, timebase indeed).. takes some time to get right (usually streamlit or vibe coded react)

Now, If we must begin by selecting our first product/platform.. which one would you recommend? I know it‚Äôs a general question.. but that‚Äôs how it will go I‚Äôm pretty sure. Buying one product, making it work, providing incremental value and maturing the landscape.

Author: _dyland
Content:
By current state - I mean more than you can probably talk about publicly - What PLCs, DCS, Historians, Robots, CNC, or other Machines / Field Devices are there? Are they networked? What protocols do they speak? 

What is the current state of the People and Culture - is there resistance or excitement? Both? Who are the stakeholders, who is "On Your Team" and who has yet to get on board? What do they care about? 

What are the first few projects we intend to use this "Stack" for? 

In some situations I would start with Flow - Others Ignition or Litmus. Depending on the short term need and the long term goals. 

More often then not, Ignition is the swiss army knife, it does most everything that any of the other platforms do but eventually you will scale out of any stack that is exclusively Ignition. Depending on the cultural state, this may be a requirement - or it may be a terrible technical debt as those other parties may prohibit other platforms as Ignition shows that it "Can" do those tasks (for now). 

If it is an Industry and Site with Heavy Process Historian integration - Flow is one of the best starting points.

If you need more than the base Ignition drivers than Litmus is probably the best bet for connectivity as it can be the connectivity layer today and grow into it's other functions. 

Sorry for the long non-answer... it really depends on the situation... but 99 times out 100 Ignition is somewhere in the stack so it is hard to go wrong with it as a starting point.

Author: singhnitish.disc
Content: Thanks.. I think we will get started with evaluating ignition.. completely agree about all the aspects. Luckily, there is good support for these initiatives. First pocs revolve around tracking machine states, creating availability charts (not OEE yet).. tracking released workload on to lines, assessing impact of unreleased workorders on workloads of lines.. so really contextualizing and normalising data on to our shopfloor namespace.. I also believe ignition will be a good starting point to manage and scale our UNS.. create some quick dashboards, user interfaces for factory planners etc

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
IT very much depends on what you want to do.
There is some overlap and it is very common to start with Ignition and then add highByte on top They complement each other very well. The way I think about it is, Igntion is about connection and moving data. HighByte is for modelling  information to analyse and give insights.

Single plant I would look at starting with Frameworx, Igntiosn, WinCCoA, InTouch  (in that order, but if you have one already on site it should be leveraged if possible - I am not a rip and replace guy)

Multi Site I would look at Litmus, or leveraging Litmus through Google to build solutions with Google Cloud

IF you have a very manual driven process, I would be looking at Tulip

Litmus, Tulip and HighByte would be a dream stack for me to work on.

here is an old post of mine with some thoughts https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7310063911901294592/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
HighByte is for standardizing, curating, integrating, and governing industrial data. Ignition is for building SCADA and IIoT applications to produce and consume industrial data. 

HighByte engineers industrial data:
-Data orchestration
-Data quality
-Data governance
-Data observability

Ignition makes use of industrial data:
-Supervisory control
-Visualization
-Alarm and event management
-IoT application development

At scale, HighByte is a hub and Ignition is a spoke. HighByte converts raw data into information. It collaboratively and methodically remediates mismatches between data producers and data consumers. Ignition is a net data producer in process control contexts (e.g., HMI, SCADA). In industries with batch or continuous processes, Ignition will typically be a provider of telemetry data in its supervisory context (e.g., with alarms, with operator HMI inputs, with set points). Telemetry indicates what industrial automation is doing, but alone lacks operational context to support business processes and timely decision making. This is where transactional, historical, and file data comes in. Beyond this, Ignition is a net data consumer in visualization and application contexts (e.g., IoT, MES, frontline apps, dashboarding, workflows). Ignition is an ultra flexible node for using data to facilitate business processes with human involvement and custom application logic.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: While I‚Äôm on the topic of Ignition. I‚Äôve tended to end up using tag event scripting for the purpose of storing events to a database in Ignition. I know this is basically a big part of what SQL bridge is meant to do. But since we have all of our stuff in UDTs, from what I understand, there is no way to tie a transaction group to UDTs, such that if I were to make a new UDT it would automatically be subscribed to by the transaction group.. (or something to that effect). So I tend to use tag event scripts on UDTs instead. Have I misunderstood something? I‚Äôve never found the case for SQL bridge because of this limitation. Similar for gateway tag change scripts, as they can‚Äôt be applied to UDT definitions..

Author: _dyland
Content:
On this one, I haven't used the SQL bridge in probably 5 years (maybe more) myself. We used to use it a lot but after a bit we changed to almost using python scripts - sometime around 7.9. Now it's a combination of scripts,Named Queries, and Query Tags.

I personally find the SQL bridge limiting myself but I know some people love its simplicity.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I don't think the development time should really factor in here, if IA was able to develop it fast, power to them. The market will eventually determine if a module is worth it or not... 

For me, I don't know any work arounds or custom built options that are cheaper than the web dev... 

I mean, I could spin up a service with FastAPI or Flask or something but even if it takes only 12 hours to develop and 12 hours to implement, even if we ignore the need to support and maintain a custom solution it's more expensive to have a mid-level developer build it than the $2,300 it will cost after these price increases. 

At the end of the day, it has its price, as do other options and workarounds, if it's cheaper to work around it than people won't buy the module....more so,  if people think it's cheaper... They won't buy it. 

If enough people didn't buy it, they would likely lower the price. Or bundle it like you suggested. 

If it were overpriced, I would suspect that we would see a popular 3rd party module that does the same thing? Like we see for GIT integration, Custom Charts, or MQTT.

Nothing stopping someone from building an alternative module - or spinning up an external option - or using a different platform.

Author: _dyland
Content: Not trying to get defensive for IA, just that in a market where they are raising their prices, including  the features of one module into another is not something I would think they would, or should, do for free... If perspective were to be $2k more expensive because of it, it would be a sad day for all the perspective users who don't need the WebDev functionality.

Author: hanno23
Content:
Thanks for suggesting EAM @Jon Forbord & @Josh Mac . I have not personally used it before. In an ideal world I would want to use MQTT for the communication protocol in conjunction with EAM to manage the infrastructure (gateway, tags , etc). I am just worried that the EAM module is not built for unstable networks the same way MQTT is? Or have you guys had success?

Our edge devices will be in remote places where cellular connection is the only option. This is no problem for MQTT but I am not sure about EAM? If EAM does not work I need to make another plan, either send files to the edge devices containing tag configs, or load tag configs via MQTT  (@jon.forbord interesting to hear you thought about it as well).

Author: jon.forbord
Content: With SpB, any sending of values to edge (ie cmd) will be on QoS=0, so it will fail if there is network issues.  EAM likely uses synchronous communication, and will similarly return a fail if the send fails. Point being, i don‚Äôt know how they would be much different. I‚Äôd give EAM a try.

Author: thunt.career
Content: What would the module do for you? I believe most Ignition historian modules are specific to inserting data directly into the database. Timebase doesn't expose its store directly so you either could do send POST to the web API for new data or could just configure the OPC-UA collector to read your Ignition tags. On the visualization side, you could either use the Explorer web page or build a custom component to leverage the live data or GET requests to their web API.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: It would be, but it wouldn‚Äôt be bundled. So it‚Äôs another thing to manage. Plus it couldn‚Äôt be expanded upon to make use of the integrated parts.

Author: enlace3444
Content:
Hi everyone ‚Äî continuing my exploration into how Situation Awareness (SA) principles can improve industrial dashboards.

Just wrapped up another SA design test ‚Äî this time using Ignition Perspective to visualize Deviation with Limits + Duration.

The idea: it‚Äôs not just about knowing a value is out of spec ‚Äî
‚Ä¶it‚Äôs about helping operators understand the situation.

üïì How long has it been off?
üìç When did it go out of range?
üî∫ Which direction is the deviation heading?

Full write-up and visuals here:
üåê https://framework.clearpicturesa.com/sa-principles/deviation#ignition-perspective-supports-deviation-duration-limits

Would love to hear your thoughts/comments ‚Äî how do you currently visualize duration of abnormal conditions in your dashboards?

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Had to put my actions where my mouth was, so here we go: 

¬´WebFolders¬ª - a free Ignition module that lets you expose content of folders as web resources. Setup in the gateway configuration - specify ¬´name¬ª and root path. To use the resource it‚Äôs http://ignitionurl/system/webfolders/¬´name¬ª/filename.xxx

http://ignitionurl/system/webfolders/¬´name¬ª/folder/subfolder/anotherfile.xxx

As opposed to the WebDev module this resource will expose all folders and files including subfolders and files in those folders. If the path is a folder, WebFolders will return a json with the folder content. 

Zipped archive attached below, password: uns

Feedback is welcome üôèüèª

Author: jon.forbord
Content: There‚Äôs currently no good inherent way of using images and videos and pdfs and so on in perspective that allows you to do it dynamically. This module is intended to solve that problem, by exposing folder content (files) as web resources you can then embed into perspective with dynamic bindings.

Author: jpmac.s
Content:
i've recently built my first software tool that converts tag exports to Ignition tags. Its got a GUI and does pattern matching to check for candidates to convert to a UDT.  If it detects a data type UDT, it will build the UDT. Then creates the test sheets ready for FAT , SAT etc in excel and when ready it will convert the tags to a JSON import. 

I always had a lot of Python scripts which did the trick in the past but the goal is to have a single program that does all the major PLCs/Legacy SCADAs. Still currently testing and adding features.

Author: rma002
Content:
Hi All

Can anyone provide any tips or best practises on mapping 20000 tags per site in to a standard tag structure for ignition HMIs 

PLCs are siemens s7300 and s7400s in 5 sites with poor structure and naming 

Plan is to standardise them into ignition standard structure however looking for some tools or suggestions on standardising the process

For example mapping UDTs from siemens directly into ignition 

Maybe use perspective instead of excel to import tags and so on 

Any tips would be appreciated

Author: jon.forbord
Content: They are doing some touches on it for 8.3 I‚Äôve heard.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Starting point is getting them into excel, break the tags out into the key attributes, tag name ,data type, description , area and site. You will need a script that can read that file and translate them into ignition tags and translate the data types to their Siemens driver expected format. That would work for a flat import, but if you want to use UDTs and improve the naming convention, your script will have to find the patterns you predetermine to group UDT candidates.

Author: rma002
Content:
In one of site I have UDTs in plc in other site it‚Äôs loose tags as well 

I have an excel file 

The script should be a jython script inside project script? 

The plan is to use udts for motor and Vfds and valves otherwise might not be scalable, what do you think 

And the script that you mentioned to use to find patterns is outside of ignition?

Author: jpmac.s
Content:
Thats the time consuming part , the lack or standardisation and so many edge cases. But targeting motors and valves is a good starting point. 

Ive written all my tools external to Ignition.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: @Rma

Author: rma002
Content:
Do you think it still a good approach to udts in ignition? 

Does it make sense to add a concentrator plc to create a DB there and udts in this plc so that ignition interface remains consistent?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Thats another approach which works well, build your UDT blocks in the controller and pin the tags , this way your UDTs in Ignition only need to communicate the block ensuring its consistent. All comes down to time and money.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I'm not Jon but I'll often do different "edge" or "raw" tag providers per functional area (or line, or whatever makes sense). With a "Unified" or "MES" or something like that tag provider for cleaned up data. 

Though, I'll often use UDTs even in the Edge provider. It takes more upfront work to model but doing so makes every subsequent step faster. 

Separately, I'll usually have at least one tag group per device too.

Author: rma002
Content:
So for example 
PLCNamespace (tag provider) 
All raw tags structured same as plc with plc tag naming
No history enabled 
Used for hmi views due to all bool and byte tags here (don‚Äôt need be sent over mqtt or gan) 

UNSNamespace (tag provider) 

Structured with site area line cell 
Referencing Ints and floats from plc raw tags provider
History enabled 
Descriptive tag naming

‚Äî-
And history would be enabled only on reference tags then to not duplicate? 

Uns provider to be exposed over mqtt / gan 

‚Äî‚Äî-
Questions: will it cause any scalability issues later on, any further best practises here? 

Will it cause any performance issues? 

For asset monitoring, all assets such as motors udts or folders , conveyors, etc are in raw provider, do I duplicate them as well somehow in uns provider? The plan is to have asset monitoring / maintenance in ignition 

Appreciate the response

Author: jpmac.s
Content: I like the idea of breaking up the tag providers per PLCs . If you are going to have a raw namespace it makes sense to use that method when the PLC supports browsing and you can just dumb the tags in, however if you are going to write a script to convert, you may as well do the extra effort and clean them up with UDTs etc.

Author: rma002
Content: Im unable to find info if it‚Äôs a good idea to enable history on reference tags and not source tags to avoid duplication and also that way if source tag is change ideally it shouldn‚Äôt break the history of the tag

Author: jon.forbord
Content: We sort of do this, with a raw namespace we don‚Äôt historize and then a fully formed namespace we historize consisting of reference tags and expression tags.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I haven‚Äôt done this at a scale where I can guarantee anything, but the approach sounds good. If the data is well formed, I don‚Äôt use raw namespace + reference tags, I put the OPC tags directly in the fully formed namespace (UDTs etc).

Author: du5tins
Content: I have seen some forum posts on this. We are also doing reference tags for a fully formed namespace after we consume tags over MQTT engine. The forum posts recommended not adding alarms and history to MQTT engine because sometimes it is necessary to delete all those tags and make every connected thing rebirth. Still working on the scalability/best practices around it though because it seems like a double effort

Author: b_dawg_17
Content:
I think this depends a lot on the specifics of your use case. Ignition‚Äôs reporting module is tricky to get the hang of, but it‚Äôs inexpensive (iirc) and has a lot of parameterization capabilities. If you‚Äôre doing a one-off or a small (not growing) number of label formats, then it‚Äôs kind of a preference thing imo. If you‚Äôre in need of a flexible and reusable template, I would nudge you towards the reporting module.

All that said, I don‚Äôt have much experience with Zebra printers or what you‚Äôre able to do with them. I just know that the reporting module is finicky but powerful if you learn how to use it.

Author: vikanchira
Content: I am wondering if the QuestDB Internal Historian can be moved to another server in the same network or does it need to be in the same server as the Gateway. Why do they call it 'Internal' Historian when it is the same as just being another historian in the system. How is it different from the say... Canary historian?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You'd likely need the enterprise version (which supports TLS) if you did that. TBH, you should probably do the same locally, as it might be possible to snoop in on local unencrypted traffic and gain access to the database.  Curious how Ignition is deploying/connecting to it.  They could be using the embedded mode, which would be secure, but wouldn't allow moving it.

Author: _dyland
Content:
It's embedded. 

https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.3/ignition-modules/tag-historian/tag-history-providers#local-historian

Author: _dyland
Content:
They still have the SQL based historian as well as a "Splitter" so there are options for external historians. The door opens wider with OPC Historian collectors as they can just read the tags right out of Ignition. This could include Timebase, Pi, Telegraf, etc.

And Off memory, last year at ICC they talked about a new Historian API to open the door to external and 3rd party historians while maintaining the same scripting and tag functions inside Ignition. I would expect options like Timebase, Canary, Influx, and Timescale at minimum but would not be surprised to see support for OSI-Pi in the future (even if 3rd party). Split between paid offerings and open source projects... There is a history of 3rd party modules built by integrators and open sources so I would expect some of that. 

There was a similar announcement for scripting too, it was one of the ways they mentioned they could open the door to other scripting languages besides just Jython... As well as allowing for 3rd parties to add support for their preferred languages. 

Really feels like this 8.3 refactoring of the gateway is leading to a much more distributed and modular Ignition.

Author: _dyland
Content: Modular means they could possibly start migrating features away from requirements like Jython and Fat clients over time. Piece by piece.

Author: vikanchira
Content: That would be a welcome change

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I didn‚Äôt quite understand the historian API. Is it a write API, or readAPI, or both? And is the idea that Ignition will be the database and the third party is a client, or is it the other way around? What do they mean with 3rd party historians? Client/analysis-side or storage or all of the above?

Author: _dyland
Content: From my  understanding it was just being able to connect other non-ignition historians to Ignitions Historian Functions like the tag logging, metadata, scripting functions, and bindings. I may be completely wrong though too.

Author: _dyland
Content: https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.3/ignition-modules/tag-historian

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's the abstraction between a historical tag provider and the underlying data store. This allows perspective screens and other features (clients) to call the data store (server) through Ignition's proprietary tag provider construct. This could be the embedded QuestDB, a SQL db, or something else. It's really like a cataloging layer to provide a consistent tag historization experience.

In v8.1, the tag historian is a narrow pattern between a tag provider and those underlying SQL tables (e.g., sqlth_te, sqlt_data_X_X). In v8.3, it's a more generalized pattern not tied to SQL and a particular schema.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content:
Hi guys. We are implementing MES for our customer using Ignition (Ignition is his requirement).

While Ignition is cool platform, developing anything complex (as external library or internal script) with jython 2.7 that doesn't even support type annotations makes me "at least" unconfortable.
We wanted to use mixed approach with .NET app that will handle all the complex stuff (we're much more experienced with C# than Jython and it's not dynamically typed). I watched Walker's MES Bootcamp and I would just replace Python package with REST calls to .NET API. I read this https://support.inductiveautomation.com/hc/en-us/articles/360056397252-Python-In-Ignition where they explicitly pointed using api calls for using  python 3.

Can it be valid approach or am I moving in completely wrong direction?

Below is diagram:

Author: system24seven9226
Content: If the customer requirement is to use ignition, you aren‚Äôt really following that directive at all‚Ä¶ you‚Äôd be better off just writing your ‚Äúcomplex‚Äù business logic in Java as a native module for ignition. Then it‚Äôs one platform and one service. It also gets rid of a lot of abstraction.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: I thought that scripting and creating custom libraries can be done in Jython (at least it is what Walker is doing)

Author: system24seven9226
Content: It can, but ignition is natively Java, the jython layer is only so you can write easy scripts inside the designer with little experience. If you want fast code, use Java. If you want modern object oriented code, use Java.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @system24seven, you just advanced to level 4!

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: Fine, but I think this is strange that they are officially referencing REST calls as way to eg Python 3. If they are doing so it looks like it's valid way of doing stuff.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content:
especially when they are saying to rather use jython scripts with classes than java modules like here pturmel

https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/deciding-whether-to-write-jython-scripts-or-modules/12126

Author: system24seven9226
Content: That‚Äôs because python 3 is so different in software architecture to Java that the best way to integrate with it in particular is to abstract up to the lowest common denominator, which they have selected as rest.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Pturmel also happens to write a very large amount of Java modules with jython hooks in them so you can do functions in jython that aren‚Äôt available normally.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: This is a bit messed up for me. They push users to dynamically typed Jython, that is in long term non maintable (is like vanilla javascript nowadays, it's used mainly in legacy) and jav that can be valid solution is not promoted at all

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: Looks like I'll have to reconsider. Go with Java that is kinda similar to .NET for price of my experience or just go with REST

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Miko≈Çaj Walu≈õkiewicz, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Python3 isn‚Äôt Java compatible. Ignition didn‚Äôt have an option to use it. Writing a rest api to interface with a custom .net service is the sort of thing that creates technical debt in a company. There is a reason sepasoft didn‚Äôt use that approach to create an ignition mes platform. If you want to use .net, go build your mes on FT Optix

Author: sp00k4228
Content:
Does anyone have experience using the EAM module in Ignition?

I'm trying to figure out if it's possible to use EAM to distribute project-related files, like custom styles/themes (CSS), to Edge nodes. These files are stored locally on the Gateway (not embedded directly in the project), and it seems like EAM doesn't include them when pushing the project to other nodes.

Is there a best practice for handling this? Ideally looking for a way to maintain consistent styling across multiple Edge nodes without having to manually copy files to each one.

Edit: Guessing the short answer is no.

https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/eam-sync-folder-of-ressources/95870

could i do a workaround with WebDev maybe?

Author: jdingus
Content:
Not sure if git would be helpful here or not.  Ive had git in place for projects and then someone did a project import and overwrote my.git folder. 

If you did it maybe ignition could trigger a powershell script that would essentially git pull to get updates.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: You can make a post-request script in webdeb that takes the custom style css as a zip binary, unpacks it into the appropriate folder on the edge gateway. Then use EAM to deploy the project resource to all agents and make a script in the main gateway that calls the agents webdeb resource to push the css files..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Or go more general. Make a post script that takes a file binary input and a target folder, and copies it, and then more scripting on the main gateway to do the same.

Author: sp00k4228
Content:
Thank you!

I was thinking about WebDev as well. But the customer in question does not have that module. 

I have not used GIT with Ignition yet, but that sounds like it could be a workaround, from what i understand the support for GIT has increased in 8.3 also

Author: jon.forbord
Content: edge iot licenses includes web dev!

Author: jon.forbord
Content: And you don‚Äôt need webdev to do send post-requests..

Author: vikanchira
Content:
As an update. I have formed a product agnostic strategy and will present it to the customer.

Operation Center Overview & Product Options

Core Components
1. War Room Dashboard: Executive-level, visually impactful displays for showcasing plant performance.
2. Business Analytics: Historical data analysis for trends, KPIs, and optimization.
3. Operation Management: Real-time access for engineers/operators from any device.
4. Industrial DataOps: Backend infrastructure to connect, collect, and structure data from industrial equipment.

Product Options
1. FanRuan + HighByte + Ignition: Top-tier visuals, strong DataOps, and operator tools.
2. FanRuan + HighByte: Beautiful War Room dashboards with robust data infrastructure.
3. FanRuan + N3uron: Executive visuals with cost-effective Chinese DataOps.
4. FanRuan + Ignition: Combines executive dashboards with operational data distribution.
5. Peakboard + N3uron: German visuals, quick deployment, budget-friendly.
6. Ignition Only: All-in-one platform; requires dev effort for aesthetics.

Selection Guide
- For aesthetics & corporate image: FanRuan or Peakboard.
- For strong data infrastructure: HighByte or N3uron.
- For full operational control: Include Ignition.

Author: kvaneenennaam
Content:
Hey RMA,

Connecting the dev and prod gateways and creating a remote tag provider, in my eyes would not be done. You would keep your dev isolated from anything that isn't for testing. That is part of why the concept of a digital twins useful, the dev and QA isolation can pose a burden while developing.

In order to effectively test the HMI and tags, you will want to simulate them for the dev. My advice for Ignition without anything fancier is to: take the tags you want to simulate, identify a realistic range for the values (tag history could do this if its on), create a simulator CSV file (AI can do this these days). To truly test you would want simulated or test PLCs with logic that mirrors what you expect in prod, this is harder to do with Ignition simulator tags.

The enterprise question is an it depends answer, there are many ways to approach managing it. With 8.3 the enterprise deployment management mode will make this answer more clear as it will have more clear dev > testing > prod definitions and workflows.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Depends on what you are trying to do with a camera - and what you mean by "camera functionality".
On mobile, it has barcode functionality through the camera - 
https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.3/ignition-modules/perspective/scripting-in-perspective/perspective-session-events-scripts#barcode

And full support for IP cams - 
https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/appendix/components/vision-components/display/ip-camera-viewer

You can upload files - Including photos taken through the mobile camera - through scripting -
https://www.docs.inductiveautomation.com/docs/8.1/appendix/components/perspective-components/perspective-input-palette/perspective-file-upload/perspective-file-upload-scripting

Depending on what you need it may be easy or it may be convoluted. Worst case is a 3rd party module.

From my host I can curl https://localhost:45280/ and get a response, so I know the port is open. Content: Looks right, are you seeing anything in the Ignition logs on startup? It should say "listening on port 45280..." or something like that. We won't "connect" until you try and use the connection in HB. If you go to "Input" and browse, so you see the browse tree or get a connection error?

Author: dsi_101
Content:
Walker had a test script at one point that he shared, I took his as a base and created this.

//Use a Gateway Tag Change Script - * Wildcard will subscribe to all tags under this folder.
[default]Enterprise/*

#Set Event values from tag that triggered the event
tagValue = newValue.getValue()
tagQuality = str(newValue.getQuality())
tagPath = str(event.getTagPath().getParentPath())
tagName = str(event.getTagPath().getItemName())
scriptName = "Scr.MQTT.Plain.Publish"

if not initialChange and tagQuality == "Good":
    MQTT.Publish.Plain(tagPath=tagPath,tagValue=tagValue,tagName=tagName, parentTopic="Syn",scriptName=scriptName) #Pass Event to Project Script.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Module modules? Using the SDK? 

What‚Äôs the SNMP traps for? And what are you doing with hose mqtt subs?

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Yep SDK modules.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: SNMP traps are network generated events from things like switches that announce things like a port being unplugged. Using the module you can process these events easily.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: The MQTT sub module watches a topic and every time a publish happens it bundles the event into the event stream. No more polling MQTT tags and comparing timestamps

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Does Ignition Edge (8.3) support MQTT natively?  I can't find anything to indicate that it does.  Surprising to me.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: No. They seem to be committed to Cirrus Link providing the mqtt support.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yet the "official" modules page for 8.3 says that the Cirrus Link MQTT modules are not compatible with 8.3  I've also seen a demo showing the new Event Stream module being used to interact with MQTT brokers, but the docs for this module make no mention of MQTT.  It seems a bit odd to me that in 2025 you'd need a third party module for MQTT interaction.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, Event Streams don't appear to be supported on Ignition Edge.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Nope.

Author: system24seven9226
Content: Event streams are a structure you can develop functionality as a developer to integrate with. My module above subscribes to a broker and provides it as an event source. When I have time I‚Äôll be adding publish capability as an event handler to the same module.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Caching dependencies that you've tested and verified is a good idea.  DevOps/build processes that always get the latest version can be dangerous for mission critical apps.

Author: .killnine
Content:
Not sure what source you're talking about here but typically most systems allow you to pin dependencies to a version. 

Some even allow you to automatically pull newer minor revisions (that is, bug fixes) but not move to a new major revision (typically meaning API changes). I know that's easy with .NET and NPM dependencies. I'm certain Python has a similar mechanism with its package management.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: For sure.  Just remarking that I've seen a lot of folks with FOMO set their builds up to get the latest and greatest.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I may or may not have have made that mistake myself. üòâ

Author: shiva187.
Content: You can serve your HTML page as a resource through the web dev module. You can save the static html inside of ignition and then expose a GET or POST  endpoint that renders the HTML. You can also add JavaScript files as resources and link them in the html

I have done that but now wondering how to link ignition tags to the html 

Do I need to expose tags via api and then call that api into that html

Author: shiva187.
Content: I would have to see a little more of your setup to make the best call, but yes it sounds like exposing the tag via a web dev end point (a system.tag.read formatted as json) that your JavaScript could then call and retrieve the data and update a value in the html via document.querySelector or similar
